questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right-sided facial heaviness for the past 10 hours. He also reports decreased tear production on the right side and the inability to tolerate loud sounds that started simultaneously. Medical history is remarkable for a right-sided parotid gland adenoma which was surgically resected one month ago. The patient has no hearing loss, ringing sensation in the ears, or difficulty walking. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown in the image below.

 


Examination of the right auditory canal and auricle is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings seen in this patient?

choices.text: Lower motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve
Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve

questions.solution:
With paralysis of the upper and lower right side of the face, together with loss of tear production and hyperacusis, this patient most likely has Bell palsy, a mononeuropathy affecting the lower motor neuron of the facial nerve (CN VII). The etiology is often idiopathic, with the possible cause being viral-associated ischemic demyelination (e.g., herpes simplex, Epstein-Barr) or sometimes as a complication of Lyme disease or sarcoidosis.

The motor pathway for the facial nerve starts from the motor cortex, where its upper motor neuron (UMN) travels downwards through the internal capsule to reach the facial motor nucleus in the lateral pons. This nucleus has a dorsal and ventral part. The former innervates muscles of the upper face and lacrimation, while the latter innervates muscles of the lower face and salivation. The dorsal region receives innervation from the UMN of both hemispheres. The ventral region receives innervation only from the UMN of the opposite hemisphere. That is why unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side.

The UMN fibers cross over before they synapse with LMN, which then travel ipsilaterally, supplying the same side of the face. Therefore, an LMN lesion affects the upper and lower side of the face ipsilaterally.





Option Analysis

✅ Lower motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Upper motor neuron lesion of the involved cranial nerve:
Incorrect: Unilateral UMN lesions (e.g. stroke) only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side. The upper facial muscles receive dual innervation from the ipsilateral and contralateral sides, which means upper facial muscles are spared when there is an upper motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve. This patient has paralysis on the right side of the upper and lower facial muscles, making a UMN lesion unlikely.
❌ Reactivation of a dormant virus:
Incorrect: The major complication of reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus is the Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which typically includes the triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. This patient does not have otalgia, and physical examination of the auricle and auditory canal is unremarkable.
❌ Recent surgery:
Incorrect: The motor component of the facial nerve enters the parotid gland before it divides into the terminal branches to innervate the facial muscles. Injury to this area can lead to ipsilateral paralysis of the facial muscles. However, it would not explain the sudden onset of symptoms one month after the procedure and the hyperacusis in this patient.
❌ Tumor at the cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: Even though a tumor at the cerebellopontine angle (e.g. schwannoma) can sometimes involve the facial nerve, it is usually preceded by the symptoms of CN VIII impingement (i.e., tinnitus, ataxia, vertigo, or sensorineural hearing loss), none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 73-year-old person comes to a neurology clinic to establish care after a recent hospitalization for stroke. The patient sustained acute right-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the left middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy due to presenting eight hours following symptom onset. Muscle strength significantly improved after physical therapy. However, the patient reports that they are now unable to differentiate between the fingers in their right hand, and they are now unable to write. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength is 4/5 on the right side. When asked to elevate the left hand, the patient elevates the right hand. The patient is unable to solve a simple mathematical problem. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with inability to recognize individual fingers (finger agnosia), left-right disorientation, and acalculia (inability to solve simple math); they most likely have Gerstmann syndrome. 

The angular gyrus refers to an area located in the inferior parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere that integrates visual, acoustic, and somatosensory information necessary for problem solving (in particular, speech and number processing). It is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Occlusion of these arteries in the dominant hemisphere can result in Gerstmann Syndrome (as in this patient), or, in rare cases, the syndrome can result from a traumatic brain injury or a brain tumor in the same region. Clinical manifestations include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia (inability to write), and alexia (inability to read).  



Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.  
❌ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body). 
✅ Gerstmann syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents for evaluation of a headache. The patient was in his usual state of health until several days ago, when he noted an occipital headache that has progressed and is now associated with nausea, vomiting, and fever. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and kidney transplant, for which he takes tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 38.0 °C (100.4 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for photophobia, nuchal rigidity, and scattered petechiae over the upper and lower extremities. Based on the image below, which of the following is the most appropriate anatomical location to perform the procedure to diagnose this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This immunocompromised patient with headache, fever, and associated nuchal rigidity and photophobia most likely has meningitis. The most appropriate test to diagnose this condition is a lumbar puncture performed at the L4/L5 intervertebral space, denoted by choice D in the diagram above.  

Indications for the performance of a lumbar puncture (LP) are many, namely the evaluation of infection in the central nervous system, subarachnoid hemorrhage, central nervous system malignancies, and demyelinating disorders such as Guillain Barre syndrome. LP is generally safe; however, it is contraindicated in patients with increased intracranial pressure, bleeding diathesis, or suspected spinal epidural abscess.    

Performance of the procedure requires sterile technique and positioning the patient in either a lateral decubitus position or sitting upright. In an average adult, the spinal cord tapers and ends at the level between the L1 and L2 vertebrae. In neonates, it ends at L3, so the procedure is safely performed via needle insertion at the L4/L5 interspace in both populations. This space is most easily identified via direct palpation of the superior iliac crests and tracing an imaginary line from this point to the lumbar spine. Palpation of the lumbar spine at this location will reveal the L4/L5 spinous processes, and the area for needle insertion is between the two.  

The insertion sequence includes skin, subcutaneous tissue, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, epidural space, and finally, the subarachnoid space. Once in this space, removal of the stylet will reveal the flow of cerebrospinal fluid through the proximal end of the needle.  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Choice A represents the thoracic spinal vertebral interspace, which is too high to perform this procedure safely. Lumbar puncture at this interspace risks damage to the thoracic spinal cord.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Choice B represents the thoracic interspace between ribs 9 and 10. This area may be appropriate for performing a thoracentesis, not a lumbar puncture.  
❌ C:
Incorrect: Choice C represents the L2 interspace, which is too high to perform a lumbar puncture safely. Performance of this procedure at this interspace risks direct injury to the spinal cord.  
✅ D:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Choice E represents the sacrum, which does not have an interspace for the performance of a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling two stories while washing windows on scaffolding. Per paramedics, the patient fell directly on his back, was helmeted, and did not suffer the loss of consciousness. On arrival, temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 178/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. The patient’s primary survey is intact. The patient's secondary survey is notable for bruising and tenderness over the cervical and thoracic spine. A neurological examination demonstrates loss of sensation starting below the xiphoid process. The patient has 2+ triceps and brachioradialis reflexes and 5/5 strength of the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to move the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following reflects the most likely level of spinal injury?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for trauma evaluation after sustaining an injury to the spine. The neurologic examination is consistent with preserved sensation and motor strength above the level of T7, which is best approximated at the xiphoid process level.    

Pathologies that affect the spinal cord are diverse and include trauma, ischemia, infection, autoimmune conditions, neoplasm, and hereditary-degenerative diseases. Compressive etiologies (e.g. those resulting in direct physical impingement on the spinal cord) include tumors, spinal epidural abscesses, hematomas, herniated disks, or bony disease. Spinal cord transection can also result from direct trauma such as stab wounds, gunshot wounds, or extreme shearing forces. Ischemia, particularly from the anterior or posterior spinal arteries, may also result in injury to the spinal cord.    

Regardless of the etiology, the level of injury can be determined via a focused neurological assessment, including sensation testing, motor function testing, and reflex testing. The absence of sensation below a particular dermatome in conjunction with correlating motor and reflex deficits can indicate the level of a lesion.  


Option Analysis

✅ T7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ T4:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at T4 would present with loss of sensation below the nipple line; this patient has preserved sensation at this dermatome.  
❌ C2:
Incorrect: A spinal lesion at C2 would result in loss of sensation below the posterior half of the skull; injuries to this spinal level are often lethal due to damage to brainstem structures.  
❌ C4:
Incorrect: Injury to the C4 level would result in loss of sensation below the collar line and possible diaphragmatic dysfunction since this spinal cord level helps innervate the diaphragm.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: A spinal cord lesion at T10 would result in loss of sensation starting at the level of the umbilicus.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to progressively worsening headaches. He states he was “feeling fine” until 2 weeks ago when he started having fevers, accompanied by malaise, and headache. Medical history is significant for renal transplantation from a living donor 6 months ago. Medications include tacrolimus and prednisone. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 138/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic and in distress due to pain. Neck is supple, and there are no focal neurologic signs. Lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals an elevated opening pressure, elevated cell count, low glucose and high protein. Examination of the CSF shows the following:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    

Appropriate treatment is initiated. Which of the following is a side effect associated with this treatment?
questions.solution:
This immunocompromised patient is presenting with headaches, fever, and malaise; given the lumbar puncture analysis, the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is confirmed by the demonstration of clear halos on India ink staining.   

Cryptococcus neoformans is a budding, heavily encapsulated yeast (not dimorphic) that can be found in soil and pigeon droppings. It is acquired through the inhalation of spores with subsequent hematogenous dissemination to the brain meninges. Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., organ transplant, HIV) are specifically at risk for infection with cryptococcus. Treatment consists of induction therapy with amphotericin B and flucytosine followed by fluconazole for the maintenance period.  

Amphotericin B is a medication used to treat systemic mycosis conditions including Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Mucor, and Candida. It works by binding ergosterol (unique to fungi) and forming membrane pores that lead to leakage of electrolytes. Side effects include fever, chills, hypotension, nephrotoxicity, arrhythmias and anemia. Hydration prior to treatment is recommended as it reduces the nephrotoxic effect. Liposomal (lipid formulations) amphotericin is better tolerated. Supplements of potassium and magnesium are recommended due to depletion from altered renal tubule permeability.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cytochrome P-450:
Incorrect: Inhibition of cytochrome P-450 is a side effect of azole medications (e.g., clotrimazole, fluconazole) which are not used in the initial treatment of cryptococcal meningitis. Fluconazole is only used during the maintenance phase of treatment or if first-line medication is not available or not well tolerated. 
❌ Hepatotoxicity:
Incorrect: Hepatotoxicity can be seen with terbinafine used for onychomycosis (dermatophytic infection of the nails). Other side effects include gastrointestinal upset, headaches, and taste disturbance. Terbinafine is not used for cryptococcus treatment. 
❌ Histamine release:
Incorrect: Flushing caused by histamine release can be seen with echinocandins use (e.g. caspofungin). Echinocandins are used for the treatment of invasive aspergillosis and candida, not cryptococcus.
✅ Arrhythmias :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Hypercalcemia is associated with foscarnet, which is used to treat CMV retinitis and acyclovir-resistant HSV. Other side effects include nephrotoxicity, electrolyte abnormalities  (hypo/hypercalcemia, hypo/hyperphosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia), and seizures. It has no role in the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man was brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a severe headache for the past hour. The patient has never had a similar episode in the past. His past medical history includes end-stage renal disease due to autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 172/104 mmHg. Non-contrast CT-brain demonstrates hyperlucent density within the subarachnoid space. The patient is subsequently admitted to the neuro-critical care unit for further monitoring. Four days following the incident, the patient’s nurse notes new onset left-sided hemiplegia and worsening somnolence. Administration of which of the following medication classes could have prevented this patient’s current clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) secondary to rupture of a berry aneurysm. In SAH, the bleeding occurs between the arachnoid and pia mater, most commonly in the anterior half of the circle of Willis at bifurcations between the anterior communicating artery and the anterior cerebral artery. Genetic disorders such as ADPKD, Marfan syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome are associated with impaired collagen synthesis and predispose individuals to developing saccular aneurysms.

After the initial insult, the patient develops focal neurologic deficits and lethargy, consistent with delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI). DCI occurs in ⅓ of patients with aneurysmal SAH, typically between 4 to 14 days following symptom onset. The pathophysiology of DCI is poorly understood, but it is postulated to be due to post-traumatic vasospasm with subsequent ischemia to surrounding brain tissue. To mitigate these effects, patients with SAH are frequently prescribed calcium channel blockers (e.g. nimodipine) to relax the smooth muscle found within cerebral vasculature. 

Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-1 agonist:
Incorrect: Augmenting blood pressure with vasopressors is the cornerstone of first-line therapy for delayed cerebral ischemia. Norepinephrine, dopamine, and phenylephrine can all be used to improve cerebral blood flow and/or cerebral oxygenation, resulting in clinical improvement of the neurological deficit in many patients. However, these medications would not have prevented this patient’s current clinical condition.
❌ Benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine medications such as lorazepam can help to mitigate active seizure activity following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH); however, routine administration of benzodiazepines is not recommended after SAH unless clinically warranted.
✅ Calcium channel blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction is common after subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH); however, routine administration of glucocorticoids is not recommended after SAH.
❌ Nonselective beta-blocker:
Incorrect: Blood pressure control is necessary in patients presenting with subarachnoid hemorrhage, and current guidelines suggest the goal is to maintain systolic blood pressure (SBP) <160 mmHg or mean arterial pressure (MAP) <110 mmHg. Beta-blockers, however, would not have prevented this patient’s current condition.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he was found unresponsive at home. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension. The patient's last medication refill was almost two years ago. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 109/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 240/190 mm Hg. The patient has extensor posturing and pinpoint pupils. A CT scan of the head without contrast is shown below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia  
Despite resuscitative measures, the patient dies several hours later. Damage to which of the following structures is most associated with the depressed level of consciousness observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a hypertensive hemorrhage in the posterior rostral pons, a portion of the brainstem that houses the reticular activating system (RAS).

The RAS is a network of neurons originating in the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain that is especially important in maintaining consciousness. The RAS sends fibers towards the cerebral cortex, ensuring wakefulness and the ability to recognize and react to stimuli. Lesions of the tegmentum of the upper pons and midbrain RAS reduce the level of arousal and consciousness, leading to lethargy, stupor, and coma.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rostral ventral medulla  :
Incorrect: The rostral ventromedial medulla refers to a group of neurons located close to the midline of the medulla oblongata. This region transmits both descending inhibitory and excitatory fibers to dorsal horn spinal cord neurons, which are characterized by their response to nociceptive inputs.  
✅ Reticular activating system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Internal capsule:
Incorrect: Damage to the internal capsule presents with contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and contralateral hemisensory loss. The internal capsule is often affected in patients with putaminal hemorrhages. This patient’s CT scan is suggestive of a pontine hemorrhage.  
❌ Posterior pituitary  :
Incorrect: The posterior pituitary releases oxytocin and vasopressin produced by the hypothalamus. These hormones do not play a role in maintaining consciousness.  
❌ Basal ganglia  :
Incorrect: The “basal ganglia” refers to a group of subcortical nuclei responsible for motor control, motor learning, executive and behavioral function, as well as emotional regulation. It is not involved in maintaining consciousness.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of abnormal eating behavior. For the past few weeks, the patient has been eating more and more. This week, the patient ate five to six meals a day and has gained 17 kg in the past two months. The patient had a craniopharyngioma surgically resected three months ago. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is now 34 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone, growth hormone, prolactin, and cortisol levels are normal. Damage to which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with new onset hyperphagia after a recent intracranial surgery for the resection of a craniopharyngioma. Based on these findings, the patient has most likely suffered damage to the ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus.  

The hypothalamus is located between the optic chiasma and the mammillary bodies and serves as the site of regulation for temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. Damage to the hypothalamus occurs from tumors such as a craniopharyngiomas, radiotherapy, traumatic brain injury, infiltrative disorders,  inflammatory diseases, and surgery.  

The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus regulates blood glucose. Stimulation of the ventromedial nucleus by the hormone leptin, a product of adipose tissue, induces satiety. When the ventromedial nucleus is damaged, hyperphagia from an uncontrolled voracious appetite and hypothalamic obesity result.  



Option Analysis

❌ Lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The lateral nucleus of the hypothalamus responds to ghrelin, which is produced by the stomach to initiate hunger and increase appetite. Injury sustained to the lateral nucleus can cause loss of appetite, anorexia, and subsequent starvation. This patient has the opposite clinical presentation.
❌ Posterior hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus increases body temperature and is activated by sympathetic input. A lesion in this region will result in poikilothermia.
❌ Suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The suprachiasmatic nucleus receives input from photosensitive cells in the retina and transmits this information to the pineal gland and other hypothalamic nuclei to regulate circadian rhythm.
❌ Paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The paraventricular nucleus produces oxytocin, which is transported to nerve terminals in the posterior pituitary and stored for eventual release. Oxytocin promotes milk ejection and uterine contraction in females.
✅ Ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia in solids and liquids. The symptoms started six months ago and have gradually worsened. She also has noticed weakness in the right shoulder for a similar period. The patient does not smoke and has no chronic conditions. Physical examination of the head and neck reveals a decreased left gag reflex, uvular deviation to the right, and atrophy of the left trapezius muscle. A head MRI is obtained, and a mass is detected. Which of the following is the most likely location of the mass?
questions.solution:
Jugular foramen syndrome is the constellation of symptoms resulting from compression of the cranial nerves emerging from the jugular foramen at the skull base.

The jugular foramen is an opening on the inferior surface of the skull between the petrous temporal bone and occipital bone. The sigmoid sinus and cranial nerves IX, X, and XI course through the jugular fossa to exit from the inferior aspect of the skull.



The glossopharyngeal nerve carries motor, sensory, and parasympathetic fibers. It aids in swallowing by supplying motor innervation to the stylopharyngeus muscle. It also carries taste and normal sensation from the posterior third of the tongue. The vagus nerve assists in palatal elevation, speech phonation, blood pressure, and heart rate regulation. The accessory nerve is a pure motor nerve that innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.  

A mass extending into the jugular foramen (e.g., glomus jugulare paraganglioma, schwannoma, meningioma) can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. Jugular foramen syndrome can also develop due to non-neoplastic etiologies, including penetrating trauma, congenital conditions (e.g. primary cholesteatoma), and vascular abnormalities (e.g. internal jugular vein thrombosis).  

The clinical presentation of jugular foramen syndrome involves loss of taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue (IX), vocal cord paralysis (X), and an absent gag reflex (IX, X). In addition, patients may have weakness and atrophy of the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles (XI). Due to its location within the petrous temporal bone, pathologies affecting the jugular foramen can also cause conductive hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. If there is a significant intracranial extension of the tumor, symptoms of elevated intracranial pressure may develop.  

Option Analysis

✅ Left jugular foramen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left internal auditory meatus:
Incorrect: Cranial nerves VII and VIII pass through the internal auditory meatus. A mass in this location would cause compression of these nerves, resulting in facial paralysis and hearing loss symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s presentation is due to compression of the cranial nerves IX, X, and XI.     
❌ Left hypoglossal canal:
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) exits the skull through the hypoglossal canal, and compression of this nerve can cause tongue paralysis. However, this patient’s presentation is more likely due to jugular foramen syndrome, wherein cranial nerves IX, X, and XI are compressed as they pass through the jugular foramen.
❌ Left foramen spinosum:
Incorrect: The foramen spinosum contains the middle meningeal artery, middle meningeal vein, and meningeal branch of the mandibular foramen. Compression of these structures would not account for the symptoms experienced by this patient.
❌ Foramen magnum:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests compression of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, likely at the jugular foramen. A mass in the foramen magnum would not cause compression of these cranial nerves.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to the recent onset of seizure. Her parents report that 2 days ago, she started complaining of headaches and fever after returning from a fishing trip to Florida. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is postictal and responds only to noxious stimuli. Pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Meningeal signs are positive. Imaging results are equivocal. Lumbar puncture is obtained, and the results are shown below:  

 
 Cerebrospinal fluid 
 Opening pressure  500 mm H2O 
 Protein   250 mg/dL 
 Glucose  20 mg/dL 
 RBCs  1000 cells//mm3 
 WBC count   10000/µL 
 Neutrophils   90%  
 Lymphocytes  10% 
 Gram stain   Negative  
 Wet mount   

Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with rapidly progressive headaches, fever, altered mental status, and new onset of seizure. In light of the recent fishing trip and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis showing very high opening pressure, very high neutrophilic lymphocytosis, numerous RBCs and motile protozoan on wet mount, the most likely diagnosis is primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri.   

Naegleria fowleri is a protozoan parasite that can be found in fresh water sources (thermophilic amoebae) worldwide. The most common risk factor for infection is recreational water activities. Trophozoites from the water cross the cribriform plates to reach the brain. PAM is an acute hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis with an extremely high mortality rate. Patients often present with high fevers, severe headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, behavioral changes, seizures, and altered mental status. CSF analysis typically shows high WBC count with marked polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, elevated protein, numerous RBCs (due to hemorrhage) but negative routine bacterial cultures and gram stain. Diagnosis is based upon clinical suspicion and is established by observation of motile trophozoites on CSF wet mount or by polymerase chain reaction. Conventional treatment includes amphotericin B (first-line) as well as other agents. Amphotericin B is a medication used to treat systemic mycosis conditions including Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Mucor, Candida, etc. It works by binding ergosterol (unique to fungi) and forming membrane pores that lead to leakage of electrolytes, and it can therefore result in adverse effects such as electrolyte disturbances and cardiac arrhythmias.  

Option Analysis

❌ Metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by forming toxic free radicals that damage the bacterial DNA. It is also used to treat some protozoal and anaerobic infections. Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of Entamoeba histolytica but not for Naegleria fowleri infections.
✅ Amphotericin B:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin is an anti-tuberculosis drug that works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It is also indicated for meningococcal prophylaxis for close contacts. It is not indicated for primary amebic meningoencephalitis. 
❌ Pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Pyrimethamine is a medication that interferes with the regeneration of tetrahydrofolic acid by the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. It is used for the treatment of toxoplasmosis infection, not primary amebic meningoencephalitis. 
❌ Imipenem :
Incorrect:  Imipenem is a broad-spectrum, β-lactamase-resistant carbapenem used for the treatment of gram-positive cocci or gram-negative rods, as well as anaerobes. It is usually reserved for life-threatening infections or after other drugs have failed. However, it is not indicated for the treatment of primary amebic meningoencephalitis.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to worsening occipital headache, difficulty walking, and blurred vision for the past two months. The patient reports associated nausea and vomiting. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.2°F), pulse is 40/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Neurologic examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema and neck stiffness. A non-contrast CT-brain is demonstrated below.  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
While awaiting reassessment in the emergency department, the patient suddenly decompensates and dies. A post-mortem autopsy reveals brain herniation as the cause of death. Which of the following mechanisms of herniation most likely lead to this patient’s decompensation?
questions.solution:
A tonsillar herniation is characterized by descent of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum, which compresses the medulla against the clivus/odontoid process. When the cerebellar tonsils herniate, they can compress the brainstem respiratory and cardiac centers, leading to coma and death. This type of herniation is often described as "coning,”  as the brain tissue coming down through the foramen is squeezed into a cone. Common causes of this herniation include tumors or bleeding in the posterior cranial fossa.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cingulate herniation  :
Incorrect: Cingulate (or subfalcine) herniation is the most common type of cerebral herniation and is characterized by displacement of the cingulate gyrus beneath the free edge of the falx cerebri due to elevated intracranial pressure. This patient has evidence of a posterior fossa mass and tonsillar herniation.  
❌ Transtentorial herniation  :
Incorrect: Transtentorial (or central) herniation is a type of cerebral herniation that results in the caudal displacement of the brainstem, rupture of the paramedian basilar artery branches and Duret hemorrhages.  
❌ Uncal herniation  :
Incorrect: Uncal herniation is a subtype of the herniation that results in compression of the innermost portion of the temporal lobe (the uncus) and direct compression of the oculomotor nerve.  
✅ Tonsillar herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation  :
Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or a surgical site in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a persistent ringing sensation in his right ear for the past three months. He also reports progressive hearing loss in the right ear and right-sided facial heaviness that started simultaneously. The symptoms did not respond to over-the-counter pseudoephedrine. He has no medical problems and does not take any medications. Family history is significant for hearing loss in his father requiring hearing aid at the age of 75. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right-sided facial numbness, asymmetric smile, and diminished corneal reflex in the right eye. Weber test is positive for sensorineural hearing loss on the right side. This patient's condition suggests an intracranial mass located in which of the following locations?

choices.text: In the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity
Between the cerebellum and the lateral pons

questions.solution:
This patient has right-sided sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, facial numbness, and paralysis, which is concerning for a vestibular schwannoma, the most common cerebellopontine angle (i.e. between the cerebellum and pons) tumor in adults.  

Vestibular schwannomas arise from the Schwann cells of the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). These benign tumors often compress the nerves originating from the cerebellopontine angle, including CN V and VII. Symptoms can vary based on the pattern of nerve involvement and can include:  
 
  1.  The cochlear part of CN VIII: Sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus (ear ringing). 
  2.  The vestibular part of CN VIII: Vertigo, disequilibrium, and nystagmus.  
  3.  The facial nerve (CN VII): Paralysis of the muscles of facial expression, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, and hyperacusis (paralysis of the stapedius). 
  4.  Trigeminal nerve (CN V): Loss of sensation around the mouth and nose, loss of corneal reflex, and paralysis of the muscles of mastication. 

Option Analysis

❌ Above the diaphragma sellae:
Incorrect: Craniopharyngiomas are typically located in the suprasellar region. Patients usually present with signs and symptoms of hypothalamic or pituitary dysfunction and changes in vision due to compression of the optic chiasm (e.g. bitemporal hemianopsia), none of which are seen in this patient. 
❌ Over the lateral hemispheric fissure:
Incorrect: Meningiomas arising from meningo-epithelial cells of arachnoid mater are commonly found over the lateral hemispheric fissure and in the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity. They usually present with headaches, focal neurological deficits, or seizures.
❌ In the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity:
Incorrect: Meningiomas usually arise in the parasagittal aspect of the brain convexity. This patient’s findings are localized to CN V, CN VII, and CN VIII, making a mass at the cerebellopontine angle more likely.
✅ Between the cerebellum and the lateral pons:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ In the dorsal midbrain:
Incorrect: Pineal gland tumors (e.g. germ cell tumors) are found in the dorsal midbrain. They usually present in the pediatric population with signs of increased intracranial pressure secondary to obstructive hydrocephalus and Parinaud syndrome (i.e. upward gaze palsy).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of visual problems in his right eye for the last six months. The patient tells the physician that he finds it difficult to see with his right eye because the eyelid is covering part of his vision. He is also experiencing double vision. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the right eye is pointing down and out, and the right pupil is 9 mm. The right eyelid is drooping. Visual field examination is unremarkable except for diplopia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a “down and out” right eye and associated ptosis, mydriasis, and diplopia; he most likely has an oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former component supplies the ciliary muscles, which alter the shape of the lens to allow better focus on near objects, and the sphincter pupillae muscle, which constricts the pupil (miosis). Meanwhile, the inner somatic fibers provide nerve supply to the levator palpebrae superioris, which elevates the eyelid, and four of the extraocular muscles (superior, middle, inferior recti, and inferior oblique). These muscles are responsible for adjusting the gaze superiorly, medially, and inferiorly.  A helpful way to remember the anatomy of the parasympathetic and somatic fibers in CN III is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral.

Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, which are innervated by CNs IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Meanwhile, compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Other possible causes of CN III palsy include injury to the CN III nucleus in the brainstem (e.g. demyelination), supranuclear injuries (e.g. injuries in the cerebral cortex), or injury in the cavernous sinus, where the CN III passes (along with other nerves and vascular structures). 

Option Analysis

✅ CN III (oculomotor) palsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CN IV (trochlear) palsy :
Incorrect: Patients with CN IV (trochlear) palsy present with vertical diplopia that worsens when reading or going downstairs. CN IV palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis.
❌ CN VI (abducens) palsy:
Incorrect: CN VI palsy is not associated with ptosis or mydriasis, and in CN VI palsy, the eye is deviated medially. 
❌ Horner syndrome :
Incorrect: Although Horner syndrome does present with ptosis, it is associated with miosis, not mydriasis. Also, diplopia is not expected in Horner syndrome. 
❌ CN VII (facial) palsy :
Incorrect: Facial nerve palsy is associated with loss of motor function in the muscles of the face. The facial nerve does not provide parasympathetic innervation to the eye (mydriasis), nor does it innervate the extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to a primary care clinic by his partner for evaluation of ongoing behavioral problems. The patient has a long history of aggressive behavioral outbursts and is known to be apathetic and unapologetic for his actions. Past medical history includes blunt head trauma at age 22 after being struck in the head with an iron rod. Prior to the accident, the patient was well-mannered and an excellent student; however, after the accident, he became progressively distractible, disobedient towards adults of authority, and quarrelsome. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Damage to which of the following cortical areas is the most likely precipitant of this patient’s behavioral changes?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits abnormal behavior including aggression, distractibility, apathy, and impulsivity. These changes in behavior are reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.  

The prefrontal cortex is located anterior to the precentral area in the frontal lobe and includes the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. It harbors both afferent and efferent pathways to and from the thalamus, hypothalamus, cerebral cortex, and the corpus striatum. The prefrontal cortex governs personality, social behavior, and executive functions, including decision making, reasoning, and emotional regulation.  

Damage to the prefrontal cortex results in disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior. Re-emergence of primitive reflexes are often observed.

Damage to the prefrontal cortex can occur secondary to trauma, cerebrovascular disease, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease (e.g. fronto-temporal dementia).  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Prefrontal cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Broca’s area:
Incorrect: Broca’s area lies at the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere and has connections to the motor cortex – specifically to areas that control the muscles of the larynx, mouth, soft palate, and the tongue, as well as muscles of respiration. The primary function of this area includes formation, or production, of words and speech. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Wernicke’s area:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area encompasses a portion of the superior temporal gyrus along with the supramarginal and angular gyri of the parietal lobe. This area of the brain is responsible for comprehending written and spoken language. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Rostral to the premotor cortex and extending into the middle frontal gyrus is the frontal eye field, which controls voluntary eye movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity and integrates both sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. This patient’s changes in behavior are instead reflective of damage to the prefrontal cortex.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphonia and dysphagia with solids and liquids. The patient’s symptoms started a month ago and have been progressively worsening. He has had difficulty drinking water and frequently experiences associated regurgitation and coughing. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals palatal deviation towards the right side and an absent gag reflex. MRI of the brain shows a mass. Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this mass?
questions.solution:
Bulbar palsy is a lower motor neuron defect that arises from injuries to the nucleus ambiguus.

The nucleus ambiguus is a group of motor neurons situated in the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. The emerging fibers from the nucleus ambiguus give rise to cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, which travel to ipsilateral somatic muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. These muscles are responsible for generating speech and swallowing. The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) plays a role in swallowing by innervating the stylopharyngeus muscle. The vagus nerve innervates the palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal muscles. The spinal accessory nerve innervates the cranial portion of the laryngeal muscles.  

Bulbar palsy is most often caused by ischemic stroke and tumors. Other less common causes include degenerative disorders (e.g. ALS), autoimmune diseases (e.g. Guillain-Barre syndrome), and hereditary conditions (e.g. Kennedy disease).    

Clinical features arise due to isolated paralysis of the palate, pharynx, and larynx. They include dysphagia to both solids and liquids, hoarseness, aspiration of secretions, nasal regurgitation, dysphonia, dysarthria, and slurred speech. The uvula often deviates to the side contralateral to the causative lesion on examination. The gag reflex is often absent. 



In contrast, pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron defect involving cranial nerves IX, X, and XI (damage to the connections between the cortex and medulla) that presents with symptoms similar to bulbar palsy. Reflexes are normal or more prominent in pseudobulbar palsy. In addition, atrophy and fasciculations are absent. Lastly, pseudobulbar palsy is characterized by emotional lability, which is not seen in bulbar palsy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Left nucleus ambiguus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Corticobulbar tract bilaterally :
Incorrect: Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by a lesion affecting the bilateral corticobulbar tracts. However, unlike bulbar palsy, pseudobulbar palsy is not associated with an absent gag reflex. In addition, pseudobulbar palsy is associated with emotional lability, which is not noted in this patient. 
❌ Right cerebral cortex :
Incorrect: This patient has dysphagia, dysphonia, palatal deviation, and loss of the gag reflex. These findings are suggestive of bulbar palsy, which is a lower motor neuron lesion. In contrast, lesions in the cerebral cortex would be classified as upper motor neuron lesions.
❌ Right nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side in patients with bulbar palsy. This patient has rightwards uvula deviation, which means the causative lesion is on the left side.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of numbness in the upper extremities that started several days ago. The patient has no significant past medical history, but he did have an episode of trigeminal neuralgia 4 months ago, which resolved spontaneously. He does not have any urinary incontinence, but he mentions that he took fiber supplements last year due to several weeks of constipation that “resolved on its own.” Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows decreased vibratory and positional sensation in both upper extremities but no other sensory loss. An MRI is performed and shows the following:  


 Image reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following medications is likely to prevent future exacerbations of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with various neurological dysfunctions (e.g., paresthesias, constipation, trigeminal neuralgia) over the past year that have all resolved spontaneously. Taking into account the MRI scan, which demonstrates multiple periventricular plaques, he likely has multiple sclerosis (MS).  

Three therapeutic categories are used in the treatment of MS:  

1) Prevention of exacerbations with disease-modifying drugs (DMDs). All patients with relapsing-remitting MS should begin treatment with DMDs as soon as possible to prevent further exacerbations and slow the disease process. DMDs include interferon-beta, glatiramer acetate, alemtuzumab, and natalizumab. The initial choice of a specific DMD should be individualized according to disease activity and risk of adverse effects.  
2) Limiting the severity and duration of an acute MS attack. First-line treatment for acute exacerbations is high-dose glucocorticoid therapy. If the patient’s symptoms fail to improve, plasma exchange should be considered.
3) Supportive therapy aimed at improving or eliminating the various clinical complaints. This therapy includes medications that treat spasticity (e.g. baclofen), paresthesias (e.g., carbamazepine, amitriptyline), and concurrent psychiatric conditions (e.g., SSRIs, SNRIs).

Option Analysis

✅ Glatiramer acetate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen is a GABA receptor agonist that acts within the central nervous system. Although it is commonly used in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) to treat muscle spasticity, it is not a disease-modifying drug and would therefore not prevent future attacks. 
❌ High-dose glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Acute attacks of MS are treated with high-dose methylprednisolone. Corticosteroids have various immunosuppressive properties (e.g. induction of T-cell apoptosis). Given Th1 cells initiate the demyelinating episodes, corticosteroids would therefore be helpful during acute flares. However, the medication would not prevent future exacerbations. 
❌ Plasmapheresis :
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis can be used in patients with acute exacerbations of MS who do not respond to glucocorticoid therapy. Plasmapheresis involves removal of blood plasma and then reinfusion; this procedure may reduce the number of antibodies against myelin. However, plasmapheresis is not effective in reducing future MS relapses.
❌ Carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine can be used to treat painful paresthesias in patients with MS. Brain lesions can cause pain and paresthesia in the face, trunk, and limbs. Although helpful for symptomatic treatment, carbamazepine is unlikely to prevent the recurrence of future attacks in patients with MS.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) began his first cycle of chemotherapy two days ago. Today, he endorses severe nausea and vomiting. Which of the following structures is involved in the pathway responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's nausea and vomiting are a result of stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) located within the area postrema. This structure is found on the floor of the fourth ventricle at the caudal end of the rhomboid fossa, near the entrance of the central canal. The CTZ does not have a well-developed blood-brain barrier but rather fenestrated capillaries, allowing chemical substances to cross from the bloodstream. Thus the CTZ  can sense emetogenic substances, including chemotherapeutics, alcohol, toxins, and hormones that directly stimulate the vomiting reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Area postrema  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Medial geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The medial geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the auditory cortex of the temporal lobe and is involved in processing auditory information.  
❌ Lateral geniculate nucleus  :
Incorrect: The lateral geniculate nucleus is a thalamic structure that projects to the calcarine sulcus and is involved in processing visual information.  
❌ Posterior hypothalamus  :
Incorrect: The posterior hypothalamus is responsible for the body's ability to warm itself via sympathetic output.  
❌ Ventral pons  :
Incorrect: The ventral pons contains the corticospinal tract (limb/torso movements), corticobulbar tract (face/head/neck movements), and abducens nucleus (lateral eye movements).

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of facial weakness. Earlier that morning, he had trouble drinking water, as it was drooling from the side of his mouth. When he looked in the mirror, he noticed the right side of his face was drooping, and he could not move his mouth or eyebrow on that side. He has no past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an asymmetric smile, loss of the right nasolabial fold, and drooping of the right eyelid. The rest of the neurologic examination is noncontributory. Extensive workup, including Lyme serology and MRI of the brain, is unremarkable. A provisional diagnosis of cranial nerve paralysis secondary to a viral infection is made. In addition to facial weakness, which of the following findings is this patient most likely to demonstrate?

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of facial touch sensation
Loss of taste of the anterior third of the tongue
Inability to sweat on the right of the face
Ipsilateral loss of the pupillary light reflex

questions.solution:
This patient with paralysis of the upper (drooping of the eyelid, inability to move eyebrow) and lower (loss of nasolabial fold, drooping of the lips, asymmetric smile) right side of the face most likely has Bell palsy, a mononeuropathy affecting the facial nerve (CN VII).

The facial nerve is a mixed nerve, with the following functions:

  • Motor: Facial muscles involved in facial expressions, eye closure, and the stapedius (which contracts to dampen loud sounds) 
  • Somatic sensory: Afferents from the area of the pinna and external auditory canal 
  • Special sensory: Afferents for taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue 
  • Parasympathetic innervation of the submandibular, sublingual and lacrimal glands
The etiology of Bell palsy is most commonly idiopathic.  It can be caused by viral-associated ischemic demyelination (e.g., herpes simplex, Epstein-Barr) or sometimes as a complication of Lyme disease or sarcoidosis. It typically presents with sudden-onset unilateral facial paralysis causing impaired eye closure, eyebrow sagging, inability to smile, frown or purse lips on the affected side, and disappearance of the nasolabial fold. Other findings include decreased tear production, hyperacusis, and loss of taste sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.


Option Analysis

❌ Ipsilateral loss of facial touch sensation:
Incorrect: Facial touch sensation is innervated by the somatic afferents of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). The facial nerve (CN VII) is only responsible for afferents from the area of the pinna and external auditory canal.
❌ Contralateral uvula deviation:
Incorrect: Contralateral uvula deviation occurs when CN X is affected, resulting in palatal weakness of the affected side and uvula deviation towards the unaffected side.
✅ Loss of taste of the anterior third of the tongue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inability to sweat on the right of the face:
Incorrect: Sympathetic innervation to the face is primarily provided by postsynaptic sympathetic axons traveling in a perivascular plexus along the carotid arteries. Their interruption can be seen in patients with Horner syndrome, which classically presents with hemifacial ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, and enophthalmos.
❌ Ipsilateral loss of the pupillary light reflex:
Incorrect: Ipsilateral loss of the pupillary light reflex is seen in patients with CN III palsy, the cranial nerve involved in the efferent pathway of the reflex.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic to evaluate progressive hearing loss. Over the past six months, she mentions trouble hearing from her left ear which is more pronounced when she uses that side for a phone call. The patient also reports a ringing sensation in the ear that started around the same time. Past medical history is significant for melanoma on her back which was resected after imaging was negative for metastatic lesions. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Rinne test is normal. When a vibrating tuning fork is placed on the middle of the forehead, the patient hears the sound louder in the right ear. Imaging reveals an intracranial mass; histopathology of the sample is shown.  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons   

The cells show diffuse S-100 immunoreactivity. Which of the following is the most likely cell of origin of this lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient with an intracranial mass, tinnitus, and sensorineural hearing loss likely has involvement of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). The histopathology finding of highly cellular areas intermixed with myxoid regions of low cellularity, with S-100 positivity, confirms a vestibular schwannoma diagnosis.  

Vestibular schwannomas are the third most common primary brain tumor in adults. They arise from the Schwann cells of the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). These benign tumors often compress the nerves originating from the cerebellopontine angle, including CN V and VII. Symptoms can vary based on the pattern of nerve involvement and include:  

  •  Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, disequilibrium, and ataxia (CN VIII) 
  •  Loss of ipsilateral facial sensation with interruption of the corneal reflex (CN V) 
  •  Ipsilateral facial muscle paralysis (e.g., asymmetric smile, facial droop) (CN VII) 
On magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a well-circumscribed and encapsulated mass is usually seen near the cerebellopontine angle and the internal auditory meatus. Microscopically, vestibular schwannomas appear biphasic with areas of spindle cells that form a palisading pattern (Antoni A pattern) with a myxoid region of low cellularity (Antoni B pattern). Immunohistochemical staining for S-100 is usually positive and confirms the neural crest origin of the tumor.

Option Analysis

❌ Oligodendrocyte:
Incorrect: Oligodendroglioma is a rare, slow-growing tumor that originates from oligodendrocytes. It usually grows in the frontal lobe and is calcified on morphology. Histopathology reveals neoplastic cells with round nuclei and clear cytoplasm (“fried egg cells”) with chicken-wire-like capillary pattern in between.
✅ Schwann cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Astrocytes:
Incorrect: Low-grade astrocytoma and glioblastoma originate from astrocytes. The former most often occurs in the posterior fossa and appear as bipolar cells with hair-like projections on histopathology. Glioblastoma occurs in the cerebrum and appears as pleomorphic tumor cells with a central area of necrosis. They are glial-fibrillary acid protein (GFAP) positive.
❌ Meningothelial cells:
Incorrect: Meningiomas are slow-growing extra-axial tumors arising from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid mater. Histologically, they appear as whorls of cells with or without psammoma bodies (laminar calcification).
❌ Melanocyte:
Incorrect: Melanoma is an aggressive skin tumor that tends to metastasize to the brain. Being neural crest in origin, it is also S-100 positive. Metastatic lesions typically form well-circumscribed masses along the gray-white matter junction. However, histologically, there is often necrosis with areas of gliosis and edema.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for dysphagia and recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patient has hypertension and often forgets to take his blood pressure medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. Physical examination reveals an absent right-sided gag reflex. Loss of function of the nerve responsible for transmitting the afferent signal of this reflex is associated with which of the following additional neurological deficits?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled hypertension and recurrent aspiration pneumonia presents with an absent right-sided gag reflex. Afferent signals of the gag reflex are sent via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.  

A reflex arc typically consists of sensory receptors, the afferent sensory nerve that sends an impulse to the central nervous system, and an efferent motor nerve that transmits a motor response. The gag reflex is mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve. The gag reflex is triggered via contact with the posterior pharynx, tonsillar area, or tongue base. Afferent nerve impulses (sensory limb) are sent through the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), which also aids in swallowing by supplying the stylopharyngeus muscle and carries taste from the posterior third of the tongue. Efferent nerve impulses (motor limb) are then sent through the pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve (X), which also innervates muscles of the pharynx and larynx and helps regulate blood pressure.  



The gag reflex is assessed when there is reason to suspect reduced palatal strength or sensation (e.g. clinical symptoms of stroke). It is evaluated by observing the patient’s response when the posterior pharynx is touched with a cotton swab. The reflex elicited on one side can be compared with that of the contralateral side to assess for asymmetry.  

A normal gag reflex involves brisk, symmetrical elevation of the soft palate and contraction of pharyngeal muscles. If both cranial nerves IX and X are damaged, stimulation of the affected side would fail to elicit a reflex. Loss of the gag reflex makes patients susceptible to aspiration and pneumonia.  

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Loss of taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue:
Incorrect: Taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is transmitted via the facial nerve, while somatosensation is transmitted via the trigeminal nerve. In contrast, the glossopharyngeal nerve, which carries the afferent signals of the gag reflex and is likely damaged here, is responsible for taste and somatosensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue.     
❌ Vocal cord paralysis:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve is responsible for the motor supply of the vocal cords. It carries the efferent signal of the gag reflex. The glossopharyngeal nerve carries the afferent signal of the gag reflex, in addition to sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Tongue paralysis:
Incorrect: Most of the tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. The exception is the palatoglossal muscle provided by the vagus nerve. However, this patient has an absent gag reflex, and the afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.
❌ Loss of the cough reflex:
Incorrect: The vagus nerve mediates both the afferent and efferent signals of the cough reflex. In contrast, this patient has an absent gag reflex. The afferent signals of the gag reflex are transmitted via the glossopharyngeal nerve, which is also responsible for sensation in the posterior one-third of the tongue.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his partner after being found unresponsive one hour ago. The patient fell down a flight of stairs the previous evening, but he appeared fine immediately afterwards, and he went to bed at his usual time. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. On arrival, the patient is unresponsive. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 200/102 mm Hg. On examination, the right pupil is 5 mm and fixed. The left pupil is 4 mm and reactive to light. There is an extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination demonstrates a systolic click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is started. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows a right-sided 6-cm subdural hematoma with an 18-mm midline shift and associated cerebral edema. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Right eye esotropia and upward deviation

questions.solution:
This patient has a large right-sided subdural hematoma, resulting in elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral edema, presenting as midline shift and transtentorial herniation of the uncus.

With this type of herniation, the uncus (the innermost portion of the temporal lobe) slips down towards the tentorium and compresses parts of the brain stem. The following neurologic deficits are commonly observed with transtentorial herniation of the uncus:

  •  CN III nerve palsy, where the eye is fixed in a “down and out” position with a dilated and unresponsive pupil. 
  •  Posterior cerebral artery compression leads to contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.  
  •  Paramedian basilar artery injury results in small linear or flame-shaped hemorrhages called Duret hemorrhages. 
  •  Contralateral hemiparesis is secondary to compression of the ipsilateral cerebral peduncle of the midbrain, damaging corticospinal fibers. 
  •  Contralateral peduncle compression against the tentorium results in ipsilateral hemiparesis, known as a false localizing sign, the so-called Kernohan's notch. 

Option Analysis

❌ Right eye esotropia and upward deviation  :
Incorrect: Right eye esotropia and elevation would be caused by concomitant CN IV and VI palsies, leading to unopposed CN III activity. When CN III is unopposed, the associated extraocular muscles produce adduction and elevation or depression of the eye. Instead, uncal herniation causes CN III palsy, resulting in pupillary dilation and absent light reflex (as seen in this patient), abduction, and slight depression of the eye (“down and out” gaze).  
❌ Multifocal myoclonus  :
Incorrect: Multifocal myoclonus is associated with various neurologic disorders, including seizures. It is more frequently observed in severe cerebral hypoxia, progressive myoclonic epilepsy, neurodegenerative diseases (e.g. Alzheimer disease), or metabolic coma (e.g. secondary to glycemic disturbances). However, it is not a common symptom of uncal herniation.  
❌ Left-side vagus nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vagus nerve (CN X) exits the brainstem via the medulla, which lies at a position too inferior to be affected by uncal herniation. CN X can be injured via direct trauma to the neck and can also occur due to compression from an aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Bilateral vestibulocochlear nerve palsy  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) exits the brainstem at the pons, situated too low to be affected by uncal herniation, which is seen on this patient's CT scan. CN VIII can be injured by hemorrhage or aneurysms of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.  
✅ Right-sided hemiplegia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his parent for evaluation of "abnormal behavior.” The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been eating uncontrollably. The patient has also demonstrated inappropriate sexual behavior towards family members. Also of concern to the patient’s parent is that the patient seemed indifferent to the news that the patient’s other parent had passed away a few weeks ago. The patient’s parent denies any recent head trauma sustained by the patient but does state that the patient was hospitalized two months ago for a “brain infection.” A follow-up MRI is ordered. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely to demonstrate abnormal findings?

choices.text: Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
Kluver-Bucy syndrome is a neurobehavioral syndrome that results from bilateral damage to the amygdala. It is characterized by three types of disinhibited behavior: increased sexual drive (hypersexuality), uncontrollable desire to eat (hyperphagia), and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Lack of emotional responsiveness, recurrent unprovoked seizures, and visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects) are other symptoms that are also seen in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.  

The most common etiology of Kluver-Bucy syndrome is viral encephalitis typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, which can damage the temporal lobes and the amygdala. The amygdaloid nuclei are located within the temporal lobes and supplied by the anterior choroidal arteries. They comprise a portion of the the limbic system, which is responsible for sexual drive as well as emotional and behavioral responses. Other causes of Kluver-Bucy syndrome include temporal lobe surgery and head trauma that results in temporal lobe contusions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome typically results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus could present with left-sided hemiballismus. Hemiballismus is an involuntary, large amplitude, unilateral movement of the limbs and most commonly results from a lacunar infarct sustained to the subthalamic nuclei.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus includes the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior right parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock), and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
✅ Bilateral amygdala:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of dysarthria and dysphagia. The patient’s symptoms started three months ago. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension, both poorly controlled. Current medications include metformin, glyburide, losartan, and atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 162/89 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Examination of the head and neck reveals atrophy and fasciculations of the tongue. Rightward deviation of the tongue is noted when the patient is asked to protrude the tongue. He has no sensory or motor abnormalities in other parts of the face or the body. Further evaluation of this patient’s clinical history will most likely reveal the following?

choices.text: History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery
Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes
Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection
Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation

questions.solution:
The hypoglossal nerve emerges from the anterior surface of the medulla oblongata and leaves the skull through the hypoglossal canal. It descends through the neck close to the internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. The hypoglossal nerve supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue, except the palatoglossal muscle, which is supplied by the vagus nerve.    

Hypoglossal nerve injury can occur anywhere along the nerve’s course. Etiologies include tumor, cerebrovascular injury, demyelinating diseases, injury following cervical spine surgery, and traumatic injury. In addition, the hypoglossal nerve can be injured during operations involving the upper part of the anterior neck. It is especially susceptible to injury during carotid endarterectomy.   

Features of hypoglossal nerve injury include tongue atrophy and fasciculations and ipsilateral paralysis of one-half of the tongue. Moreover, when the patient is asked to stick out their tongue, the tongue will deviate towards the side of nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Right carotid artery endarterectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of stroke involving the right medullary branch of the vertebral artery :
Incorrect: A stroke involving the medullary branch of the vertebral artery will result in medial medullary syndrome. The condition is associated with hypoglossal nerve palsy, contralateral weakness of the body, and contralateral sensory loss. In contrast, this patient has isolated hypoglossal nerve palsy, which would more likely arise as a complication of carotid surgery.
❌ Lymph node biopsy from the posterior cervical lymph nodes:
Incorrect: The spinal accessory nerve can be injured during a lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical region. Spinal accessory nerve injury can present with shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. However, it would not present with dysarthria, dysphagia, or tongue deviation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior and inferior thyroid arteries dissection :
Incorrect: The superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during dissection of the superior thyroid artery, and the recurrent laryngeal nerve can be damaged during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. However, this patient’s symptoms are more suggestive of hypoglossal nerve injury.
❌ Mitral stenosis associated with left atrial dilation :
Incorrect: Left atrial dilation can cause compression of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve and associated hoarseness of the voice. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms suggest hypoglossal nerve injury.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a gunshot wound to the back. The patient was the victim of a robbery and was shot while attempting to flee the scene. Temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 19/min, blood pressure is 166/84 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the patient's secondary survey is notable for a single gunshot wound at the T10 spinal level without an exit wound. An emergent MRI demonstrates complete transection of the spinal cord at the level of T10.  Which of the following neurologic deficits are most likely to be expected based on this patient's spinal cord injury?

choices.text: Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities
Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation after sustaining a gunshot wound that results in a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T10. At this level, neurologic deficits to be expected would be a total loss of sensation at the level of the umbilicus and loss of motor function of the bilateral lower extremities.   

The spinal cord is divided into several different cross-sectional anatomic tracts and levels based on the corresponding vertebrae; an injury at any one of these levels or within the anatomic tract results in distinct neurologic deficits. During a spinal cord transection, the patient loses all sensation and voluntary movement inferior to the lesion site. For example, if a transaction occurs between C4 and C5, the patient will lose all motor and sensory functions below this level, rendering them quadriplegic.  If transection happens between C6 and C8, there’s a complete loss of lower limb function combined with a loss of hand and a variable amount of upper limb function.  

Damage to specific tracts can also occur via partial spinal cord transection. For example, Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that arises following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to damage to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tracts. Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure).  



Option Analysis

✅ Complete loss of sensation at the umbilicus and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the xiphoid and loss of strength of the bilateral lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of T7, not T10.  
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the clavicular line and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
