Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C5. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the bilateral upper and lower extremities  :
Incorrect: This answer describes the neurologic deficits observed given a complete spinal cord transection at the level of C3. 
❌ Complete loss of sensation at the neckline and loss of strength of the upper extremities only  :
Incorrect: This choice is not a physically realistic possibility. Complete loss of sensation at the neckline without the involvement of lower extremity weakness would not occur.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to debilitating headaches for the past two months. She recently started college, and has been under a lot of stress due to the amount of work. Her medical history is significant for generalized anxiety disorder. She rates the pain as a 5 on a 10-point scale, and describes it as “tightness around her head”. Physical examination shows tenderness over the trapezius muscles bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to benefit this patient in the long term?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a tension headache based on her moderate-intensity headache and shoulder muscle tenderness without other symptoms, in association with recent stress and general anxiety disorder.  

The typical presentation of a tension headache includes a bilateral, mild to moderate intensity, non-throbbing headache without other associated features. The pain is often described as “pressure-like” or “band-like,” and patients often have pericranial muscle tenderness. The pathophysiology is uncertain, but proposed mechanisms include peripheral activation or sensitization of myofascial nociceptors. Common precipitating factors are stress and muscle tension. Acute abortive treatment includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and acetaminophen, with prophylactic treatment options including behavioral therapy and tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) (e.g. amitriptyline).    

Behavioral therapy for tension headaches includes any of the following:   
  •  Regulation of sleep, exercise, and meals 
  •  Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) 
  •  Relaxation 
  •  Biofeedback 
CBT is aimed to modify maladaptive responses to stressful experiences by altering associated thoughts and assumptions. Identifying headache triggers (e.g., physical, psychological, or behavioral) and developing effective coping strategies are cardinal aspects of therapy. TCAs and CBT may be used together as prophylactic treatment.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Non-steroidal anti-inflammatories:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are used as an acute abortive treatment for tension headaches, but they are not indicated for prophylaxis. NSAIDs work through the inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and/or COX-2), which are involved in the synthesis of biological inflammatory mediators (prostaglandins), thus reducing inflammation.   
✅ Cognitive behavioral therapy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is used as a prophylactic treatment for cluster headaches, but it is not indicated as prophylactic treatment for tension headaches. Verapamil works by blocking voltage-dependent calcium channels found at the sinoatrial and atrioventricular nodes and smooth-muscle lining blood vessels. Blocking these channels leads to vasodilation and reduction of the heart rate.   
❌ Botulinum toxin injections:
Incorrect: Botulinum toxin injections are used as part of the prophylactic regimen for migraine headaches, and they are not indicated for tension headaches. Botulinum toxin works by cleaving SNARE protein, which mediates acetylcholine vesicle fusion and release from the presynaptic vesicle. This stops nerve signaling, leading to paralysis.  
❌ Dihydroergotamine:
Incorrect: Dihydroergotamine can be used as an abortive treatment for migraine headaches. It works through multiple mechanisms including activation of 5-HT1D receptors located on intracranial blood vessels causing vasoconstriction, and/or activation of 5-HT1D receptors on sensory nerve endings of the trigeminal system leading to the inhibition of pro-inflammatory mediator release.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male college student is brought to the emergency department accompanied by his roommate due to fever, headache, and altered mental status. The roommate says that the patient was healthy until 2 days ago, when he started having persistent fevers and progressively worsening headaches. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and nuchal rigidity is noted. Examination of the skin shows no signs of rash or lesions. Neurological examination is limited due to altered mental status. Lumbar puncture is performed and reveals low glucose, elevated protein, and leukocytosis with polymorphonuclear predominance. Gram staining shows gram-negative bacteria. Which of the following should be administered to close contacts of this patient?
questions.solution:
This previously healthy college student is presenting with a severe headache and high-grade fever. In addition, he has altered mental status and positive meningeal signs, which are all consistent with meningitis. Based on his risk factors (living in a dormitory), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, and gram stain, the most likely causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis. It is important to note that characteristic petechial rash is present only in 50% of the cases, and its absence does not rule out the diagnosis.  

Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is gram-negative diplococci that is capable of a variety of clinical manifestations ranging from transient fever and bacteremia to fulminant fatal disease within hours. It is the second most common cause of meningitis in adults below the age of 60 years (with S. pneumoniae being the most common). Infections typically occur in the settings of weakened immunity or crowded places with infected patients; crowded areas like military bases or college dorms allow the bacteria to spread quickly via respiratory droplets and oral secretions. Due to these features and the mortality risk, close contact requires immediate prophylaxis to prevent the spread of the infection. Close contact refers to individuals who:  

  •  spent prolonged time with an infected person (>8 hours) while in close proximity (< 3 feet) 
  •  individuals who have been directly exposed to the patient’s oral secretions 7 days prior and up until 24 hours after antibiotics treatment initiation 
Prophylactic antibiotics regimen include rifampin, ceftriaxone, and ciprofloxacin (avoided in pregnant patients and in those <18 years of age). 

Option Analysis

❌ Metronidazole :
Incorrect: Metronidazole is a bactericidal antibiotic that works by forming toxic free radicals that damage the bacterial DNA. It is also used to treat some protozoal and anaerobic infections. Although metronidazole covers gram-negative bacteria, it is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis. 
❌ Vancomycin :
Incorrect: Vancomycin is an antibiotic that works by inhibiting cell wall peptidoglycan formation. It is effective against gram-positive infections only. This patient's CSF was positive for gram-negative bacteria. 
❌ Imipenem :
Incorrect: Imipenem is a broad-spectrum, β-lactamase-resistant carbapenem used for the treatment of gram-positive cocci or gram-negative rods, as well as anaerobes. It is usually reserved for life-threatening infections or after other drugs have failed. It is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis. 
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rifabutin:
Incorrect: Rifabutin is an anti-tuberculosis medication that works by inhibiting DNA-dependent RNA polymerase. It is not indicated for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis. In contrast, rifampin, another type of anti-tuberculosis medication, can be used for meningococcal meningitis prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his partner due to an inability to focus. For the past 2 months, the patient has been unable to complete his daily sudoku puzzle. His partner recalls that the patient has been increasingly withdrawn and no longer attends social gatherings. The patient has also been sleeping more due to worsening fatigue and has experienced a 5 kg (11 lb) weight gain over this same time period. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, which is well-controlled with medications, and constipation for the past 8 weeks, which he has been self-treating with fiber supplements. In the office, temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 48/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 125/84 mmHg. Physical examination reveals cold, dry skin. The abdomen is mildly distended with hypoactive bowel sounds. Fecal occult blood test is negative. Sensation in the extremities is intact. Which of the following tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This elderly male is presenting with fatigue, depression, constipation, weight gain, and systemic signs (bradycardia, low body temperature). These symptoms are concerning for hypothyroidism, which is a reversible cause of dementia. Some common causes of reversible dementia include:

  •  B12 deficiency, which can be evaluated by measuring serum vitamin B12 levels. This condition should be considered in patients presenting with signs of anemia and peripheral neuropathy. 
  •  Hypothyroidism, which can be evaluated by measuring serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). 
  •  Tertiary syphilis (neurosyphilis), which can be worked-up via screening tests, such as the rapid plasma reagin test. However, these tests should only be performed if there is a high clinical suspicion based on symptoms and social history. 
  •  Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which is caused by impaired CSF absorption. It classically presents with the triad of urinary incontinence, dementia, and ataxic gait. The diagnosis is confirmed when a lumbar puncture and CSF removal leads to symptom improvement. 
  • Major depressive disorder is also termed pseudodementia. A key finding in individuals with pseudodementia is that they often show poor effort on neurocognitive tests. In contrast, patients with dementia will try hard but are nonetheless unable to answer questions correctly.
Of note, prior to diagnosing a patient with an irreversible cause of dementia (e.g., Alzheimer disease, Parkinson disease), it is crucial to first rule out these reversible causes.

Option Analysis

✅ Serum TSH levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Serum B12 levels:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency should be suspected in patients presenting with signs of anemia (e.g., fatigue, pallor) and neurological disturbances, such as peripheral neuropathy, gait abnormalities, and neuropsychiatric diseases (e.g., depression, dementia). However, vitamin B12 deficiency would not explain this patient’s weight gain, constipation, and skin changes.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) can present with fatigue and lethargy, such as in this patient. Elderly individuals presenting with signs of IDA should undergo colonoscopy for evaluation of underlying colorectal cancer. However, IDA typically presents with compensatory cardiac signs, such as tachycardia (not bradycardia). Furthermore, this patient’s fecal occult blood test is negative.
❌ Screening for depression:
Incorrect: Cognitive impairment secondary to underlying depression is termed pseudodementia. Pseudodementia is an important reversible cause of cognitive impairment. Although this patient is presenting with signs of depression (e.g., lethargy, lack of focus, social withdrawal), his other systemic signs and symptoms (e.g., bradycardia, skin changes, constipation, decreased body temperature) are suggestive of a different etiology.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar punctures are useful when samples of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) need to be collected for testing, such as a suspicion for neurosyphilis. This patient lacks the classic clinical course associated with syphilis infections (e.g., genital lesion, maculopapular rash, history of multiple sexual partners). Lumbar punctures are also the confirmatory test for patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH); however, this patient lacks the urinary incontinence and wide-based gait associated with NPH.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a 30-minute episode of left hand weakness. During the episode, he was unable to pick up any object at home. He denies any difficulty in ambulation or speaking during the episode. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension and a 25-pack-year smoking history. He drinks 1-2 beers on the weekend. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/88 mmHg. BMI is 21 kg/m2. He is alert and oriented, and his speech is fluent and clear. Motor strength is normal in all extremities, and there are no focal deficits. Noncontrast head CT shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiogram demonstrates normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for long-term risk mitigation given this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with resolved neurological deficits, and likely suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Up to 80% of strokes following a TIA are preventable; therefore, early diagnosis and treatment are critical for risk mitigation.

A TIA is managed via calculation of the risk of suffering a subsequent stroke by taking into account the patient’s age, blood pressure, clinical findings, duration of the TIA, and presence of associated risk factors. If the individual is deemed high risk, further hospitalization for advanced testing is appropriate. In addition, risk factor modification is appropriate for all patients with TIA, including blood pressure reduction, statins, antiplatelet therapy, lifestyle modification, and smoking cessation.

Regardless of risk factors, all patients with ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack should be prescribed antiplatelet therapy, preferably aspirin. If the patient was previously on daily aspirin therapy, the addition of clopidogrel is the most appropriate next step in management. Additionally, initiation of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) lowering therapy with a statin, independent of the baseline LDL-C, is appropriate as well.    

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of alteplase:
Incorrect: Alteplase is first-line therapy for an ischemic stroke with persistent neurologic deficits, provided that treatment is initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset and the patient does not meet any strict exclusion criteria (e.g., history of gastrointestinal bleeding, history of head trauma). This patient no longer has any neurologic deficits (he likely suffered from a TIA), making him ineligible for alteplase treatment.
✅ Initiation of aspirin and atorvastatin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of warfarin:
Incorrect: Long-term anticoagulation with warfarin may be beneficial for stroke prevention in patients with atrial fibrillation. This patient’s ECG is normal.
❌ Reduction of alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: Excessive alcohol consumption can increase the risk of various morbidities; however, this patient consumes a minimal amount of alcohol.
❌ Weight loss:
Incorrect: Weight loss is one of the most effective methods in lowering blood pressure and therefore in reducing the risk of a future stroke; however, this patient has a healthy BMI.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of left-sided numbness and unsteady gait. The patient was having dinner with family one hour ago when she suddenly developed numbness in the left side of her body and could no longer sense the temperature of her food. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes metformin, glipizide, amlodipine, losartan, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates deficits in touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature on the left side of the body and face. Motor strength and speech are normal. Romberg sign is positive. An ischemic stroke involving which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of her clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden-onset, unilateral sensory deficits (touch, two-point discrimination, pain, and temperature) without cortical signs or motor deficits. A positive Romberg test suggests an additional deficit in proprioception. This presentation is suggestive of a pure sensory stroke involving the thalamic nuclei.  

The thalamus is a component of the diencephalon that lies on either side of the third ventricle and serves as the site of integration of somatosensory information. The thalamic nuclei include the ventral posteromedial nucleus (VPM) and the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL). The former receives afferent neuronal fibers from the trigeminal lemniscus and the gustatory pathway, while the latter receives afferent information from the dorsal column pathway (medial and lateral lemniscus) and from the lateral spinothalamic tract. These pathways carry sensory information regarding vibration, proprioception, pressure, pain, taste, light touch, and temperature. Efferent neuronal fibers from these nuclei terminate in the primary somatosensory cortex.  

Clinical manifestations of an ischemic thalamic stroke include loss of touch, pain, temperature, vibration, proprioception, and tactile discrimination over the contralateral half of the body (including sensory loss over the contralateral side of the face without motor deficits or cortical signs). Thalamic lesions are frequently the result of a lacunar stroke (small vessel microatheroma or lipohyalinosis). Risk factors for these lesions include hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia (all of which are present in this patient).  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypothalamus:
Incorrect: The hypothalamus is the site of regulation of temperature, hunger, satiety, endocrine functions, circadian rhythm, emotion, behavior, and sexual drive. It is not involved in relaying somatosensory information.
✅ Thalamus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Internal capsule is a subcortical white matter structure that relays sensory-motor information from the brainstem and contralateral body to the brain. Strokes involving the posterior limb of the internal capsule present with pure motor or mixed sensory-motor deficits, as opposed to pure sensory deficits. 
❌ Brainstem:
Incorrect: Stroke syndromes involving the brainstem are accompanied by signs and symptoms of autonomic, corticospinal (motor), and/or cranial nerve(s) involvement. Pure sensory deficits are not usually seen.
❌ Cerebral cortex:
Incorrect: Cortical strokes involving the somatosensory areas of the brain can be differentiated from thalamic strokes by the presence of cortical symptoms, which include aphasia, neglect, and behavioral changes.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to his primary care physician to evaluate low back pain. The patient was helping his sibling lift furniture yesterday when he experienced acute onset low back pain, requiring him to lay in bed the remainder of the day. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine on physical examination. Strength is 5/5 with foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion in the right lower extremity, while 4/5 in the left lower extremity. Sensation is also diminished on the lateral aspect of the left lower extremity compared to that of the right side. Which of the following is the most likely affected nerve root responsible for this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with low back pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion is most likely suffering from L5 radiculopathy.  

Lumbar and cervical disc herniations are common musculoskeletal back pathologies that result from herniation of the nucleus pulposus and compression of the nerve root. In general, symptoms include focal back pain with associated radiation of pain, weakness, and sensory disturbance in the anatomic distribution of the compromised nerve root. Overall, the most common site of lumbar disc herniation is the L4-L5 vertebral level, which produces symptoms of pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated weakness in foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion.  



In the cervical spine, the most common site of disc herniation is the C6-C7 vertebral level, which compresses the C7 nerve root. Herniation at this site presents with pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, along with weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion. 

Option Analysis

❌ C7:
Incorrect: A disc herniation at C6-C7 would result in C7 nerve root compression, causing pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, as well as weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: Thoracic disc herniation is overall uncommon compared to lumbar or cervical disc herniation. A lesion at this site would result in pain that radiates towards the umbilicus.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction.  
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ S1:
Incorrect: S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a reduced ankle jerk reflex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of difficulty walking and recurrent falls. The patient states, “I’m not sure what’s wrong with me. I just can’t seem to keep my balance. I just feel like I’m in a fog all day.” The patient also has numbness and tingling in the tips of her fingers and toes. Her past medical history includes hypothyroidism, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. The patient currently takes levothyroxine, amlodipine, and metformin. She works as a school teacher and drinks 3-4 glasses of wine per day. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates an ataxic gait and 3+ reflexes in the upper and lower extremities. The patient has diminished two-point discrimination in the upper extremities with preservation of pinprick sensation. This patient's clinical presentation reflects damage to which of the following anatomic sites?

choices.text: Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns
Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple risk factors for developing vitamin B12 deficiency (cobalamin), including chronic alcohol use and metformin use. Additionally, the physical examination demonstrates dysfunction of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, consistent with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.    

Several spinal cord pathologies can be identified via a careful neurological examination to reveal the affected spinal cord tract(s). For example, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord results when vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is absent or deficient. It may become deficient due to malabsorptive disease (e.g., Crohn disease, pernicious anemia), dietary restriction (e.g. veganism), or medications that interfere with cobalamin absorption (e.g., metformin, proton pump inhibitors). When physiologic stores of vitamin B12 are low, levels of methylmalonic acid increase, which causes degeneration of the myelin sheath of the spinocerebellar, lateral corticospinal, and dorsal column pathways, resulting in subacute combined degeneration (SCD). SCD manifests with symptoms of gait ataxia, paresthesias, and impaired position/vibration sense. Furthermore, SCD can cause psychiatric symptoms, including worsening depression or signs of dementia.    

Additional noteworthy patterns of spinal cord pathologies include Brown-Sequard syndrome, syringomyelia, and tabes dorsalis. Brown-Sequard syndrome is a rare asymmetrical spinal cord injury pattern that occurs following a stab wound, penetrating injury, or, less commonly, fracture or blunt trauma. It results in ipsilateral loss of motor function, vibration, and proprioception due to the dorsal columns and corticospinal tract damage. In addition, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation occurs at one or two levels below the lesion due to injury of the spinothalamic tracts (which decussate at the anterior commissure). Brown-Sequard syndrome may also be associated with Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) if the lesion occurs above the T1 level and causes damage to the oculosympathetic pathway.    

Syringomyelia describes a cystic cavity within the spinal cord, usually within the central canal, that can expand over time and compress the anterior white commissure, a structure directly anterior to the cervical canal. The anterior white commissure is the decussation site for the spinothalamic tracts, relaying pain and temperature sensation. As a result, syringomyelia causes a "cape-like," bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities. Syringomyelia is associated with Chiari I malformation, a congenital condition characterized by abnormally shaped cerebellar tonsils that herniate below the level of the foramen magnum.  

Lastly, tabes dorsalis arises due to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by Treponema pallidum, the spirochete that causes syphilis. Tertiary infection of the spinal cord leads to demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal column and roots, resulting in findings of gait ataxia and incoordination. The condition takes nearly 20 years to develop after the initial infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinocerebellar tracts, lateral corticospinal tracts, and dorsal columns  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior white commissure  :
Incorrect: Chiari I malformation is characterized by cerebellar tonsillar ectopia and is most commonly associated with a syrinx within the spinal cord. Most cases are asymptomatic. In symptomatic patients, the condition can result in a bilateral, symmetrical loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper extremities due to impingement on the anterior white commissure.  
❌ Dorsal columns and roots  :
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis is a manifestation of tertiary neurosyphilis and is characterized by degenerative changes of the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Tabes dorsalis would not typically present with signs of spastic paralysis. 
❌ Lumbar spinal roots  :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome results from compression of spinal roots at the L2 level or below. It is usually due to a mass effect or a fracture. Cauda equina syndrome tends to present with radicular pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia.  
❌ Anterior, lateral corticospinal tracts, and anterior white commissure :
Incorrect: Central cord syndrome commonly occurs due to forced hyperextension injury or syringomyelia. The condition results in sensory and motor deficits, with the upper extremities affected more than the lower extremities.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to his primary care physician to evaluate recurrent tripping and falling over the past two months. The patient states that he loses his balance easily and finds it difficult to walk in narrow spaces, such as the school hallway. He reports difficulty sleeping for the same duration. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. Physical examination demonstrates bilateral papilledema, impaired upward gaze, and bilateral eyelid retraction. A brain mass is suspected, and an MRI brain is ordered.  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org  
Which of the following structures is most likely affected by this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ataxia, insomnia, downward gaze, and nystagmus consistent with Parinaud syndrome. This condition is classically associated with a tumor of the pineal gland.

Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome refers to a cluster of eye movement abnormalities characterized by limitation of upward gaze and downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and light-near dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). This combination of abnormalities manifests with a conjugate downward gaze, referred to as the "setting-sun" sign. These eye movement deficits are secondary to compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain, which in young patients often occurs due to tumors of the pineal gland.  

Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: Suprasellar germinomas are a less common cause of germinoma than pinealomas. They are more likely to present with endocrinopathies due to their proximity to the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. Moreover, suprasellar germinomas do not result in Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ B:
Incorrect: Damage to the thalamus by hemorrhage or an intracranial mass would present with contralateral hemisensory loss, behavioral changes, and language deficits.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ D:
Incorrect: Pontine tumors or hemorrhage can result in ‘locked in’ syndrome, which presents with spastic quadriplegia and paralysis of most cranial nerves with preserved consciousness and eye movement.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: Cerebellar lesions usually present with limb and truncal ataxia, intention tremor, and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician with diplopia. The patient tells the physician that he has fallen multiple times because of having double vision. The problem started eight months ago, and it has not improved. Past medical history of the patient includes hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and coronary artery disease. On physical examination, the left eye is pointing downwards and outwards. Both pupils are 4 mm in diameter, and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery
Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery
Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe

questions.solution:
This patient with diplopia and a “down and out” right eye most likely has damage to the somatic component of the oculomotor nerve (CN III). Ischemia, secondary to diabetes and hypertensive vasculopathy, is the most common cause.

CN III has parasympathetic and somatic components. The former is present in the outer region of the nerve, while the latter is found in the center of the nerve. A helpful way to remember this distinction is the alliteration that the Parasympathetic fibers are Peripheral. Clinical findings of CN III palsy depend on the components that are affected by the pathology. Loss of parasympathetic function leads to mydriasis and inability to accommodate to near objects, while loss of the somatic function causes ptosis and deviation of the eye down and out (due to unopposed action of superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles, innervated by CN IV and VI, respectively).

Isolated CN III palsy is most commonly due to ischemia or compression. Ischemia is mostly caused by hypertension or diabetes mellitus and preferentially affects somatic fibers. Compression of CN III (e.g., by posterior communicating artery aneurysm, tentorial herniation) can lead to parasympathetic loss of function. However, it is not uncommon to see involvement of both the components.



Option Analysis

✅ Ischemic injury of the oculomotor nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Posterior communicating artery aneurysms are one of the most common causes of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior cerebral artery is another cause of CN III injury. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Compression of the oculomotor nerve by an aneurysm in the superior cerebellar artery is also a cause of compression injury of CN III. However, compression injury to CN III always affects the parasympathetic fibers because they run in the outer layer of the nerve; thus the affected patient will have dilated pupils that are nonreactive to light.
❌ Compression of CN III by the uncus of the temporal lobe:
Incorrect: Uncal herniation through the tentorium cerebelli can compress CN III. However, this is an emergency, and patients will present with other neurological manifestations (e.g., coma, spastic paresis). Moreover, compression injuries to CN III affect the parasympathetic fibers, leading to dilated, nonreactive pupils.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate acute-on-chronic low back pain. Several years ago, the patient was diagnosed with prostate cancer, but he elected to forego treatment and was lost to follow-up. Today, the patient was brought in by family members after he could not get out of bed. The patient states, “I can’t lift my legs, and I woke up covered in my stool.” The patient has no other significant medical history or medication use. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows a cachectic male in moderate distress. The patient has diffuse lumbar spinal tenderness to palpation and 2/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. The patient’s pelvic x-ray is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features most indicates this patient’s clinical condition?


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of prostate cancer presents for evaluation of acute-on-chronic low back pain with associated bowel dysfunction, motor deficits in the lower extremities, and a pelvic x-ray demonstrating numerous osteoblastic lesions consistent with metastatic disease. This clinical presentation is suspicious for cauda equina syndrome, and urinary retention is a particularly specific finding for this condition.    
Cauda equina syndrome refers to a spinal cord injury caudal to the conus that injures two or more nerve roots, often via direct compression of the cauda equina within the lumbar spinal canal. The disease has multiple etiologies, including ankylosing spondylitis, chemotherapy, disc herniation, osteomyelitis, spinal epidural abscess, neoplasm, hematoma, arteriovenous malformations, inferior vena cava thrombosis, or trauma.  

The most common presenting complaint is acute-on-chronic low back pain; however, the associated features vary. In general, most patients have a combination of back pain, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and symptoms of radiculopathy. Additional findings include lower extremity weakness and diminished sensation in the distribution of multiple nerve roots (L3-S1), peri-anal numbness, and loss of anal sphincter tone. This disorder, while rare, carries significant morbidity, often resulting in permanent neurologic dysfunction if left untreated. When suspected, management includes emergent MRI of the lumbar spine and neurosurgical consultation.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary retention :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decreased deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: The absence of deep tendon reflexes is often found in patients with cauda equina syndrome; however, it is not a specific feature of this condition as it may be found in simple, unilateral radiculopathy as well.  
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Hyporeflexia, not hyperreflexia, is more commonly found in patients with cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Preserved perineal sensation :
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome usually exhibits sensory loss in the perineal area (saddle anesthesia).  
❌ Increased anal sphincter tone :
Incorrect: Decreased, not increased, anal sphincter tone is observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe facial pain. He describes the pain as severe, sharp pain around his right eye and temple. The pain came on slowly two hours ago, and it has been getting worse. He also complains that his right ear feels "full of cotton," and his nose is running. Similar episodes have happened to him over the last few years, often occurring multiple days in a row around the same month. Which of the following would be the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Cluster headaches are a type of primary headache characterized by unilateral pain around the periorbital region, and they are often described to be excruciating in quality. They often occur episodically at the same time of the day (and may occur multiple times per day), with cluster headache cycles usually occurring around the same time of the year. Autonomic symptoms are often associated with cluster headaches ipsilateral to the side of the pain, and only occur during the headache episode. These symptoms include conjunctival injection, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, and nasal congestion. Cluster headaches may also present with ipsilateral Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis).  

The first line treatment for cluster headaches is always 100% oxygen because of its efficacy with lack of side effects. If oxygen fails to reduce symptoms, triptans are the next line of therapy. Triptans are serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) agonists, and may cause adverse effects including coronary artery vasospasm, mild paresthesias, and serotonin syndrome (in combination with other 5-HT agonists). For patients with chronic cluster headaches, verapamil may be used as headache prophylaxis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Carbamazepine :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is a neuroleptic medication used to treat seizures, neuropathic pain, and bipolar disorder. It is the first line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, which typically presents with episodic, unilateral, shooting, and “shock like” pain in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Symptoms are often precipitated by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth, shaving, chewing) within the affected trigeminal nerve branch distribution. Carbamazepine has no role in the treatment of cluster headache.   
❌ Ketorolac:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory medications, like ketorolac, have a role in the treatment of migraine headaches, but they are not routinely used in the treatment of cluster headaches.  
✅ High-flow nasal cannula:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant that is often used in treating peripheral neuropathy, chronic pain, resistant depression as well as migraine or tension headache prophylaxis. However, it is not used for migraines during the acute phase, and it is not indicated for cluster headaches.   
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil has been shown to be effective for prophylaxis, significantly reducing the attack frequency. It is typically used in patients who have chronic cluster headaches.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 0, para 0, comes to the office for prenatal counseling, as she is planning to start a family. Past medical history is significant for epilepsy, for which she takes valproate. The patient has had 3 lifetime episodes of generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and the last episode was 9 months ago, after which valproate was started. However, the patient is now thinking of discontinuing the drug to avoid any harmful effects on the baby. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to high dose folic acid supplementation, which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Taper off valproate and switch to carbamazepine
Discontinue valproate and switch to phenytoin
Taper off valproate and switch to levetiracetam
Add magnesium sulfate in the current regimen

questions.solution:
Epilepsy poses an increased risk for a number of perinatal complications as compared to the general population. These include preeclampsia, placental abruption, stillbirth, and increased maternal mortality. Therefore, the use of anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) to keep the patient seizure-free during pregnancy is important. However, several AEDs are associated with teratogenic effects. These AEDs include valproate, carbamazepine, phenytoin and barbiturates. The neural tube defects seen in affected fetuses are largely due to impaired absorption of folic acid.  

For women who remain seizure-free for two or more years, gradually tapering off AEDs can be considered at least 6 months prior to becoming pregnant, as the risk of seizure recurrence is highest during this period. This patient is on a stable dose of valproate and has been seizure-free for 9 months. She should be switched to either lamotrigine or levetiracetam, since these two have the lowest teratogenic risk during pregnancy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue valproate:
Incorrect: Valproate is a category D teratogen and should be avoided in pregnancy, with the rare exception that it may be used when other antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) fail. Valproate can cause neural tube defects, oral clefts and multiple organ malformations due to impaired absorption of folic acid.  
❌ Taper off valproate and switch to carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine also increases the risk of neural tube defects due to impaired absorption of folic acid. It is similarly associated with oral clefts and multiple organ malformations and should also be avoided.  
❌ Discontinue valproate and switch to phenytoin:
Incorrect: Abrupt discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) is associated with increased risk of seizure recurrence. Moreover, phenytoin increases the risk of fetal hydantoin syndrome, in addition to increased incidence of cardiac and neural tube defects, and it should be avoided in pregnancy.  
✅ Taper off valproate and switch to levetiracetam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Add magnesium sulfate in the current regimen:
Incorrect: Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for the treatment of eclamptic seizures. It has no role in the management of epilepsy. Furthermore, valproate is a known teratogen which should be tapered off before conceiving.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner due to dizziness, difficulty walking, and severe headache for two hours. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 182/106 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 20/min. Neurologic examination demonstrates right-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose testing and right-sided dysrhythmia with rapid finger tapping. The patient appears to have difficulty with balance and a propensity to fall to the right side. Motor strength and sensation are symmetric and preserved bilaterally, and no speech deficits are apparent. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s brain lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has a lateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion resulting in ipsilateral deficits (imbalance and falling toward the side of the lesion), limb ataxia, and intention tremor.

Lateral lesions of the cerebellum affect the cortex of the cerebellar hemispheres and deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei. Cerebellar efferent fibers first cross to the contralateral side and the ipsilateral side. Together, these structures assist in planning and programming movements that influence the proximal flexor muscles of the upper extremities.

Clinically, lateral cerebellar lesions result in ipsilateral limb ataxia (loss of coordination of the limb on the same side as the lesion), which can lead to intention tremor (involuntary, trembling movements that occur with voluntary movements), dysmetria (loss of coordination that presents as the overshoot or undershoot of the intended position of the extremities), dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform fast alternating movements), decreased muscle tone of the extremities and loss of balance, with a tendency to fall towards the side of the lesion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Cerebellar vermis  :
Incorrect: Lesions that affect midline structures of the cerebellum, such as the vermis or the flocculonodular lobe, cause problems such as truncal ataxia, cerebellar gait, and the proximal muscle groups. This patient’s intention tremor and limb ataxia suggest an alternative structure.  
✅ Lateral cerebellar hemisphere  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral medulla  :
Incorrect: A lateral medullary infarct can occur due to occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar or vertebral artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain and temperature of the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vestibulocerebellar impairment, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Medial mid-pons  :
Incorrect: A medial mid-pontine infarction presents with contralateral ataxia and hemiparesis of the face, trunk, and limbs. There is a variable loss of contralateral tactile and position sense. This patient’s intention tremor and ipsilateral limb ataxia with preserved sensations suggest an alternative structure.  
❌ Medial medulla  :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome presents with contralateral paralysis of the arm and leg and tongue deviation towards the lesion.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the local urgent care with a right facial droop and ear pain. The symptoms started three days ago and have been insidious. Review of systems is significant for persistent dizziness and nausea. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection. She declined antiretroviral therapy at the time of diagnosis  two years ago. She went camping in Massachusetts with her family three months ago. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.5°F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows the right eyelid drooping with loss of the nasolabial fold on the right side. Multiple vesicles are seen in the right auditory canal and the auricle, with sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles in the auditory canal and on the auricle most likely has Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus), a major otologic complication varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection.

The etiology is the reactivation of latent VZV in the geniculate ganglion. Following primary VZV infection (chickenpox), the virus migrates via sensory nerves to the cranial nerves and ganglia, where it lies dormant for years. Risk factors for reactivation include immunocompromised states like recent chemoradiotherapy, pregnancy, transplant patients, and HIV infection with low CD4 count (as in this patient). The classic triad is ipsilateral facial paralysis (due to involvement of CN VII), ear pain, and vesicular lesions in the auditory canal or on the auricle. Other findings include altered taste perception, tongue lesions, and decreased lacrimation. The involvement of CN VIII can cause hearing abnormalities (sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, hyperacusis) and vertigo.

The treatment of choice is the guanosine analog valacyclovir with prednisone. Treatment should be initiated as soon as possible, as treatment is associated with decreased risk of postherpetic neuralgia and spread of infection.

Option Analysis

❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is considered in patients with early disseminated Lyme disease with neurologic symptoms. Although this patient traveled to a Lyme-endemic area three months ago, the development of a vesicular rash and CN VIII symptoms (vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss) makes herpes zoster a more likely diagnosis.
✅ Valacyclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Foscarnet:
Incorrect: Foscarnet is a viral DNA polymerase inhibitor used for acyclovir-resistant HSV infections and as an alternative to ganciclovir for the prophylaxis and treatment of CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is not first-line in this patient’s case.
❌ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Incorrect: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy can be considered in patients with neuroinvasive West Nile virus infection, which presents with signs and symptoms of meningoencephalitis (headache, photophobia, confusion). Development of a vesicular rash would be atypical.
❌ Hydration and supportive therapy:
Incorrect: Hydration and supportive therapy are considered in viral infections with no specific treatment, like Zika virus which presents with maculopapular rash, arthralgia and conjunctivitis after recent travel to endemic areas (e.g., Africa, Southeast Asia, the Pacific Islands, the Americas, and the Caribbean).

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent pain in his lower extremities and back for the past two months. He describes these episodes as sudden, brief, severe stabs of pain that affect his legs and back, lasting for minutes to hours. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II. He had a sexually transmitted infection in his teenage years, but he cannot remember what it was, and it resolved without treatment. He takes metformin, and he is inconsistent with clinic follow-ups. Physical examination of the lower extremities shows absence of deep tendon reflexes and impaired vibratory sensation and two-point discrimination, with normal motor strength. The Romberg test is positive. On ophthalmologic examination, the pupils fail to constrict in response to direct light, but when the patient is asked to focus on the examiner's index finger, the pupils constrict uniformly. CSF analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis. Which part of the pupillary light reflex pathway is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s pupils are nonreactive to light with the retained ability to accommodate; this finding is consistent with Argyll Robertson (AR) pupil, most likely secondary to tabes dorsalis (tertiary syphilis) given the noted history of an untreated sexually transmitted infection. He also has the characteristic lancinating pains, physical examination findings of impaired vibratory sense, positive Romberg test, and absent deep tendon reflexes, in addition to CSF findings of lymphocytic pleocytosis, all of which are seen in tertiary syphilis.

The pupillary light and accommodation reflexes start at the retina, where sensory information travels through the optic tract. For the pupillary accommodation reflex, information goes to the lateral geniculate body, then into the visual cortex, then to the superior colliculus, before arriving at the Edinger-Westphal nucleus. For the pupillary light reflex, sensory information travels straight from the optic tract into the pretectal nucleus and then to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus.

Based on these two different pathways, we can see three possible sites of a lesion which may result in preservation of the accommodation reflex but loss of the pupillary light reflex. First, there may be a lesion along the pathway from the optic tract to the midbrain only affecting the pupillary light pathway fibers; second, there may be a lesion of the pretectal nuclei where only the pupillary light reflex synapses; and third, there may be damage to the part of the Edinger-Westphal nuclei that receives input only from the pretectal nuclei, not the superior colliculus fibers of the accommodation reflex. It is thought that neurosyphilis affects one of these areas, resulting in an AR pupil.

The AR pupils don’t constrict in response to light but are responsive to accommodation (when focused on a nearby object). AR pupils are highly suggestive of tertiary syphilis; however, they can occur in other underlying conditions, such as diabetes and multiple sclerosis.



Option Analysis

✅ Edinger-Westphal nucleus.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ciliary ganglion:
Incorrect: Damage to the ciliary ganglion will cause Holmes-Adie Syndrome, in which the pupils are dilated and react slowly to direct light.
❌ Optic nerve:
Incorrect: Damage or inflammation to the optic nerve (e.g. optic neuritis) causes pain with eye movements or at rest, as well as loss of vision.
❌ Superior colliculus:
Incorrect: Superior colliculus is not involved in the pupillary light reflex pathway. It is a part of the pupillary accommodation reflex pathway, which is intact in this patient.
❌ Short ciliary nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the short ciliary nerve will lead to loss of the pupillary reflex and mydriasis.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician with double vision, which started three weeks ago. She noticed that her double vision worsens when she is reading. She also has had difficulty walking downstairs. On physical examination, the patient prefers to keep her head tilted towards the right side. Ophthalmologic examination is significant for deviation of the left eye outward and upwards. Both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and are reactive to light. The physician suspects a cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following ocular muscles most likely lost innervation due to the cranial nerve palsy seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is a pure motor nerve that is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle, which is responsible for internal rotation of the eye; it is the main muscle that depresses the eye when it is adducted.



CN IV palsy results in the loss of the superior oblique muscle action. The patient usually complains of vertical diplopia, which is mostly seen when looking inward and downwards (e.g., reading a book, descending the stairs). In addition, due to the loss of internal rotation, the eye rests in the “out and up” position. This causes the patient to tilt their head toward the contralateral side in order to minimize the diplopia.



Isolated CN IV palsy is rare and is most commonly idiopathic, which is thought to be congenital and usually appears in the fourth decade of life. Other risk factors include head trauma and diabetes. 

Option Analysis

✅ The superior oblique muscle:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ The inferior oblique muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior oblique muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The medial rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The medial rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The inferior rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The inferior rectus muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Oculomotor nerve palsy results in pupils deviating down and out (due to unopposed contraction of the superior oblique and lateral rectus muscles), with dilated pupils.
❌ The lateral rectus muscle:
Incorrect: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the abducens nerve. Abducens nerve palsy results in eye deviation medially, with inability to look laterally, and nystagmus on lateral gaze.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of persistent sciatica symptoms. The patient has had low back pain that radiates down the back of his left leg for weeks after he fell while skiing. The patient states, “The symptoms are getting so bad that I feel the leg is getting weaker. I’ve tried physical therapy, but it does not work.” The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has 4/5 strength with plantar flexion and a 1+ ankle jerk reflex on physical examination of the left leg. The right leg has 5/5 strength and full reflexes. Which of the following myotomes is most likely affected based on this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of persistent sciatica and has evidence of S1 radiculopathy given this patient’s clinical findings of pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion and diminished ankle jerk reflex.   

Deep tendon reflexes can provide valuable information regarding the level of spinal cord involvement or damage to a particular nerve route. When this reflex is triggered, stretch receptors in the muscle-tendon send afferent impulses to the spinal cord through their cell bodies in the dorsal root ganglion, which then synapse with alpha motor neurons. Alpha motor neurons then transmit an automatic efferent signal back to the muscle leading to a contraction.    

Critical deep tendon reflexes include the brachioradialis and biceps tendon, which test myotome C5 and C6; the triceps tendon, which tests C6, C7, and C8; the patellar tendon, which tests L2, L3, and L4; and the Achilles tendon, which tests S1 and S2. Hyperactive reflexes indicate an upper motor neuron problem within the spinal cord or central nervous system, whereas hypoactive reflexes indicate peripheral nerve pathology.  


Option Analysis

✅ S1-S2:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 is the myotome reflecting the knee jerk reflex, which is elicited by tapping on the patellar tendon while the knee flexes.  
❌ S3-S4:
Incorrect: S3-S4 is the myotome reflecting the anal wink reflex. This reflex may be absent in cauda equina syndrome due to compression of these nerve roots.  
❌ L1-L2:
Incorrect: L1-L2 are the myotomes associated with the cremasteric reflex, which will often be diminished in cases of testicular torsion.  
❌ C5-C6:
Incorrect: The C5-C6 myotome is associated with the biceps and brachioradialis reflexes, which are not implicated in this patient’s clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old, right-handed man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate sudden onset weakness. The patient awoke with left-hand clumsiness that rapidly progressed to left-sided weakness, affecting the left arm more than the left leg. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. The patient’s last refill of medications was one year ago. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 200/110 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has slurred speech, left-sided facial weakness sparing the forehead, 2/5 muscle strength in the left upper limb, and 4/5 muscle strength in the left lower limb. Right-sided strength and sensation are normal. A right-sided infarct localized to the paramedian pontine base is seen on MRI. Which of the following additional findings will likely be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has an infarct of the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF), which is located in the pons and supplied by the paramedian branches of the basilar artery.

The PPRF is the subcortical lateral gaze center, which normally receives input from the contralateral frontal eye field to stimulate the lateral rectus muscle of the ipsilateral eye via the ipsilateral abducens nucleus. This signal is also transmitted to the medial longitudinal fasciculus of the contralateral oculomotor nuclei to stimulate the medial rectus muscle of the contralateral eye. Together, these signals result in both eyes' simultaneous, conjugate movement towards the left or the right.

Common causes of lesions to the PPRF include ischemic or hemorrhagic strokes of the paramedian branches of the basilar artery. When these lesions occur, both eyes deviate toward the contralateral side, away from the brain lesion. On the contrary, the frontal eye field lesions produce similar symptoms where both eyes deviate but to the ipsilateral side, towards the brain lesion. For example, when the eyes deviate to the right, the lesion can either involve the left PPRF or the right frontal eye field.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bitemporal hemianopia:
Incorrect: The x-shaped optic chiasm serves as the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure results in bitemporal hemianopia. Common etiologies include pituitary tumors, craniopharyngiomas, and aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery.  
❌ Eye deviation to the right  :
Incorrect: Destructive lesions of the frontal eye field (e.g. middle cerebral artery stroke) cause the eyes to look toward the side of brain lesion (i.e. away from the side of hemiplegia). The middle cerebral artery does not supply blood to the paramedian pontine base.  
✅ Eye deviation to the left  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing  :
Incorrect: Contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing is characteristic of posterior cerebral artery infarction. Other features include alexia without agraphia when the dominant hemisphere is affected.  
❌ Vertical gaze palsy  :
Incorrect: Parinaud (dorsal midbrain) syndrome is characterized by limitation of upward gaze with a downward gaze preference, bilateral eyelid lid retraction, and near-light dissociation (i.e. pupils react to accommodation but not to light). These findings often result from compression of the pretectal region of the midbrain (most likely from a pinealoma).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician to evaluate dysphagia and hoarseness that have been ongoing for the past three days. He has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. He has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/85 mmHg, and pulse is 92/min. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the posterior aspect of the tongue. The uvula deviates towards the right side. The appearance of the uvula suggests loss of function of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
The vagus nerve carries parasympathetic motor fibers to the somatic organs. It also provides motor supply to the muscles of the larynx, pharynx and soft palate.   

The main motor nucleus of the vagus nerve is situated within the reticular formation of the medulla oblongata. It receives inputs from the corticonuclear fibers and sends motor impulses via the direct pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve to the constrictor muscles of the pharynx and soft palate (except for the tensor palatini muscles) and intrinsic muscles of the larynx.    

The uvula is a centrally located conic projection from the soft palate. If the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve is injured, the uvula will deviate away from the side of the lesion and towards the contralateral (unaffected) side. This phenomenon occurs due to a combination of intact palatal muscle pull on the contralateral side and palatal droop on the ipsilateral side.  

Additional symptoms seen in high vagal injuries include dysphagia from palatal weakness and paralysis of the constrictor muscles, in addition to hoarseness from impaired sensation from the superior laryngeal nerve (another branch of the vagus nerve).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Right vagus nerve:
Incorrect: The uvula deviates towards the contralateral side from the causative lesion. As a result, rightwards deviation of the uvula is suggestive of a left vagus nerve injury.
✅ Left vagus nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation.   
❌ Right glossopharyngeal nerve :
Incorrect: Uvular deviation is due to vagal nerve injury and subsequent loss of palatal muscle function. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury does not cause uvular deviation. 
❌ Left hypoglossal nerve :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve is responsible for the movement of the tongue. Loss of the left hypoglossal nerve function will result in ipsilateral tongue deviation. In contrast, uvular deviation is due to vagus nerve injury.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department as a level 1 trauma following a fall from scaffolding. The patient worked as a painter and slipped and fell approximately 20 ft, landing on his back. Upon arrival, the patient has a GCS of 15 and endorses pain in his lower back. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 176/65 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 97% on room air. The patient's primary survey is intact, and his secondary survey is notable for a step-off and pain at the T12-L1 spinal level. An emergent MRI of the spine is demonstrated below. Which of the following additional clinical features is most specific to this patient's clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation following back trauma and has an MRI that demonstrates a compression fracture of the L1 vertebral body with subsequent compression on the conus medullaris. This neurosurgical emergency presents with all the clinical features of cauda equina syndrome, plus upper motor neuron deficits such as hyperreflexia.    

Conus medullaris syndrome is a rare neurosurgical emergency that refers to compression of the conus medullaris from trauma, spinal epidural abscess, hematoma, or disc herniation. This pathologic entity presents with many overlapping features of cauda equina syndrome, including acute lower back pain with associated lower extremity weakness, saddle anesthesia, and bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction.  

Key differentiating features of conus medullaris syndrome include the presence of upper motor neuron deficits (e.g. hyperreflexia, increased tone) and symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness. The latter may be mild if the lesion is restricted and spares both the lumbar cord and the adjacent sacral and lumbar nerve roots. In addition, conus medullaris syndrome is more commonly implicated in spinal lesions from T12-L1 since the spinal cord terminates as the conus medullaris at this level in most adult patients. Trauma or lesions below this spinal level are unlikely to result in conus medullaris syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia :
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific.  
❌ Asymmetric lower extremity weakness:
Incorrect: Symmetric, bilateral lower extremity weakness is more likely to be found in patients with conus medullaris syndrome; however, it can also be observed in patients with cauda equina syndrome and is therefore nonspecific.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is found in both conditions and is not specific to conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome.  
❌ Decreased bulbocavernosus reflex:
Incorrect: A decreased bulbocavernosus reflex is present in both cauda equina syndrome and conus medullaris syndrome and is therefore not specific to either condition.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate following an episode of shaking in multiple limbs. According to the roommate, for the past few days, the patient has had fevers, headaches and vomited multiple times. An hour ago, while sitting in the living room, the patient lost consciousness and his right hand started shaking. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and flexion of the neck elicits an involuntary flexion of the knees and hips. Two blood cultures are obtained, followed by the administration of empiric antibiotics. CT of the head shows temporal lobe abnormalities. Which of the following laboratory studies is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Detection of antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, headaches, and new onset of a focal seizure; he likely has encephalitis. Since the patient had a recent seizure, a CT scan should be performed first to exclude contraindications for lumbar puncture. The CT revealed abnormality of the temporal lobe, a highly suggestive finding for Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis. 

HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis. Most cases are caused by type HSV-1, but type 2 is also seen. Patients often present with rapid onset of fever and at least one of the following: altered mentation, focal cranial nerve deficits, hemiparesis, dysphasia, aphasia, ataxia, focal seizures, headache, and focal neurologic signs. HSV encephalitis is a devastating disease with significant morbidity and mortality, even with antiviral therapy. Therefore, intravenous acyclovir should be administered empirically in any patient that is suspected of having HSV encephalitis. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, increased number of erythrocytes (due to hemorrhage), and elevated protein. However, the CSF profile can be normal early in the course of the disease and therefore is not diagnostic. CSF polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used to identify HSV-1, HSV-2, and enteroviruses. Identification of HSV-1 in the CSF is an efficient, rapid, sensitive, and specific diagnostic test for HSV-1 encephalitis and therefore is the test of choice.   

Option Analysis

❌ Cerebrospinal fluid cultures:
Incorrect: CSF cultures for herpes simplex virus have a sensitivity of less than 10% and, therefore, are not reliable.
❌ Brain biopsy:
Incorrect: Brain biopsy is the "gold standard" for the diagnosis of herpes virus encephalitis. Although brain biopsy has a sensitivity of 99% and a specificity of 100%, it is an invasive procedure, and the results take a few days; therefore, it is not the test of choice.
✅ Cerebrospinal fluid polymerase chain reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Detection of antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid:
Incorrect: Measuring herpes virus antigens or antibodies in the CSF has sensitivity and specificity rates of approximately 80% and hence are not the test of choice. 
❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: Focal electroencephalogram (EEG) findings are positive in approximately 80% of cases of herpes encephalitis, and EEG may show prominent intermittent high amplitude slow waves (delta and theta slowing) or continuous periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges. However, EEG findings are often nonspecific, and therefore, it is not the test of choice.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of "shakiness" in his hands. The tremor is most noticeable when he is holding something or writing and is more prominent in the right hand than the left. The patient’s only medication is an albuterol rescue inhaler for long-standing asthma. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. He is constantly nodding his head even when the physician does not ask any questions. A tremor is noted while the patient picks up a pen. Gait is normal, and there is no resting tremor. The remainder of the neurologic exam is normal. Which of the following medications would be the best choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is presenting with progressive, bilateral action tremor and head tremor, along with a normal neurological examination, most likely has essential tremor (ET). β-adrenergic blockers (e.g. propranolol) have been the mainstay of treatment for these tremors, but beta blockers are contraindicated in this patient given the history of asthma. Therefore, primidone should be the preferred treatment.  

Tremor is defined as a rhythmic, involuntary, oscillatory movement of a body part caused by either alternating or synchronous antagonist muscle contractions. ET is the most common cause of action tremor in adults. Classically, ET involves the hands and becomes apparent by arm movement during an activity (intention tremor) or sustained antigravity postures. The tremor can be quite disabling, affecting daily activities such as writing, drinking from a glass, and using utensils. The tremor is typically slowly progressive, bilateral, slightly asymmetric with moderate to high frequency (6 to 12 Hz). ET may also affect the head, voice, and less commonly, the face or trunk. A helpful clue often seen on USMLE exams is that ET is often relieved by small amounts of alcohol intake, and therefore, patients often self-medicate with alcoholic beverages.  

The neuropathologic basis of ET remains poorly understood, but involvement of the cerebellum and brainstem (locus coeruleus) has been suggested. ET has a strong genetic component, often referred to as “familial tremor.” The diagnosis of ET is based purely upon the clinical features according to the following criteria:

  •  Isolated, bilateral upper limb action tremor, without other motor abnormalities 
  •  At least three years in duration 
  •  With/without a tremor in other locations (e.g., head, voice, or lower limbs) 
  •  Absence of other neurologic signs (e.g., parkinsonism, ataxia) 
First-line treatment consists of beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol) or certain barbiturates (e.g. primidone). 

Option Analysis

❌ Levodopa/carbidopa:
Incorrect: Levodopa in combination with carbidopa is useful in the treatment of parkinsonian tremors but not essential tremors. Parkinson disease presents with a pill-rolling tremor at rest that tends to resolve with purposeful movement. This patient’s presentation is instead consistent with essential tremor. 
✅ Primidone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amantadine:
Incorrect: Amantadine is an antiviral that has also been shown to have mild anti-parkinsonian effects. It is not a medication indicated for the treatment of essential tremor.
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used to treat essential tremor, such as in this patient. However, this patient's asthma could be exacerbated by propranolol, and therefore, another medication is considered first-line at this time.
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines are often prescribed for essential tremor because the condition is mistaken to be the result of anxiety. If the condition is worse with anxiety, an anxiolytic may partially reduce tremor. However, they are not first-line treatment due to the potential for abuse and dependence, the side effect profile, and the withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset of weakness of the right upper and right lower extremity for three hours. He does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or leg pain. His past medical history includes recurrent infections when he lived in Mexico as a child, all of which were resolved with “home remedies.” He immigrated to the United States in his 30’s and was told by several physicians he has a cardiac murmur. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 141/78 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. He has marked weakness and sensory loss of  the right arm and right leg. There is no warmth, swelling or increased diameter of either leg. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: CT of the brain with contrast
CT of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of sudden onset hemiplegia in the setting of an irregularly irregular heart rate, consistent with an embolic stroke secondary to atrial fibrillation. The two main types of stroke are  ischemic and hemorrhagic, with different management approaches for each. Therefore, differentiating between these two entities is the initial, primary goal, which is best accomplished with a stat  non-contrast CT scan of the brain. I  

In the case of an ischemic stroke, the primary management involves thrombolytic therapy (e.g. alteplase administration or thrombectomy) dependent on the time-course of illness. For eligible patients with acute ischemic stroke--that is 4.5 hours since symptom onset--intravenous tPA is first-line therapy. Since the administration of alteplase is time dependent, patients with concern for ischemic stroke need to be evaluated expeditiously.

In the initial evaluation of stroke, administration of intravenous contrast should be avoided to prevent the masking of blood from underlying hemorrhage--since both contrast and blood appear as white, or hyperdense lucencies on CT imaging. If a non-contrast CT brain is without evidence of hyperdense lucency, the patient may be suffering from an ischemic stroke.

Option Analysis

❌ CT of the brain with contrast:
Incorrect: Obtaining a noncontrast CT of the head to exclude hemorrhagic stroke is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient, as hemorrhagic stroke cannot be reliably distinguished from ischemic stroke on clinical grounds alone. The use of contrast would inhibit the ability to visualize underlying hemorrhage. 
✅ CT of the brain without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: An electroencephalogram (EEG) may be beneficial in patients who present with syncope or seizures. They are not, however, useful in the initial management of patients presenting with signs and symptoms of a stroke.
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Head imaging is crucial in the initial steps of stroke management; however, CT is preferred initial imaging due to its rapidity and effectiveness at distinguishing between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
