Incorrect: Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography can detect cardiogenic and aortic sources of cerebral embolic stroke. Utilization of these tests should be postponed until later in the hospitalization, when the patient is in a stable clinical condition.
❌ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Transthoracic and transesophageal echocardiography can detect cardiogenic and aortic sources of cerebral embolic stroke. Utilization of these tests should be postponed until later in the hospitalization, when the patient is in a stable clinical condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate intermittent painful double vision for three days. Her symptoms occur only when looking laterally. The patient has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for ten years. Ten days ago, the patient fell off her bike and was seen in the emergency department. During that visit, a head CT scan was performed and was unremarkable. Current medications include oral contraceptive pills. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the pupils are equal and reactive to light. Corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. The left eye abducts with attempted left gaze, but the right eye remains stationary. The right eye abducts and exhibits horizontal nystagmus with a rightward gaze, but the left eye remains stationary. The patient can converge both eyes without associated nystagmus. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc hyperemia. Injury to which of the following structures is the most likely etiology of this patient's ocular symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic adduction defects of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) and hyperemia of the optic discs. Together, these findings indicate optic neuritis, one of the most common initial findings of multiple sclerosis (MS).

INO is a disorder of conjugate horizontal gaze. The affected eye cannot adduct, and the contralateral eye abducts with nystagmus; however, convergence and pupillary light reflexes are preserved. This condition is secondary to demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which normally mediates communication between the CN III (oculomotor) and CN VI (abducens) nuclei to allow for coordinated horizontal eye movements. Unilateral MLF lesions often result from lacunar strokes in the pontine artery distribution, whereas bilateral MLF lesions are typically observed in patients with MS.  



Option Analysis

❌ Oculomotor nerve  :
Incorrect: Damage to the oculomotor nerve (CN III) leaves the actions of the lateral rectus and the superior oblique muscle unopposed, resulting in an abducted and depressed eye (“down and out”). Ptosis and mydriasis are often seen as well.  
❌ Medial lemniscus  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the medial lemniscus would result in contralateral loss of vibration, proprioception, and light touch.  
✅ Medial longitudinal fasciculus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dorsal midbrain  :
Incorrect: Damage to the dorsal midbrain can cause Parinaud syndrome, with impaired upgaze and dilated non-reactive pupils. Moreover, Parinaud syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with hydrocephalus or posterior midbrain lesions (e.g. pineal tumors); trauma is an infrequent cause of Parinaud syndrome.  
❌ Abducens nerve:
Incorrect: Abducens nerve damage results in isolated lateral rectus palsy and an inability to abduct the eye.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department after being involved in a street fight. The patient was punched in the left eye and subsequently developed eye pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), the pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows a laceration on the left brow, left-sided periorbital ecchymosis, and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The left eye appears slightly sunken compared to the right. The visual acuity is as expected in both eyes on the Snellen chart. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is shown.


Reproduced from Radiopedia

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient received a direct blow to the orbit during a street fight that resulted in an orbital floor fracture. The CT scan demonstrates herniation of the inferior rectus muscle into the maxillary sinus, which can cause impairment of upward gaze.  

The orbital floor is composed of a thin layer of bone that separates the orbit from the air-filled maxillary sinus. Orbital floor fractures, sometimes known as "blowout fractures,” result from force transmitted from blunt trauma (e.g., when a small, round object such as a baseball or fist strikes the eye) through the orbital soft tissue into the bony orbital walls. This commonly results in fractures of the medial and inferior orbital walls due to the thin bone in these areas.    

Since the inferior rectus muscle lies directly above the orbital floor, it can herniate through a fracture in the floor of the orbit and into the maxillary sinus below. If the muscle becomes entrapped in the fracture, the patient will demonstrate limited upward gaze and thus vertical diplopia. Injury to the infraorbital nerve (resulting in decreased sensation along the cheek, upper lip, or upper gingiva) may also occur due to an orbital floor fracture.  

Fracture is usually evident on radiographic imaging, and fluids or herniation of orbital contents can be visualized in the adjacent, normally air-filled sinuses or nasal cavities.   

Option Analysis

✅ Impaired upward gaze:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Absent corneal reflex:
Incorrect: Corneal reflex can be impaired with orbital fissure fractures, as the nerves involved (CNV1 and CN VII) pass through it. It is not affected by orbital floor fractures. 
❌ Bruising of the mastoid process:
Incorrect: Bruising of the mastoid process and periorbital ecchymosis and clear otorrhea suggest basal skull fracture. 
❌ Fixed and dilated left pupil:
Incorrect: A fixed and dilated left pupil can occur in the setting of orbital trauma due to increased intraorbital pressure. This can occur from retrobulbar hematoma or other causes of orbital compartment syndrome. This would be accompanied by proptosis, which is not found in this patient. 
❌ Impaired olfaction:
Incorrect: Nasal fractures or high force trauma to the midface can impair olfaction if olfactory nerves are torn from the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. This patient has an orbital floor fracture.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of double vision and headache, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Her symptoms started three days ago and have worsened since the onset. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, for which she takes amlodipine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Ophthalmologic examination reveals bilateral papilledema and medial deviation of the right eye. Abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal in both the eyes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s double vision?

choices.text: Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery
Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone
Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery
Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) including papilledema, nausea, vomiting and headache. The ophthalmologic findings of diplopia and dysfunction of lateral gaze of the right eye are concerning for abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy. This patient most likely has a space-occupying lesion that is stretching and injuring the CN VI for which imaging (e.g. MRI) is warranted.

The abducens nerve (CN VI) is a pure motor nerve that supplies the lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for abducting the eye. It exits the midbrain at the level of pontomedullary junction, then crosses over the petrous apex of the temporal bone, where it enters the cavernous sinus. It then travels towards the lateral rectus muscle.

CN VI palsy causes loss of lateral movement of the affected eye, leaving the action of the medial rectus muscle unopposed, which leads to medial deviation of the eye and resulting diplopia. Diplopia usually worsens when looking towards the side of the lesion and resolves when looking away from the lesion.



The most common cause of abducens nerve palsy is increased ICP, which can stretch the nerve as it crosses over the petrous apex. Common causes of increased ICP include space-occupying lesions (e.g., tumor, abscess). Other causes of CN VI palsy include head trauma, cavernous sinus thrombosis, demyelinating disorders, ischemic vascular disease and mastoiditis or otitis media, which may spread to the petrous portion of the temporal bone and damage the abducens nerve.



Option Analysis

❌ Compression of a cranial nerve by an aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: Aneurysm in the posterior communicating artery can compress the oculomotor nerve. This causes the eye to deviate down and out and the affected pupil to dilate (mydriasis). None of this is seen in this patient. Instead, this patient is most likely having CN VI palsy due to increased intracranial pressure.
✅ Stretching and injury to a cranial nerve over the petrous portion of the temporal bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thrombosis of the cavernous sinus:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis can cause CN VI palsy, but this condition is usually associated with proptosis, orbital swelling, and other cranial nerve palsies (e.g., CN III, CN IV).
❌ Occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the medial midbrain. Its occlusion causes Weber syndrome, which is characterized by oculomotor nerve dysfunction with associated contralateral hemiparesis, which are not seen in this patient.
❌ Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which is characterized by loss of the gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness, and loss of pain and temperature sensation of the face and the contralateral side of the body. This patient does not have Wallenberg syndrome.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the clinic for evaluation of memory problems. The patient has become increasingly forgetful and has trouble remembering recent events, but memory of remote events remains intact. The patient is able to cook for himself and has no trouble getting around the neighborhood. The patient does not have depressive symptoms. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which amlodipine, valsartan, metformin, insulin and atorvastatin are prescribed. The patient has been smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg. Mental status examination is significant for anterograde amnesia. Pathologic involvement of which of the following areas of the brain is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with isolated anterograde amnesia (difficulty remembering recent events) without dysfunction in performing activities of daily living; he has most likely suffered damage to the hippocampus. Past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension, active smoking, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia puts this patient at risk of having significant atherosclerotic disease.  

The hippocampus serves as a component of the limbic system, which is involved in the formation and retrieval of recent memories and in the conversion of recent memory to long-term memory. The hippocampus receives its blood supply from the terminal branches of the anterior choroidal artery and posterior cerebral artery and is in a watershed area, making it particularly susceptible to ischemic damage. Injury to the hippocampus results in anterograde amnesia (the inability to form new memories) with preservation of remote past memories.  



Option Analysis

❌ Nucleus basalis:
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis is involved in the production of acetylcholine for the cerebral cortex. Decreased production of acetylcholine is believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer disease. This patient presents with isolated memory loss without dysfunction in activities of daily living and is therefore less likely to have Alzheimer dementia.
❌ Ventral tegmentum:
Incorrect: The ventral tegmentum provides dopaminergic input, and decreased activity can be associated with Parkinson disease.
❌ Raphe nucleus:
Incorrect: The raphe nucleus provides serotonergic input, and decreased activity of this region of the brain is sometimes associated with depression.
✅ Hippocampus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome is caused by a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. It results in spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to an episode of convulsions. His roommate who accompanied him reported that in the last few days, the patient has had progressively worsening headaches, fevers and malaise. The roommate notes that the patient was complaining of a runny nose and sinus pain several days earlier. He does not recall any blunt trauma and states his roommate does not use recreational drugs. The patient has no recent travel history. Medical history is unremarkable other than recurrent sinusitis. The patient is a veterinary student and works as a clinic assistant. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination the patient is postictal, and unilateral hemiparesis is noted. MRI is obtained and reveals a ring-enhancing lesion of 3 cm surrounded by vasogenic edema within the frontal lobe. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in this patient management?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, headaches, seizure and a focal neurologic deficit, a presentation consistent with brain abscess. The MRI confirms the diagnosis by showing a solitary ring-enhancing lesion within the frontal lobe, most likely due to direct spread of bacteria from the patient’s preceding sinus infection.  

A brain abscess is a focal collection of pus within the brain tissue that occurs as a complication of infection, trauma or surgery. Bacteria gain access to the brain either by direct spread from a contiguous location or through hematogenous seeding. A direct spread of infection from a contiguous site usually causes a single abscess, while the spread through bacteremia usually causes multiple lesions. Primary infections that can directly spread to the brain include:  

  •  otitis media and mastoiditis, resulting in abscess formation in the temporal lobe and/or cerebellum 
  •  sinusitis in the frontal or ethmoid sinuses, resulting in abscess formation in the frontal lobes 
  •  dental infections, resulting in abscess formation in the frontal lobes  
The pathogens involved differ depending upon the primary infection location, patient age, and the immune status of the host. However, viridans streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus are the most common pathogens. Patients may present with a classic triad of headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits; however, this triad is not always present. Other signs may include seizure and altered mental status. Imaging may show ring-enhancing lesions (MRI most sensitive). Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of intracranial pressure signs due to the risk of herniation. Stereotactic CT-guided aspiration is required to direct treatment. Treatment of brain abscesses usually requires a combination of antibiotics and surgical drainage. 


Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar puncture :
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture can assist in the diagnosis; however, it is contraindicated in a patient with focal symptoms or signs (e.g. unilateral weakness) due to the risk of brain herniation. 
✅ Surgical drainage:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Pyrimethamine is used for the treatment of toxoplasmosis, which is caused by the intracellular protozoan parasite, Toxoplasma gondii. Reactivation of latent infection is often seen in immunocompromised patients and presents with multiple central nervous system ring-enhancing lesions. Primary infection in immunocompetent individuals is usually asymptomatic. This patient is immunocompetent, and the presence of focal neurologic deficit favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Albendazole :
Incorrect: Albendazole is used for the treatment of Cysticercosis caused by the larval cysts of the cestodes (tapeworms) Taenia solium parasite. Humans acquire the larvae encysted in undercooked pork (intestinal larvae) and later pass the eggs in food contaminated with human feces (cysticercosis). Patients present with multiple cystic central nervous system (CNS) lesions and seizures. It is unlikely in this patient who has had no travel history.   
❌ Empiric metronidazole and doxycycline:
Incorrect: Empiric treatment is often used in the treatment of brain abscess until the results of culture and gram stain become available. However, doxycycline and other tetracyclines antibiotics have poor penetration to the CNS and, therefore, are not prefered.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of a one-week history of eye pain and double vision. The patient also noticed swelling that started around her right eye but is now around both eyes. She says she feels “warm” but does not have a thermometer at home to take her temperature. Before her symptoms started, she had a toothache, for which she tried ibuprofen. She did not see a dentist. She has no significant past medical or surgical history. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. Physical examination reveals proptosis of both eyes with periorbital edema. In addition, abduction of the right eye is impaired. All other eye movements are normal, and both pupils are 3 mm in diameter and reactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ophthalmalgia, periorbital edema that started unilaterally and quickly progressed bilaterally, and CN VI palsy; she most likely has cavernous sinus syndrome. She also has high-grade fever in the setting of a possible tooth infection, making cavernous sinus thrombosis the most likely cause.

The cavernous sinus is a dural venous sinus that is found lateral to the sella turcica on both sides. It contains many important structures including the abducens nerve (CN VI), the internal carotid artery and associated postganglionic sympathetic fibers, the oculomotor nerve (CN III), the trochlear nerve (CN IV), and the ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V)



The abducens nerve and internal carotid artery (with its postganglionic sympathetic fibers) run in the center of the sinus, while the oculomotor, trochlear, ophthalmic and maxillary nerves run along the lateral walls of the sinus. As a result, abducens nerve (CN VI) palsy is the first and most common palsy associated with cavernous sinus syndrome, though other structures in the sinus can also be affected.

In addition to nerve palsies, patients usually develop headache, periorbital edema, proptosis, and chemosis, which start unilaterally and then progress to bilateral involvement. Horner syndrome can occur with injury to the postganglionic fibers. Fever can be present if the cause is septic, and patients can develop vision loss.

Cavernous sinus syndrome can occur due to tumors (e.g., meningioma, pituitary tumor), carotid artery aneurysm, and cavernous sinus thrombosis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually occurs due to an infection spreading from adjacent structures such as sinuses, ears, eyes, or teeth.




Option Analysis

✅ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) presents with headache, nausea, vomiting, and decreased visual acuity. It is not associated with fever, proptosis, or periorbital edema.
❌ Orbital cellulitis:
Incorrect: Orbital cellulitis can cause proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and fever. However, it is exceedingly rare to be bilateral. The bilateral nature of this patient’s symptoms favors cavernous sinus thrombosis as the diagnosis.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Although multiple sclerosis can cause demyelination of any cranial nerve (including the abducens nerve), it is not associated with acute proptosis or orbital swelling. In addition, this patient does not have a history of other neurological manifestations disseminated in place and time (e.g., lower extremity paresis, ataxia).
❌ Superior vena cava syndrome:
Incorrect: Superior vena cava syndrome is characterized by diffuse facial and neck swelling and plethora, distended neck veins, upper extremities swelling, cough, and dyspnea. This patient has orbital swelling with ophthalmoplegia, making cavernous sinus syndrome more likely.

questions.text: A 72-year-old right-handed person is brought to the clinic to establish care. The patient was recently discharged from the hospital where they were admitted for the management of a stroke. The patient initially presented with left-sided hemiparesis and was found to have a large ischemic stroke involving the right middle cerebral artery. The patient did not receive fibrinolytic therapy as they presented outside of the administration window. The patient participated in physical therapy during hospitalization and reports that muscle strength has improved significantly. The patient reports that they feel like they are coming back to their baseline. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows motor strength of 4/5 on the left side. Dress and appearance on the left side of their body appears unkempt. When asked to draw a clock and copy a box and a flower, their drawings appear as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, they only draw the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (inattention to the left side of the body) most likely has spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. This patient also exhibits anosognosia (unawareness of neural defect). Together, these features suit a diagnosis of hemispatial neglect syndrome.

Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from injury to the inferior parietal lobe in the non-dominant hemisphere. This area houses the somatosensory association area and is supplied by the angular and posterior parietal arteries, which are branches of the middle cerebral artery (MCA). Injury to this area ultimately results in a patient who is unable to integrate somatic and visual inputs and cannot appreciate an image on the opposite side of the body.  

Clinical manifestations include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body and anosognosia (individual is unaware of neural defect). Affected individuals may fail to shave, wash, and dress the contralateral half of their bodies. When asked to draw a clock, the patient's drawing might only show numbers on one side of the clock or all 12 numbers might be on one half with the other half distorted (construction apraxia).  

Option Analysis

❌ Kluver-Bucy syndrome:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.
✅ Hemispatial neglect syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Gerstmann syndrome:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome is a dominant hemispheric stroke syndrome that usually results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Frontal lobe syndrome:
Incorrect: Frontal lobe syndrome occurs as a result of damage to the prefrontal cortex. This condition presents with disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Damage to the corpus callosum:
Incorrect: The corpus callosum transfers information between the cerebral hemispheres. Damage to the corpus callosum results in transcortical apraxia, wherein the patient is unable to execute learned motor movement using the side of the body supplied by the nondominant hemisphere.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient is unresponsive, and the paramedics report a witnessed generalized-tonic-clonic seizure. Past history is significant for mitral valve replacement four years ago, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include aspirin, warfarin, enalapril, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. On examination, the patient appears comatose with mispositioned and fixed pupils. The upper extremities are adducted, extended, and in hyperpronation. The lower extremities appear extended, adducted, and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. A non-contrast CT scan of the head demonstrates extensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage with a horizontal shift of midline structures. Damage to which of the following anatomic structures most likely contributed to the extensor posturing observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage that is complicated by brain herniation (coma, mispositioned and fixed pupils, and rigid extension of upper and lower extremities).

Abnormal posturing secondary to brain herniation results from disruption of the descending tracts (e.g. rubrospinal and vestibulospinal tracts) involved in reflexive and postural movements. The red nucleus in the midbrain gives rise to the rubrospinal tract, which acts on the proximal flexor musculature of the upper limbs.  
 
  •  Transection or injury to the brainstem at the level of the red nucleus or below the red nucleus (pons) damages the rubrospinal tract. Spared vestibulospinal and reticulospinal tracts overstimulate extensor muscles, leading to the characteristic decerebrate/extensor posturing where the upper extremities are adducted, extended and in hyperpronation, while the lower extremities are also extended, adducted and internally rotated with the feet in plantar flexion. 
 
  •  Damage above the level of the red nucleus (e.g. cerebral hemisphere and internal capsule) over stimulates the flexor muscles of the upper extremities. The unaffected vestibulospinal and pontine reticulospinal tracts stimulate the extensor muscles of the body leading to decorticate/flexion posturing, where upper extremities are adducted and flexed with wrists, hands and fingers flexed into fists near the chest, while the lower extremities remain extended and internally rotated with feet in plantarflexion and big toes pointing medially. 


Option Analysis

❌ Locus coeruleus  :
Incorrect:  The locus coeruleus houses norepinephrine secreting neurons that participate in fight and flight responses during physical and emotional stress. It is located in the dorsal pons and does not affect the motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
✅ Red nucleus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raphe nuclei  :
Incorrect: The raphe nuclei are located in the midbrain, pons, and medulla and project widely through the CNS. They house serotonergic neurons which play a role in sleep-wake cycle, anxiety, psychosis and mood changes. They do not affect motor coordination of the upper and lower extremities.  
❌ Substantia nigra:
Incorrect: The substantia nigra contains dopaminergic neurons, which are depleted in Parkinson disease. This disease presents with bradykinesia, involuntary tremor, and rigidity.  
❌ Nucleus basalis of Meynert  :
Incorrect: The nucleus basalis of Meynert houses the cell bodies of cholinergic neurons. Decreased acetylcholine is released from these neurons in patients with Alzheimer disease.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her family medicine physician for a routine checkup after sustaining a right tibia fracture from a motor vehicle accident one month ago. She has been using crutches frequently for ambulation and endorses decreased sensation over her right dorsoradial arm and an inability to extend her right wrist, thumb, and fingers. The patient states that her symptoms subside with rest. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of radial nerve compression (often known as “Saturday night palsy”).   Patients with this condition often have a history of persistent compression applied to the axilla, either by a physical object such as crutches or via prolonged abduction of the arm (e.g. falling asleep on an outstretched arm).

Patients with radial nerve compression often endorse absent or decreased sensation on the dorsoradial side of the hand and wrist, in addition to the inability to extend their wrist, thumb, and fingers. When the hand is placed in pronation, the wrist and hand will drop (a finding known as “wrist drop”)—approximately 92% of patients suffering from radial nerve compression resolve with observation alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ C7 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
❌ Carpal tunnel syndrome  :
Incorrect: This patient’s disease etiology and symptomatology are not congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome, which presents with median nerve neuropathy most commonly in patients with underlying diabetes, hypothyroidism, or repetitive hand motions.  
✅ Radial nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulnar nerve injury  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injury presents with an ulnar claw hand, rather than complete wrist drop as observed in this patient’s presentation.  
❌ C5-C6 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: Upper brachial plexus injuries often occur from lateral flexion of the neck, causing partial or complete laceration of cervical nerve roots C5-6. Injury to these nerve roots results in Erb palsy, wherein the wrist is flexed, the forearm is extended, and the arm is internally rotated.

questions.text: A 85-year-old left-handed woman is brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden involuntary body movements. The patient states that she is having a hard time controlling movements of her right leg. Symptoms started a few hours ago. Past medical history is notable for diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. The patient takes metformin, insulin, amlodipine, valsartan, atorvastatin, and aspirin. The patient smokes one to two cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 160/93 mmHg. Physical examination shows intermittent wide flinging movements of the patient’s proximal right arm and leg. Damage to which of the following parts of the brain is the most likely cause of these abnormal body movements?
questions.solution:
Hemiballismus is a form of  involuntary movement associated with diseases afflicting the subthalamic nuclei. These movements are typically unilateral, irregular, and of large amplitude (violent flinging movement of limbs) that become more prominent with action. A lacunar stroke involving penetrating branches of a large cerebral artery supplying the subthalamus is the most common etiology of hemiballismus. Risk factors for lacunar strokes include hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. 

The basal ganglia consists of gray matter masses within the cerebral hemispheres. These include the caudate, putamen, globus pallidus, and amygdaloid nucleus. The subthalamic nuclei, substantia nigra, and the red nucleus are structures functionally related to the basal ganglia. Physiologically, the subthalamic nucleus sends excitatory signals to the globus pallidus that, in turn, inhibits the thalamus and serves as an important modulator of basal ganglia output to regulate movement.  



Option Analysis

✅ Left subthalamic nucleus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus presents with left-sided hemiballismus.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus is the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior left parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock) and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
❌ Bilateral amygdala:
Incorrect: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral lesions of the amygdala and surrounding cortex of the temporal lobe. Affected patients present with hypersexuality, hyperphagia, and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Some patients exhibit visual agnosia, or psychic blindness, and personality changes, like passivity or docility.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to slurred speech and difficulty swallowing. The patient’s symptoms started two weeks ago and have progressively worsened. In addition, she has noticed excessive drooling and difficulty chewing food. She was seen five years ago due to painful eye movements, decreased vision in the left eye, and associated left lower extremity weakness. She was started on a monoclonal antibody, which helped control her symptoms, but she later stopped using it due to the adverse effects. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals brisk jaw reflexes bilaterally and an exaggerated gag reflex. The patient bursts out into spontaneous laughter on multiple occasions during the encounter. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts
Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus
Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus
Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX

questions.solution:
Pseudobulbar palsy is an upper motor neuron lesion involving the corticobulbar (supranuclear) pathways of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. An upper motor neuron lesion occurs above the motor nuclei of the cranial nerves. Pseudobulbar palsy is caused by bilateral damage to the corticobulbar tracts. Causes of the condition include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), strokes, traumatic brain injury, neoplasm, and multiple sclerosis (as is the likely diagnosis in this patient).  

The clinical presentation of pseudobulbar palsy includes dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and an increased gag reflex. Patients may also show signs of emotional lability and apathy. Of note, while the gag reflex is exaggerated in pseudobulbar palsy (upper motor neuron lesion), it is typically absent in bulbar palsy (lower motor neuron lesion). This difference is a key clinical sign used to distinguish between bulbar and pseudobulbar palsy.  



Option Analysis

✅ Demyelination of the bilateral corticobulbar tracts:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Mass in the jugular foramen:
Incorrect: A mass in the jugular foramen can compress cranial nerves IX, X, and XI and result in bulbar palsy. Bulbar palsy can manifest with weakness in the muscles supplied by these nerves and an absent gag reflex since it is a lower motor neuron lesion. However, emotional lability (inappropriate laughter) is not seen in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the bilateral nucleus ambiguus :
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Tumor affecting the right nucleus ambiguus:
Incorrect: The nucleus ambiguus contains the motor nuclei for CN IX, X, and XI. A lesion affecting this structure will lead to bulbar palsy, resembling pseudobulbar palsy. However, reflexes are diminished, and emotional lability is absent in patients with bulbar palsy. 
❌ Demyelination of the distal aspect cranial nerve IX:
Incorrect: This patient has an exaggerated gag reflex, suggestive of an upper motor neuron lesion. In contrast, demyelination of the peripheral portions of the cranial nerves outside the skull will result in lower motor neuron symptoms, such as decreased reflexes.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate low back pain. The patient was using the rowing machine at the gym when he felt a “pop” in his back followed by pain. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion on the left compared to 5/5 strength on the right. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to demonstrate a positive finding given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and findings of L2-L4 radiculopathy, including diminished sensation over the anterior aspect of the leg and decreased strength with hip flexion. Given these findings, the exam maneuver most likely to be positive is the straight leg raise, which often reproduces symptoms of sciatic nerve root compression.    

The evaluation of low back pain involves a detailed examination, beginning with inspection and palpation for tenderness, step-offs, and deformities. When radiculopathy is suspected, additional examination maneuvers include checking the lower extremities for reflexes, strength, and sensation. Special examination techniques include the straight leg raise, which is performed with the patient lying down on their back, and the examiner lifts the patient's leg while the knee is straight. Reproduction of pain with radiation down the leg indicates a positive test.



Specific sensory or motor findings can also indicate the anatomic location of radiculopathy. For example, L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg, with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction. L5 radiculopathy presents with pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot, with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion. Lastly, S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a diminished ankle jerk reflex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Straight leg raise test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stork test :
Incorrect: The stork test, also known as the Gillet test, assesses for sacroiliac joint movement between the innominate and sacrum through the clinician's palpation of the posterior superior iliac spine during knee flexion. A positive test is an indication of sacroiliac joint hypomobility. 
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: The Thessaly test, like the McMurray test, is used to detect meniscal injuries of the knee, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.  
❌ Ober test:
Incorrect: The Ober test detects tension in the iliotibial band, not lumbosacral radiculopathy.   
❌ FABER test:
Incorrect: The FABER test evaluates hip pathology by flexing, abducting, and externally rotating the hip. It is not helpful for the evaluation of lumbosacral radiculopathy.

questions.text: A 17-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to behavioral concerns. The patient has been less interactive with family members and more irritable for six weeks. During his last check-up one year ago, the patient was otherwise healthy. Since then, the patient has not achieved new milestones in speech, gross motor, or fine motor development. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 28/min and blood pressure is 105/55 mm Hg. The patient does not maintain eye contact. The anterior fontanelle is closed. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination is unremarkable. The skin is pink and well perfused. Growth charting demonstrates a rapidly enlarging head circumference. A CT scan of the brain reveals a mass lesion, enlarged lateral and third ventricles, and a normally sized fourth ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic site pathology in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an enlarging head circumference, behavioral changes, and delayed developmental milestones, suggesting hydrocephalus.

In hydrocephalus, impaired outflow leads to an increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume,  dilation of the ventricles, and compression of surrounding brain tissue. Normally, CSF is produced by the choroid plexus, flows from the lateral, through the third and fourth ventricles, and ultimately to the subarachnoid space for reabsorption. The narrowest portion of the ventricular system is the cerebral aqueduct, also called the aqueduct of Sylvius, where it drains CSF from the third to the fourth ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct is the most common site of obstruction that may result in hydrocephalus.

The cerebral aqueduct can be blocked by cellular debris formed from intraventricular hemorrhage, bacterial or fungal infections, as well as tumors of the midbrain or pinealomas. Clinically, hydrocephalus can present with headaches, nausea, vomiting, papilledema, behavioral changes, coma, and even death.



Option Analysis

❌ Arachnoid villi  :
Incorrect: Inflammation or fibrosis of arachnoid villi can impair CSF absorption. This results in communicating hydrocephalus with global ventricular dilation and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient’s fourth ventricle is normal in size, suggestive of a distal blockage to CSF flow.  
✅ Cerebral aqueduct  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Interventricular foramina of Monro  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the interventricular foramina of Monro causes enlargement of the lateral ventricles, in contrast to the enlarged lateral and third ventricles observed in this patient.  
❌ Lateral foramen of Luschka  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the lateral foramen of Luschka causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.  
❌ Medial foramen of Magendie  :
Incorrect: Obstruction at the medial foramen of Magendie causes enlargement of all four ventricles. This patient’s fourth ventricle is of normal size.

questions.text: A 31 year-old woman comes to an outpatient clinic for urinary incontinence over the past week. Since the symptoms began, she reports urinating on herself before having time to reach the bathroom. Past medical history is notable for an episode of transient acute vision loss in her left eye and an episode of left-arm weakness that self-resolved after two-weeks. She works as a news reporter and drinks 3-4 cups of coffee per day to stay awake. The patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 115/79 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respirations are 16/min. Which of the following interventions is used in treating this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Referral for surgical repair of a urogenital tract fistula

questions.solution:
This patient has urge incontinence, which presents as a sudden urge to urinate, resulting in involuntary expulsion of urine. Many cases are idiopathic. However, some medical conditions may cause urge incontinence. They can be divided into neurologic conditions (e.g., neuropathy, multiple sclerosis) and non-neurologic conditions (e.g., urinary tract infections, bladder stones). The patient in this vignette has a history of transient vision loss and extremity weakness, which suggests that a multiple sclerosis flare-up is the most likely cause of her recent incontinence.  

Urge incontinence can be diagnosed based on the history & physical exam. Additional testing, such as urinalysis or bladder ultrasound, can be ordered to identify the underlying cause of the patient’s presentation. Urodynamic studies are not required to make the diagnosis, but if ordered, will show detrusor hyperactivity.  

First-line treatment consists of lifestyle modifications including caffeine restriction, Kegel exercises, and bladder training (e.g. developing a timetable that specifies when to urinate). In terms of medications, anticholinergic agents, such as oxybutynin and tolterodine, are most commonly used to treat urge incontinence. In cases where non-invasive management has failed, surgical intervention such as sacral nerve stimulation or botulinum toxin injection into the bladder wall can be used to reduce detrusor activity.  


Option Analysis

❌ Prescription of an alpha-receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Alpha-antagonists, such as prazosin or tamsulosin, are used in the treatment of overflow incontinence. The condition can be caused by an underactive detrusor muscle and results in urinary retention. Multiple sclerosis (MS), which may present with transient visual deficits, episodes of urinary incontinence, and focal weakness/numbness, is a cause of overflow incontinence. However, patients with this condition typically present with urinary dribbling that occurs as the bladder starts overflowing.  
✅ Prescription of an acetylcholine-receptor antagonist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Placement of a vaginal pessary:
Incorrect: Pessaries are used in the treatment of stress incontinence. The condition presents with loss of urine when intra-abdominal pressure is increased. This patient has none of these symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s history of having sudden urges to urinate and not being able to reach the bathroom in time is more consistent with the presentation of urge incontinence. Pessaries are not effective in treating urge incontinence.     
❌ Initiation of intermittent bladder catheterization:
Incorrect: Intermittent self-catheterization can be used in patients with overflow incontinence to prevent urinary stasis and infection. However, this patient’s symptoms of sudden urges to void and involuntary loss of urine are most consistent with those of urge incontinence. Patients with urge incontinence are not at increased risk for urinary stasis, and self-catheterization is unnecessary.   
❌ Referral for surgical repair of a urogenital tract fistula:
Incorrect: A vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal passageway between the bladder and vagina. As a result, urine from the bladder can pass through the fistula. Surgery is used to treat this condition. Risk factors for developing a vesicovaginal fistula include pelvic radiation and pelvic surgery. The patient in this vignette has none of the aforementioned risk factors, and a vesicovaginal fistula would not explain her previous neurologic symptoms.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department accompanied by his caretaker because of a 2-day history of confusion, headaches, and vomiting. Two days ago, the patient became irritable and started having headaches and eye pain when exposed to bright light. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 137/85 mmHg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. Flexion of the neck elicits an involuntary flexion of the knees and hips. Two blood cultures are obtained, and empiric antibiotics and corticosteroid therapy are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, headaches, and altered mental status, which raises concern for bacterial meningitis. The patient’s physical exam demonstrates papilledema bilaterally, which is a sign of elevated intracranial pressure and is therefore an indication for CT to exclude contraindications for lumbar puncture (LP).  

Bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention to prevent sequelae. Even with optimal therapy, bacterial meningitis is associated with significant morbidity and mortality. Essentially, every patient with suspected meningitis should undergo lumbar puncture (LP) unless there is a clear contraindication. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis helps to narrow the differential diagnosis and direct the antibiotic regimen. Increased intracranial pressure carries a risk for cerebral herniation if large amounts of CSF are collected. Therefore, if any of the abnormalities depicted in the table below is present, a CT scan should be obtained first to exclude a mass lesion or increased intracranial pressure. If none of the above is present, LP can be performed safely.  

The first step in management of patients with suspected bacterial meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and LP. Next, empiric antibiotics should be administered immediately after CSF collection. Corticosteroids should be added for patients in whom the causative organism is not yet known to prevent neurologic sequelae from S. pneumonia infections (e.g. sensorineural hearing loss). After the CSF analysis results are available, the antibiotic regimen can be tailored. If lumbar puncture is delayed more than 20-30 minutes for any reason (e.g. to obtain CT), the best initial step is to give antibiotics immediately.  

 



Option Analysis

❌ Intubation of the patient:
Incorrect: Intubation is required if there is a failure to protect the airway, oxygenation failure, or if the clinical course requires it. This patient has normal saturation and, for the time being, is stable. Intubation is not currently indicated.  
✅ CT scan of the head:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture (LP) is crucial in the evaluation of patients with suspected meningitis. However, this patient is showing signs of elevated intracranial pressure, which increases the risk for brain herniation if LP is performed. Therefore, a CT of the head should be performed first to exclude contraindications.  
❌  Obtain basic metabolic panel:
Incorrect: Basic metabolic panel provides information regarding the patient’s status of metabolism, kidney function, blood glucose level, and electrolyte and acid/base balance. It is often used in emergency settings; however, it is not the most important next step in this patient at risk for herniation. 
❌ Obtain electroencephalogram:
Incorrect: Electroencephalogram (EEG) is often used to evaluate abnormal brain function, typically after a seizure. Although it can be used as supporting evidence in patients with suspected encephalitis, it has no role in the management of meningitis, especially not in emergency settings.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her parents due to a recent episode of seizures. For the past 2 days, she has been sick with fever and headaches. The patient had never had a seizure before, and medical history is unremarkable. Family history is negative for neurological disorders. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is postictal but responsive. She is unable to speak. MRI is obtained, and the results are shown below:  

 

Reproduced form: Wikipedia    
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fever, headaches, and new onset of a seizure. The MRI shows hyperintensities in the temporal lobes, including the hippocampus, which is highly suggestive of herpes simplex virus  (HSV) encephalitis. Due to the significant morbidity and mortality associated with the condition, empiric intravenous acyclovir therapy should be started immediately when HSV encephalitis is suspected.

HSV encephalitis is the most common cause of sporadic fatal encephalitis. Most cases are caused by type HSV-1, but type 2 is also seen. Patients often present with rapid onset of fever and at least one of the following: altered mentation, focal cranial nerve deficits, hemiparesis, dysphasia, aphasia, ataxia, focal seizures, headache, focal neurologic signs. IV acyclovir should be administered empirically in any patient that is suspected of HSV encephalitis, due to the high mortality and morbidity rates. High level of suspicion includes patients with CSF pleocytosis and encephalitis, focal findings on examination, imaging, or electroencephalography. CSF analysis typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, increased number of erythrocytes (due to hemorrhage), and elevated protein. However, the CSF profile can be normal early in the course of the disease and therefore is not diagnostic. CSF polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used to identify HSV-1, HSV-2, and enteroviruses. Identification of HSV-1 in the CSF is an efficient, rapid, sensitive, and specific diagnostic test for HSV-1 encephalitis and, therefore, is the test of choice.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, culture, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are required for further evaluation of this patient. The procedure should not be performed until after imaging in any patient with signs of intracranial hypertension, seizure, or focal neurologic deficit to avoid the risk for brain herniation. However, it is important to note that this patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other diagnostic steps.
❌ Empiric antibiotics:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics should be initiated after CSF is obtained or when lumbar puncture is delayed in any patient suspected of having bacterial meningitis; however, this patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.
✅ Intravenous acyclovir :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive treatment only:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics may be initiated until a viral cause is confirmed. Supportive care is usually sufficient for confirmed viral cases but certain cases require specific care. This patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.
❌ Surgical drainage:
Incorrect: Antibiotics and surgical drainage are indicated for the treatment of brain abscesses, which typically present with headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits. This patient’s imaging and presentation are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis, which requires immediate intervention prior to other steps.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman is in the emergency department following a skateboarding accident. The patient was jumping down a flight of stairs when she lost control and fell onto concrete without wearing a helmet. She had a brief loss of consciousness following the accident. The patient reports nausea,  headache and has vomited twice during the last 30 minutes. Her past medical history is insignificant, and she does not take any medications. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), her pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min, and her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time on physical examination. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Cardiac examination shows bradycardia, but no abnormal heart sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a bruise in the left temporal region. A non-contrast head CT is shown.


Reproduced from Radiopedia

 Rupture of which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of head trauma, loss of consciousness followed by a lucid interval, and subsequent signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache and vomiting). The non-contrast head CT demonstrates an epidural hematoma, likely from a middle meningeal artery (branch of the maxillary artery) hemorrhage.  

Epidural hematoma commonly results from a blow to the side of the head, resulting in the fracture of the thin bones that form the pterion (junction of the greater wing of sphenoid, squamous temporal, frontal, and parietal bones). The pterion overlies the course of the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery, and fractures in the region may injure the artery, causing epidural hemorrhage.



Patients with epidural hematoma typically manifest with a lucid interval after an initial loss of consciousness, followed by signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, vomiting, decreased mental status, anisocoria, and Cushing reflex). Epidural hematomas are diagnosed with non-contrast CT scans and demonstrate biconvex, hyperdense masses confined to the suture lines between the dura mater and the skull. 

Option Analysis

❌ Cortical bridging veins :
Incorrect: Rupture of cortical bridging veins can result in subdural hemorrhage. In young patients, this occurs usually as the result of a fall or motor vehicle accident. The onset of symptoms is usually gradual, with a slow decline in mental function. A subdural hemorrhage is visualized as a crescent-shaped mass on a CT scan.  
❌ Berry aneurysm:
Incorrect: The anterior communicating artery is the most common site of a berry aneurysm. Its rupture can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a sudden, severe headache, described as the “worst headache of my life.”  
❌ Posterior communicating artery:
Incorrect: The posterior communicating artery is the second most common location for berry aneurysms. Its rupture can result in subarachnoid hemorrhage, which usually manifests as a sudden, severe headache, described as the “worst headache of my life.” 
✅ Middle meningeal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Lateral striate artery:
Incorrect: Lateral striate arteries arise from middle cerebral arteries. These vessels supply the internal capsule and basal ganglia and often rupture in hypertensive strokes.

questions.text: A 75-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes, for which the patient takes amlodipine, chlorthalidone, and insulin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 180/99 mmHg. On examination, right upper and lower extremity motor strength is 1/5. The patient has difficulty answering questions and appears to be frustrated by this inability to communicate. The patient is able to speak a few words, but the speech is non-fluent. She is able to comprehend 2-step instructions but is unable to repeat phrases. Which of the following best describes the type of aphasia observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty answering questions and frustration driven by their inability to communicate (expressive aphasia). The patient is able to speak a few words, but speech is non-fluent. The patient is able to comprehend 2-step instructions; however, they are unable to repeat phrases, making Broca aphasia the most likely cause of the language impairment.  

Broca’s area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Efferent pathways from Broca’s area connect to the muscles of the larynx, mouth, tongue, soft palate, and respiratory muscles to formulate speech. Broca aphasia most commonly results from an ischemic stroke secondary to anterior MCA branch occlusion. Other etiologies include trauma, tumors, and neurodegenerative disease. Typical clinical features include non-fluent, sparse speech as well as agrammatism, intact comprehension, and impaired repetition. Hemiparesis (as in this patient) and oral apraxia may occur due to ischemia sustained to the adjacent motor and supplementary areas.  



Option Analysis

❌ Transcortical sensory aphasia:
Incorrect: Transcortical sensory aphasia results from insults to the inferior temporal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech with intact ability to repeat but poor comprehension.  
❌ Global aphasia:
Incorrect: Global aphasia results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, Broca’s area, and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes non-fluent speech, poor comprehension, and impaired repetition.
❌ Conduction aphasia:
Incorrect: Conduction aphasia results from a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. The arcuate fasciculus is the bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech often contains frequent phonemic errors.
❌ Wernicke aphasia:
Incorrect: Wernicke’s area is involved in processing and understanding of written and spoken language. It is supplied by the posterior MCA branch and located within the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. Damage to Wernicke’s area manifests with fluent speech and poor comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech sounds voluminous but without meaning, and the patient often appears unaware of the deficit. A right superior visual field defect may be present as well.
✅ Broca aphasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that lasted 30 seconds. The patient’s partner endorses increased difficulty with ambulation for the past several days. The patient had two instances where they lost control of their bladder without seizing. The patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient appears confused but is arousable. Neurological examination is significant for motor strength of 1/5 in the lower extremities bilaterally. Motor strength in the upper extremities is 5/5. MRI of the brain is shown below. Compression of which of the following areas is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org

choices.text: Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule)
Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
This patient presents with radiologic findings of a space-occupying lesion consistent with a parasagittal meningioma. In addition, there is evidence of urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness, which can be due to compression of the medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule).   

The paracentral lobule is an area of the brain located on the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres that lies in close proximity to the falx cerebri and surrounds the indentation produced by the central sulcus. Functionally, it is involved in cerebral control of both urination and defecation. It also houses motor and sensory innervation of the contralateral lower extremities. Thus a space-occupying lesion of this area (e.g. parasagittal meningioma) can cause urinary incontinence, seizures, and bilateral lower extremity weakness.    

The paracentral lobule is supplied by the branches of the anterior cerebral artery, so occlusion of the ACA results in hemiparesis and hemisensory loss in the contralateral lower extremity and urinary incontinence. Corresponding ischemic involvement of the anterior frontal and parietal lobes results in apathy, inability to accurately identify objects, and personality changes.    



Option Analysis

✅ Medial aspect of the precentral gyrus (paracentral lobule):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Damage to Broca’s area manifests with non-fluent speech with intact comprehension and impaired repetition. Bladder incontinence is not typical for a lesion in this area.
❌ Premotor cortex:
Incorrect: The premotor cortex stores and processes information regarding past activity as well as integration of sensory and motor information for planning of future voluntary movements. A lesion of the premotor cortex would not explain this patient’s presentation with lower extremity weakness, urinary incontinence, and seizure.
❌ Prefrontal cortex:
Incorrect: The prefrontal cortex is responsible for executive functions, such as decision making, judgment, and reasoning; it also regulates depth of feeling. Damage to the prefrontal cortex leads to disinhibition and deficits in concentration, judgment, and orientation. Early behavioral changes include socially inappropriate behavior, apathy, and compulsive behavior.
❌ Arcuate fasciculus:
Incorrect: The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of nerve fibers between Broca’s and Wernicke’s area. Conduction aphasia results from injury or a lesion involving the arcuate fasciculus. Clinical presentation includes fluent speech and preserved comprehension with impaired repetition. Speech contains frequent phonemic errors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the physician to evaluate right shoulder weakness, which has been ongoing for three months. The symptom has limited her daily activities, such as brushing her hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has weakness abducting the right shoulder above 90 degrees on physical examination. In addition, there is atrophy of the right trapezius muscle. The findings are concerning for a nerve injury. Through which of the following mechanisms did this nerve injury likely occur?

choices.text: Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle.
Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection
Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection

questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve, or cranial nerve XI, consists of a spinal portion originating from the ventral horns of the upper four cervical segments of the spinal cord which is then joined by accessory components that arise from the nucleus accumbens of the medulla oblongata.  

These two components form the eleventh cranial nerve, and together, they exit the skull through the jugular foramen. The spinal accessory nerve then courses below the posterior belly of the digastric and upper end of the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM). It emerges from the posterior border of the SCM and crosses the posterior triangle before entering the trapezius. Recall, the posterior triangle of the neck is bounded inferiorly by the middle one-third of the clavicle, anteriorly by the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, and posteriorly by the anterior border of the trapezius.  

Cranial nerve XI is particularly susceptible to injury as it courses through the posterior triangle of the neck. Injury is most commonly caused by iatrogenic etiologies (e.g., lymph node biopsy, neck dissection) but can also be caused by trauma or tumors.  

Injury to the spinal accessory nerve can lead to paralysis of both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. Clinical symptoms include shoulder pain, limited abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees, and shoulder drop. These symptoms may impact an individual’s ability to complete daily tasks, such as combing one’s hair.  



Option Analysis

✅ Lymph node biopsy in the posterior cervical triangle. :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Thyroidectomy with superior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies due to its proximity with the superior thyroid artery. Patients with this nerve injury may notice changes in voice quality but would not typically experience difficulty abducting the shoulder.   
❌ Thyroidectomy with inferior thyroid artery dissection :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery. Patients with recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may experience hoarseness of the voice but not difficulty abducting the shoulder. 
❌ Left atrial enlargement:
Incorrect: Left atrial enlargement can compress the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not the spinal accessory nerve. 
❌ Medial medullary syndrome :
Incorrect: Medial medullary syndrome is caused by occlusion of the medullary branch of the vertebral artery. It results in a lower motor neuron hypoglossal nerve injury in addition to contralateral hemiparesis and contralateral loss of proprioception and tactile discrimination.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter for evaluation of  sudden-onset weakness in the left side of her body that began two hours ago. The patient does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or leg pain. Her past medical history includes hypertension and a 35-pack-year smoking history. She does not take anticoagulants, have any recent surgeries, or have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. Vital signs are temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 81/min and regular, and blood pressure is 166/104 mmHg. She has marked weakness and sensory loss in the left arm and left leg. Non-contrast CT-brain is without evidence of hemorrhage or mass effect. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient suffered from an ischemic stroke, as suggested by the focal neurologic deficits and corroborating imaging without hemorrhage. For eligible patients with acute ischemic stroke, intravenous alteplase (tissue plasminogen activator, also known as tPA) is first-line therapy, provided that treatment is initiated within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. Since the benefit of alteplase is time dependent (“time is brain”), it is critical to initiate therapy in eligible patients expeditiously.

If CT imaging identifies hemorrhagic stroke, thrombolysis should be avoided. In addition, patients who present 4.5 hours after initial symptoms have an increased risk of developing hemorrhagic conversion from ischemia, thus further contraindicating tPA administration. Thrombolysis should also be avoided in patients with increased risk of hemorrhage, including active or recent anticoagulation, gastrointestinal hemorrhage in the past 21 days, or a history of head trauma within the past three months. 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of aspirin and atorvastatin:
Incorrect: Aspirin and atorvastatin are used for primary and secondary prevention of ischemic strokes. Administration of aspirin within 48 hours of stroke onset may help reduce clot propagation and stroke recurrence. However, aspirin and other antithrombotic agents should not be given alone or in combination for the first 24 hours following treatment with intravenous tPA.
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: For patients with high-risk transient ischemic attack or minor ischemic stroke, dual antiplatelet treatment (DAPT) using aspirin and clopidogrel is recommended. However, aspirin and other antithrombotic agents should not be given alone or in combination for the first 24 hours following treatment with intravenous tPA.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin is avoided in the early stages of ischemic stroke due to minimal benefit and the increased risk of intracranial bleeding.
✅ Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: Supportive care may be appropriate in patients who present with a hemorrhagic stroke or patients who present outside of the tPA administration window. This patient is a candidate for tPA.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with facial drooping. The patient reports difficulty drinking coffee earlier this morning, along with drooling of saliva from the right side of his mouth. He had no symptoms when he went to bed last night. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He inconsistently takes amlodipine and metformin. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 106/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 161/95 mmHg. Physical examination shows loss of the nasolabial fold and drooping from the lips on the right side with an asymmetric smile. The patient can frown, elevate the eyebrows and close his eyes. The rest of the neurologic examination is unremarkable. The lesion most likely occurred at which of the following levels?
questions.solution:
This patient with paralysis of the lower right side of the face most likely has an upper motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve (CN VII). Common causes include stroke, multiple sclerosis, subdural hemorrhage, and intracranial neoplasia. Of the choices listed, the cerebral cortex is the region where a UMN lesion can demonstrate such findings.

The motor pathway for the facial nerve starts from the motor cortex, where its upper motor neuron (UMN) travels downwards through the internal capsule to reach the facial motor nucleus in the lateral pons. This nucleus has a dorsal and ventral part. The former innervates muscles of the upper face and lacrimation, while the latter innervates muscles of the lower face and salivation. The dorsal region receives innervation from the UMN of both hemispheres. The ventral region receives innervation only from the UMN of the opposite hemisphere. That is why unilateral UMN lesions only affect the lower part of the face on the contralateral side.

The UMN fibers cross over before they synapse with LMN, which then travel ipsilaterally, supplying the same side of the face. Therefore, an LMN lesion affects the upper and lower side of the face ipsilaterally.









Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral cortex:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Facial nucleus in the pons:
Incorrect: The axons of UMN enter the facial nucleus, where they synapse with LMN. Lesions in the pons usually involve LMN and result in paralysis of all of the facial muscles on the ipsilateral side (including those of the upper face).
❌ Cerebellopontine angle:
Incorrect: A facial nerve lesion at the cerebellopontine angle would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: A lesion of the facial nerve while it travels through the parotid gland would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.
❌ Internal acoustic meatus:
Incorrect: A facial nerve lesion at the level of the internal acoustic meatus would be an LMN lesion that presents as ipsilateral paralysis of the upper and lower facial muscles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a traumatic head injury in a motor vehicle collision. The patient was unresponsive and subsequently had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure during transport. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, alcohol use disorder, and cocaine misuse. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 59/min, respirations are 7/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg. The patient is comatose with downward, fixed pupils and rigid extension of the upper and lower extremities bilaterally on physical examination. A cross-sectional CT scan demonstrates complete obliteration of the perimesencephalic and premedullary cisterns and a truncated brainstem with Duret hemorrhages. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a traumatic brain injury and intraparenchymal hemorrhage progressing to brain herniation. Mass effect from intracranial hemorrhage can raise the intracranial pressure (ICP), ultimately leading to the physiologic effects of hypertension, bradycardia, and bradypnea (Cushing triad). With hemorrhage expansion, central/downward brain herniation may occur.

In central herniation, the diencephalon and parts of the temporal lobes of both cerebral hemispheres herniate through a notch in the tentorium cerebelli. As the brainstem becomes inferiorly displaced, damage to the midbrain and upper pons results in mid-positioned and fixed pupils due to loss of sympathetic and parasympathetic innervation. In addition, paralysis of upward eye movement occurs, leading to the sunset eyes sign (eyes appear driven downward). Duret hemorrhages (due to the rupture of paramedian basilar artery branches) can be seen in central herniation. Brain herniation also results in abnormal posturing due to the disruption of the descending tract typically involved in reflexive and postural movements (which accounts for the decerebrate posturing seen in this patient).  

Option Analysis

❌ Subfalcine herniation:
Incorrect: Subfalcine herniation occurs when the innermost portion of the frontal lobe herniates under a portion of the falx cerebri. This injury does not put as much pressure on the brainstem as the other types of herniation but does compress the anterior cerebral artery manifesting in dysarthria and leg weakness. This patient’s presentation is instead suggestive of central/downward herniation.  
✅ Downward transtentorial herniation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upward herniation  :
Incorrect: Increased pressure in the posterior fossa can cause the cerebellum to move up through the tentorial opening and push the midbrain through the tentorial notch. Patients typically present with nausea and vomiting with rapid progression to a depressed level of consciousness and death. This patient’s presentation suggests central/downward herniation secondary to increased intracranial pressure.  
❌ Cerebellar tonsillar herniation  :
Incorrect: In tonsillar herniation, the cerebellar tonsils move downward through the foramen magnum, causing compression of the lower brainstem and upper cervical spinal cord. Decerebrate posturing is not observed with this lesion. The most common signs include intractable headache, head tilt, and neck stiffness due to tonsillar impaction.  
❌ Transcalvarial herniation:
