Incorrect: In transcalvarial herniation, the brain herniates through a fracture or opening in the skull. This type of herniation may occur during craniectomy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old person is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right-sided weakness. They were eating dinner when, suddenly, they could not lift their fork. Upon standing up, the patient’s right side gave away, and they fell onto the carpet. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia for which the patient takes amlodipine, metformin, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 190/100 mmHg. Physical examination shows deviation of the eyes to the left side. Motor strength is 0/5 on the right side and 5/5 on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of this patient’s ocular findings?

choices.text: Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF)
Lesion involving the right frontal eye field
Lesion involving the left frontal eye field
Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)
Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF)

questions.solution:
This patient presents with right-sided hemiplegia and deviation of the eyes to the left. They likely have a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory stroke involving the left frontal eye field.  

The frontal eye field refers to an area of the frontal lobe involved in visual field perception and voluntary eye movements. It plays a crucial role in conjugate horizontal gaze and saccades (fast eye movements).  

In order to look to the right, the left frontal eye field synapses to the contralateral paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) via the superior colliculus. The efferent pathway from the PPRF passes to the right lateral rectus motor neurons (via the CN VI nucleus), resulting in abduction of the right eye. Excitatory signals are also sent to the contralateral medial rectus motor neurons (CN III) via the contralateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), resulting in adduction of the contralateral (left) eye.  

Horizontal gaze palsy is typically caused by either a contralateral frontal eye field lesion or an ipsilateral PPRF lesion.   

The middle cerebral artery supplies the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere. Strokes involving the middle cerebral artery (MCA) can lead to lesions that also involve the frontal eye field. Clinically, the eyes will deviate towards the side of the lesion (left-sided MCA stroke with right-sided hemiplegia means that eyes will be deviated to the left). In contrast, a lesion involving the PPRF results in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Lesion involving the right medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF):
Incorrect: A lesion affecting the unilateral MLF impairs adduction of the ipsilateral medial rectus, resulting in internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) – a conjugate horizontal gaze palsy.
❌ Lesion involving the right frontal eye field:
Incorrect: Preferential gaze is controlled by the contralateral frontal eye field. This patient presents with an inability to gaze to the right, which is consistent with a lesion in her left frontal eye field.
✅ Lesion involving the left frontal eye field:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lesion involving the right paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: A lesion involving the PPRF results in an ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). A lesion in this area does not explain the patient’s right-sided motor deficits.
❌ Lesion involving the left paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF):
Incorrect: Lesions involving the PPRF result in ipsilateral gaze palsy (inability to look towards the side of the lesion). This patient has left-sided eye deviation (rather than the inability to look left), and a lesion in this area would not explain their right-sided motor deficits.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate low back pain and left leg weakness. The patient has had worsening low back pain over the past three weeks, with pain radiating into her groin. The patient has also had difficulty maintaining poses due to weakness and pain during her yoga classes.  The patient recently had an upper respiratory infection six weeks ago that resolved. The patient also reports falling on her back several weeks ago while skiing in Colorado. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes oral contraceptive pills daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation over the lumbar vertebrae and reproduction of pain when raising the left leg to 45 degrees. Reflex testing demonstrates 1+ reflexes of the patellar tendon and 2+ reflexes of the Achilles tendon in the left leg. The patient has 4/5 strength with hip flexion and knee extension in the left leg compared to 5/5 strength with these maneuvers in the right leg. Which of the following best describes the underlying etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus
Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves
Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies
Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract
Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis

questions.solution:
The most common cause of radiculopathy in young, otherwise healthy patients is intervertebral disc herniation of the nucleus pulposus. This otherwise healthy patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and unilateral leg weakness. The physical examination findings are consistent with L2-L4 radiculopathy, given the associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and a diminished knee jerk reflex.    

The vertebral bodies are cushioned against one another by a ring of cartilage called intervertebral discs. The rounded region in its center is called the nucleus pulposus, and the nucleus pulposus is surrounded by a fibrous ring called the annulus fibrosus. Typically, the annulus fibrosus is thinner posteriorly and doesn’t receive support from the posterior or the anterior longitudinal ligaments.    

Movements that result in forward flexion of the spine can compress the anterior portion of the disc, pushing the nucleus pulposus posterolaterally. Most commonly, this occurs at the L4-L5 or L5-S1 levels. Over time, or with extreme flexion of the spine, the annulus fibrosus can degrade or break, resulting in posterolateral protrusion of the disk, which can compress motor or sensory nerve roots, producing radicular symptoms.  



Option Analysis

✅ Posterolateral herniation of the nucleus pulposus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Post-infectious autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves:
Incorrect: Guillain Barre syndrome more commonly presents with bilateral, ascending symmetric leg weakness. The unilateral clinical findings in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies:
Incorrect: Collapse and loss of height of the vertebral bodies is usually a result of compression fractures uncommon in otherwise healthy individuals. Compression fractures more commonly occur in the elderly with underlying osteopenia or osteoporosis.  
❌ Inflammation of the lateral corticospinal tract   :
Incorrect: Transverse myelitis reflects an autoimmune or inflammatory process directly affecting the spinal cord. Since this pathology is directly related to the central nervous system, symptoms of hyperreflexia or increased tone are more likely to be present.  
❌ Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis:
Incorrect: Neural foraminal stenosis due to degenerative arthritis is a common culprit of lumbosacral radiculopathy in the elderly, not in otherwise young, healthy patients.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following sudden onset, right-sided weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and coronary artery disease. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. Neurological examination demonstrates flaccid paralysis of the right upper and lower extremities, tongue deviation to the left, slurred speech, hyperreflexic deep tendon reflexes on the right, as well as decreased right-sided proprioception. Sensation is intact and the patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following anatomic areas of the brain is most likely affected given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with complete upper and lower limb paralysis, decreased proprioception, and deviation of the tongue with protrusion, suggestive of medial medullary syndrome. This condition often arises secondary to infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery.  

The anterior spinal artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and lower medulla at the midline. The vessel lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord with both penetrating and circumferential branches. Clinical features of medial medullary ischemia include:  

  • Contralateral hemiparesis due to involvement of the lateral corticospinal tract. 
  • Sensory symptoms related to ischemia of the medial lemniscus include decreased contralateral proprioception and pressure vibratory sensation. 
  • Ipsilateral tongue paralysis is the least common but most topographically localizing sign of medial medullary infarction and is due to infarction of the hypoglossal nucleus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Dominant parietal lobe  :
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome results from damage to the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe and is characterized by agraphia (inability to write), acalculia (inability to carry out mathematical calculations), finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation.  
❌ Dorsolateral medulla:
Incorrect: Ischemic injury to the dorsolateral medulla can result in Wallenberg syndrome, secondary to infarction of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. Patients typically present with loss of pain/temperature over the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral bulbar muscle weakness, vertigo, ipsilateral limb ataxia, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Medial medulla:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior limb of internal capsule:
Incorrect: Infarction in the posterior limb of the internal capsule results in a pure motor stroke. Patients typically present with contralateral hemiparesis without sensory loss or cortical signs (e.g. aphasia). The most common etiology of a lacunar stroke is hypertension.  
❌ Dorsolateral thalamus:
Incorrect: Acute strokes of the dorsolateral thalamus typically present with contralateral hemisensory loss. Patients often develop significant pain on the side of their deficit (thalamic pain syndrome) weeks to months following the initial insult.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office due to intermittent heaviness and paresthesias of the right arm. The patient has experienced multiple episodes over the past two months, especially while playing table tennis. Each episode is associated with nausea, dizziness, and visual disturbance. The patient has not had any falls or loss of consciousness. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes for the past forty years and drinks alcohol occasionally. Orthostatic vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates decreased radial and brachial pulses of the right upper extremity when compared to the left upper extremity. Skin over the right upper extremity feels cooler than the left. The remainder of the cardiopulmonary and neurologic exam are within normal limits. CT angiogram is performed and reveals a condition that results in reversal of blood flow through a vascular structure. Reverse blood flow through which of the following vessels is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with subclavian steal syndrome (SSS)--a constellation of signs and symptoms that arise secondary to retrograde blood flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery or internal thoracic artery due to stenosis and/or occlusion of the subclavian artery. In this condition, the affected arm is often supplied by blood flowing in a retrograde direction down the ipsilateral vertebral artery at the expense of the vertebrobasilar circulation.  

Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery is the most likely culprit of his symptoms. Reduced blood flow through the subclavian artery results in symptoms of recurrent heaviness with exertion, paresthesias, as well as decreased pulses and cooler skin.  

Over time, stenosis of the subclavian artery increases in blood flow through the contralateral vertebral artery to the basilar artery, followed by retrograde flow through the ipsilateral vertebral artery, away from the brainstem. Ultimately, this may result in presyncopal symptoms with exertion of the affected arm including lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision. Other etiologies of SSS include Takayasu arteritis, Giant cell arteritis, and thoracic aortic dissection.  

Option Analysis

❌ Right subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), he most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque of the right subclavian artery. This explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm. Blood flow is blocked rather than reversed in this vessel.  
✅ Right vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left vertebral artery:
Incorrect: Reduced blood flow to the stenosed side is compensated for by contralateral circulation (from the left vertebral artery in this case). In this case, there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side (left) to the affected side (right) via the vertebral arteries.  
❌ Left subclavian artery:
Incorrect: Although the left subclavian artery compensates for reduced blood flow in the right subclavian artery, it is not the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Left posterior cerebral artery  :
Incorrect: Reversed flow in the left posterior cerebral artery results in reduced perfusion to the left occipital lobe. This may result in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for follow-up regarding facial pain. The patient states, “The symptoms have become so bothersome, I can’t sleep at night and none of the medications I’m taking are working.” The patient reports intermittent stabbing pain along the left side of her face below the eye brought on by brushing her teeth or putting makeup on. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates reproducible pain with light tapping of the upper teeth. Tapping of the lower teeth does not elicit pain. Which of the following nerves is implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of pain in the trigeminal nerve distribution (CN V). This patient’s pain is localized to CN V's maxillary nerve branch (V2).

Trigeminal neuralgia is a poorly understood condition but is thought to be due to trigeminal nerve root compression. Clinically, this disease presents as recurrent, sudden onset stabbing pain along the trigeminal nerve's V2 (maxillary) or V3 (mandibular) branches, with onset triggered by minor stimuli such as touch, wind, or chewing food. Trigeminal neuralgia is a unilateral condition; however, it can occur bilaterally in usual cases, typically caused by multiple sclerosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Maxillary nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mandibular nerve:
Incorrect: The mandibular nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, provides sensory information to the lower jaw and cheek while also providing motor function to several muscles of mastication. While this branch of the trigeminal nerve may also be implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia, this patient’s exam suggests disease limited to the maxillary nerve branch.  
❌ Ophthalmic nerve:
Incorrect: V1 supplies sensory function to the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, the nose. It is not commonly implicated in cases of trigeminal neuralgia (<5% of cases).  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It is not implicated in the pathogenesis of trigeminal neuralgia.  
❌ Glossopharyngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Motor function of cranial nerve IX or the glossopharyngeal nerve includes innervation of the stylopharyngeus muscle, elevating the larynx and pharynx during speaking and swallowing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate a recurrent right-sided throbbing headache for the past several years. The headache is accompanied by nausea and bright spots in her visual field. The headache usually subsides with rest in a dark, quiet room. The patient does not develop weakness, numbness, or tingling during these episodes. The patient has tried multiple over-the-counter medications without relief. Her past medical history is significant for acne, for which she uses topical tretinoin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylactic therapy for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features consistent with migraine headaches. Patients with multiple migraines each year often benefit from prophylactic treatment–suitable options include beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol and nadolol), calcium channel blockers (e.g. verapamil), tricyclic antidepressants (e.g. amitriptyline) and anti-epileptic medications (e.g., topiramate and valproate).

OnabotulinumtoxinA, also known as Botox, has proved useful as a prophylactic treatment. This medication is injected into the muscles of the head and neck, where it blocks neurotransmitter release from the trigeminal sensory nerve and subsequent inhibition of painful stimuli. Anti-CGRP antibodies (e.g., erenumab and galcanezumab) block the calcitonin gene-related peptide or its receptor,  and are also effective for prophylaxis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Sumatriptan:
Incorrect: Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B and 5HT1D serotonin receptor agonist and is the first-line abortive therapy for acute migraine episodes. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
✅ Topiramate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Dihydroergotamine:
Incorrect: Ergotamine is a 5-HT serotonin receptor agonist used as abortive therapy during migraine episodes. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is an antiemetic used during migraine attacks associated with nausea and vomiting. It is not effective as a preventive therapy.  
❌ Haloperidol:
Incorrect:  Antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol are D2 receptor antagonists and are typically used to manage schizophrenia, psychosis, and bipolar disorder. It is not a practical option for migraine prophylaxis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of her altered mental status, which began three hours ago. The patient is oriented only to herself. Medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, and recently-diagnosed histoplasmosis pneumonia. Her medications include warfarin, propranolol, metformin, and itraconazole. She declined antiretroviral treatment in the past. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength in all extremities. However, the patient cannot complete finger-to-nose testing or rapidly alternating movements. She attempts to get up but loses balance and falls back into the stretcher. CT head is shown below. Her INR is 7.2, blood glucose is 175 mg/dL, and her HbA1c is 9.2%. Which of the following best explains this patient’s presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and an inability to perform coordinated movements. Her CT scan confirms the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke, which likely occurred since the patient was concurrently taking warfarin and fluconazole without dose adjustments.  

Fluconazole, and other azoles, treat mycotic infections by inhibiting fungal 14-alpha-demethylase (a cytochrome p450 enzyme). Inhibition of this enzyme blocks ergosterol synthesis, which is a vital component of fungal cell membranes.     

Unfortunately, azoles can also inhibit human cytochrome p450 found in the liver. As a result, azoles can inhibit the breakdown and cause the overaccumulation of medications (e.g., warfarin, phenytoin, simvastatin) metabolized by hepatic cytochrome p450. Elevated plasma warfarin levels would manifest with an elevated INR, as in this patient's case, as well as increased risk for bleeding and hemorrhagic stroke.  

Option Analysis

❌ Accelerated formation of atherosclerotic lesions:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to the accelerated formation of atherosclerotic plaques within blood vessels, predisposing patients to ischemic stroke. However, the hyperdense lesion on the CT scan suggests a hemorrhagic stroke. Furthermore, the elevated INR raises concerns about a different cause of the patient’s stroke.  
✅ Impaired hepatic drug metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlargement of intracranial mass:
Incorrect: An intracranial mass (e.g. tumor) in the cerebellum can cause impaired coordination. This deficit may manifest as an inability to perform tasks that require coordination on physical examination. However, intracranial masses are more likely to cause gradual, rather than abrupt, the onset of neurological symptoms.   
❌ Embolic occlusion of intracranial vessels:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can lead to thrombus formation within the left atrium. If parts of the thrombus break off and travel to the brain, the patient can develop an embolic ischemic stroke. However, this patient’s CT findings are more concerning for a hemorrhagic stroke.  
❌ Noncompliance with medical therapy:
Incorrect: Medical noncompliance, such as taking more warfarin than prescribed, can cause an elevated INR and predispose individuals to hemorrhagic stroke. However, this patient is taking warfarin concurrently with fluconazole. The latter blocks cytochrome p450, thereby inhibiting hepatic drug metabolism, and would account for the elevated INR.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office because of a six month history of progressively worsening headaches. She has also noticed blurred peripheral vision while driving. The patient does not report any head trauma or associated dizziness, weight changes, diplopia, or polyuria. Past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a bitemporal visual field defect. Laboratory studies reveal a prolactin level that is greater than 20 times normal and cranial imaging shows a large pituitary mass. Based on the diagram below, which of the following visual pathways is most likely disrupted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The optic tracts relay visual information from the optic chiasm to the ipsilateral lateral geniculate nucleus, from where it continues to the occipital lobe and primary visual cortex. The x-shaped optic chiasm is the point of partial crossing of fibers from the optic nerve. Damage to this structure causes bitemporal hemianopsia. Common causes include pressure exerted by pituitary tumor (as seen in this patient), craniopharyngioma, as well as aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery.   

The aneurysm of the internal carotid artery can also laterally impinge on the optic chiasm and cause ipsilateral nasal hemianopia, damaging uncrossed optic nerve fibers from the temporal portion of the retina. Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ A:
Incorrect: A partial lesion of the retina is more likely to produce a focal monocular scotoma rather than bitemporal visual field defect.  
❌ B:
Incorrect:: The optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) transmits visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm, where it continues on in the optic tract. Damage to the right CN II can cause complete loss of vision in the ipsilateral eye (right anopsia) as well as a right relative afferent pupillary defect.  
✅ C:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ D:
Incorrect: Damage to the lateral aspect of the optic chiasm usually results from calcification or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery impinging on uncrossed lateral retinal fibers causing unilateral nasal hemianopia.  
❌ E:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits visual information from the left visual field and vice versa. A right optic tract lesion is likely to cause left homonymous hemianopsia rather than bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman comes to her primary care provider for a general checkup. The patient is accompanied by her daughter. The patient has no active complaints except for minor joint pain in both hips. She sometimes feels sad because her spouse recently died.  She lives alone and follows a vegan diet.  The patient's daughter states that she has noticed her mother struggling with day-to-day life.  It started two years ago with her forgetting simple instructions or having difficulty running errands. Now the patient has reached the point where she can no longer pay her bills.  She has had two episodes of forgetting how to get home from the grocery store.  Past medical history is significant for obesity, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus.  Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 158/108 mmHg.  Neurological examination shows a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 7. Which following should be included in the patient's medication regimen to slow disease progression?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a gradual decline in cognitive function suggests a diagnosis of Alzheimer dementia (AD). Memantine should be added to the patient’s medication regimen to slow the progression of the disease.  

Memantine, an N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) antagonist, is proposed to be neuroprotective and is FDA approved for treating moderate to severe AD. Glutamate (excitatory amino acid neurotransmitter) activates the NMDA receptor in the brain, which is involved in learning and memory. Acetylcholinesterase (AchE) inhibitor therapy is often added when dementia reaches moderate severity. It is generally well tolerated. Side effects include headache, dizziness, confusion, and constipation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Amantadine:
Incorrect: Amantadine increases dopamine availability and can be used in the management of Parkinson disease. It is not effective in Alzhemer disease.  
❌ Vitamin A:
Incorrect: Vitamin E (not vitamin A) is neuroprotective and may slow functional loss in Alzheimer disease.  
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used to treat major depressive disorder, which may present with cognitive impairment and, in severe cases, dementia. This patient, however, does not meet the criteria for major depressive disorder.  
✅ Memantine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines should be avoided in patients with Alzheimer disease due to their depressive effects on cognition (e.g. confusion and lethargy).

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is brought to the physician’s office by her daughter to evaluate gait unsteadiness. The patient states that she often feels uncoordinated when walking, noting that she walks very slowly. The patient has a past medical history of obsessive-compulsive disorder and takes sertraline daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates mild hyperkyphosis and a slow gait. Muscle tone is increased bilaterally. There is a tremor of the right hand at rest which disappears with finger-to-nose testing. The physician notes a ratchety pattern of resistance and relaxation with a passive range of motion of the upper extremities. The physician prescribes carbidopa/levodopa, and the patient asks about any future adverse effects caused by this medication combination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient following consistent therapy?

choices.text: Reemergence of parkinsonism symptoms between doses
Formation of a lace-like pattern of reddish-blue skin discoloration
Excessive serotonergic activity in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hyperkyphosis, postural instability, hypokinesia (small steps), resting tremor, and personality changes (anxiety or depression). Together, these findings are consistent with Parkinson disease (PD). PD is caused by degeneration of the substantia nigra, and disruption of the nigrostriatal pathway, thus decreasing striatal dopamine levels. Treatment of PD involves several medications that increase dopamine levels within the brain.  

Initial treatment often involves a combination of carbidopa/levodopa. Unlike dopamine, levodopa can cross the blood-brain-barrier (BBB), which gets converted to dopamine in the CNS via decarboxylases. Dopamine decarboxylase inhibitors, like carbidopa, prevent the conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the periphery, allowing for more levodopa to cross the BBB.    

Over time, dopamine becomes more efficiently metabolized by different enzymes in the brain, leading to a “wearing-off” phenomenon–where the patient’s symptoms improve when they take the medication, with effects rapidly ending after one or two hours. People also experience the “on/off” phenomenon, where patients experience sudden oscillations of symptomatic improvement followed by a rapid return to rigidity and hypokinesia. Chronic use of levodopa can also cause dyskinesias, which are uncontrolled, involuntary movements. These motor complications occur as the disease progresses, as nigrostriatal neurons lose their capacity to store and recycle dopamine. This phenomenon requires higher doses of levodopa and subsequent over-excitation of striatal neurons.   

Option Analysis

✅ Reemergence of parkinsonism symptoms between doses:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Worsening of impulse control disorder:
Incorrect: Worsening of impulse control disorders (e.g., gambling, compulsive buying) can be seen in patients taking dopamine agonists, such as pramipexole and ropinirole. This side effect is likely caused by the accidental activation of dopaminergic receptors involved in the reward pathway, which plays a role in addictive behavior.
❌ Formation of a lace-like pattern of reddish-blue skin discoloration :
Incorrect: This stem describes livedo reticularis, a potential side effect of amantadine use, which can also be used to treat Parkinson disease. Amantadine-associated livedo reticularis is not well understood but is likely due to generalized cutaneous vascular alteration.
❌ Peripheral edema:
Incorrect: Peripheral edema can be a potential adverse effect of amantadine another medication that can be used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. The development of edema is poorly understood but is likely caused by the redistribution of fluid within the body. 
❌ Excessive serotonergic activity in the central nervous system:
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome can be seen in patients taking MAO-B inhibitors (e.g. selegiline) and SSRIs (e.g. sertraline). Although this patient is taking an SSRI, her recently prescribed carbidopa/levodopa does not increase her risk of developing serotonin syndrome.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic due to 2 months of clumsiness, progressive weakness, and personality changes. She also states that her left hand seems to move involuntarily on sporadic occasions. This patient had been treated with rituximab for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is associated with person and place, but not time. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hyperreflexia and upgoing plantar reflex. MRI is shown below. Which of the following is the likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Venous hemorrhage of the bridging veins

questions.solution:
This patient had originally been diagnosed with non- Hodgkin’s lymphoma, treated with rituximab, then developed neurological symptoms of clumsiness, progressive weakness, and personality change. Additionally, this patient shows characteristic symptoms of “alien hand syndrome,” wherein the patient experiences involuntary limb movement. These findings are characteristic of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a complication of treatment with rituximab.   

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20, a marker of B cells. This makes rituximab a common treatment for B cell lymphomas such as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, rheumatoid arthritis, and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). An important side effect of rituximab therapy is increasing the likelihood of PML. PML is a progressive inflammatory disease of the white matter. PML is commonly caused by viral infection with the latent JC virus, a polyomavirus, that reactivates and infects oligodendrocytes resulting in demyelination and death of neurons. JC virus reactivation and proliferation with chronic rituximab (or natalizumab) treatment occurs due to failure of immune surveillance within the central nervous system.

Option Analysis

❌ Venous hemorrhage of the bridging veins:
Incorrect: Bridging veins can be sheared in elderly patients with head trauma, causing progressively worsening neurological symptoms. Neither the patient’s symptomatology nor imaging suggests any type of hemorrhage. 
❌ Subdural hemorrhage:
Incorrect: Subarachnoid hemorrhage is characterized by the infiltration of blood into the cerebrospinal fluid. Neither the patient’s symptomatology nor imaging suggests any type of hemorrhage. 
❌ Glioblastoma multiforme:
Incorrect: Glioblastoma multiforme is a primary and aggressive brain tumor characterized by progressive neurological symptoms and bilateral tumor infiltration. This patient’s imaging does not suggest involvement with glioblastoma. 
❌ Ischemic stroke :
Incorrect: Ischemic strokes have a sudden onset of symptoms. This patient’s symptoms took several months to develop, making this an unlikely diagnosis. 
✅ Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his parent due to concern about seizure activity. The patient sustained jerking movements in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally for several minutes one hour after waking up. The patient did not lose consciousness during this episode. He is not currently experiencing any symptoms. The parent tells the physician that this is the second episode. The patient was seen by a physician for evaluation of staring spells and prescribed ethosuximide five years ago but stopped taking it two years ago. Laboratory work-up and a brain MRI are ordered and are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of absence seizures presents with clinical features consistent with myoclonic seizures. The most likely diagnosis is juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), a form of epilepsy characterized by absence seizures in childhood or early adolescence, followed by myoclonic seizures within three to five years.      

Once the diagnosis of seizures or seizure disorder is made, the choice of antiepileptic drugs (AED) administered depends on the type of associated seizure. Broadly, seizures are classified as generalized or focal and then further subdivided. Generalized seizures are characterized by the involvement of both cerebral hemispheres with abnormal seizure activity at the onset of a seizure.  Generalized tonic-clonic seizures, myoclonic seizures, and absence seizures are all generalized seizures, and the treatment for each type is specific:    

  •  Generalized tonic-clonic seizures: Commonly used medications are phenytoin and valproic acid, but other medications that are also effective against generalized tonic-clonic seizures include lamotrigine, topiramate, and levetiracetam.  
 
  •  Absence seizures: First-line treatment against isolated absence seizures is ethosuximide. Ethosuximide is only effective against absence seizures. Valproic acid is also effective against absence seizures. Some patients with absence seizures develop other types of seizures in the future (like this patient with JME), such as generalized tonic-clonic and myoclonic seizures. The first-line treatment in these patients is valproic acid because it is effective against absence seizures, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and myoclonic seizures. Lamotrigine can also be used in the treatment of absence seizures.  
 
  •  Myoclonic seizures: the first-line treatment of myoclonic seizures is valproic acid, especially in patients with JME who may also have generalized tonic-clonic seizures and absence seizures.  
 
On the other hand, focal (partial) seizures are characterized by abnormal neuronal firing that begins in one cerebral hemisphere. Focal seizures are subdivided into simple seizures (without impaired consciousness) or complex partial seizures. Except for ethosuximide, all other AEDs can be used to treat focal seizures. The choice of AEDs for focal seizures depends on patient preference, age, comorbidities, and side-effect profile. Generally, the first-line treatment for simple partial seizures includes carbamazepine or lamotrigine with valproic acid. Levetiracetam and oxcarbazepine can be used as alternative agents. The most commonly used medications for complex partial seizures are carbamazepine, valproic acid, and phenytoin.   

Option Analysis

✅ Administer valproic acid :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Readminister ethosuximide :
Incorrect: Ethosuximide is the first-line treatment for isolated absence seizures. Ethosuximide is not effective against other types of seizures.
❌ Carbamazepine :
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is contraindicated in patients with myoclonic seizures. 
❌ Oxcarbazepine :
Incorrect: Oxcarbazepine is also contraindicated in patients with myoclonic and absence seizures.
❌ Phenytoin :
Incorrect: Phenytoin is contraindicated in patients with myoclonic and absence seizures.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician to evaluate facial pain. The patient states she has paroxysms of severe electric-like pain over the right side of her face that radiates from the cheeks and  jaw. She adds that touching the nasal or the perioral region of her face can trigger these episodes. Neurological examination and examination of the head, oral cavity, and temporomandibular joint are within normal limits. MRI of the brain is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has trigeminal neuralgia (TN). TN refers to a chronic pain disorder characterized by severe, brief outbursts of electric-like sharp pain in the trigeminal nerve (V). It most commonly results from compression or inflammation of the trigeminal nerve but can be associated with other disorders such as multiple sclerosis.    

Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic drug (AED) used as a first-line treatment for partial seizures. Carbamazepine carries additional uses such as first-line treatment of TN and as a mood stabilizer in patients with bipolar disorder.  

Valproic acid and lamotrigine can be used as mood stabilizers in patients with bipolar disorder. Gabapentin, commonly used in partial seizures, is also very effective in treating neuropathic pain (e.g., postherpetic neuralgia, neuropathic pain) and can sometimes be used in the prophylaxis of migraine headaches.



Option Analysis

✅ Carbamazepine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Microvascular decompression:
Incorrect: Microvascular decompression serves as a surgical treatment for trigeminal neuralgia. It is an invasive procedure and should be considered for cases refractory to medical management. 
❌ Radiosurgery :
Incorrect: Radiosurgery is another surgical option for treating trigeminal neuralgia. Surgical treatment is used for cases refractory to medical management. 
❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: Gabapentin is a first-line treatment for neuropathy; however, it is not the first-line management of trigeminal neuralgia. 
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is not used in the management of trigeminal neuralgia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up after being diagnosed with medial temporal lobe epilepsy. He initially presented after experiencing unusual sensations associated with loss of consciousness. The patient’s past medical history includes atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism, and end-stage renal disease. He is currently taking warfarin. The physician decided to start the patient on carbamazepine. Which of the following must be performed after starting carbamazepine in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with recently diagnosed mesial temporal lobe epilepsy is initiated on carbamazepine, a cytochrome P450 inducer. Cytochrome P450 (CYP450) is a group of hepatic enzymes responsible for the metabolism of a wide range of medications, including warfarin, oral contraceptives, theophylline, and some antiepileptic medications like phenytoin, carbamazepine, and benzodiazepines (known CYP 450 inducers). Induction of these enzymes results in increased breakdown of the medications metabolized by CYP450 enzymes (e.g., warfarin). Therefore, increasing the dose of the medication metabolized by CYP450 is needed when using an inducer of CYP450 system.    

On the other hand, valproic acid is an inhibitor of cytochrome P450 enzymes. This results in a decreased breakdown of the metabolized by CYP450 enzymes, causing increased serum levels and increased risk of toxicity. Therefore, decreasing the dose of these medications is necessary when using CYP450 enzyme inhibitors (e.g. valproic acid).  

Option Analysis

✅ Increase the dose of warfarin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decrease the dose of warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin is metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes of the liver, which are induced by carbamazepine. Carbamazepine will increase the metabolism of warfarin, leading to decreased serum levels. Increasing the dose of warfarin is the most appropriate management. 
❌ No additional intervention is needed:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine increases the metabolism of warfarin, and thus the dose of warfarin must be increased to maintain therapeutic concentrations. 
❌ Stop warfarin :
Incorrect: This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and venous thromboembolism.   Anticoagulation is indicated. 
❌ Switch the patient to apixaban :
Incorrect: Although apixaban can be used instead of warfarin in atrial fibrillation to prevent venous thromboembolism, it is contraindicated in patients with end-stage renal disease.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department because of seizure activity witnessed by his partner at home. Three hours prior to arrival, he had an episode of unresponsiveness lasting for one minute, after which he was sleepy and confused. He had a similar episode about thirty minutes later. Then, just prior to calling the ambulance, he was sleeping when his partner observed stiffening and jerking of the left arm and left leg lasting for two minutes. His partner reports that he has no significant medical history and does not take any medications. His partner reports that he has been irritable and paranoid for the past two weeks. He has smoked a pack per day for 35 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. He is agitated with intermittent facial grimacing and writhing limb movements. He has a negative Kernig and Brudinsky and full range of motion on passive neck movement. Pulmonary examination is significant for decreased breath sounds with rhonchi on the right side. A finger-stick glucose and complete blood count with differential are normal, and a urine toxicology screen is negative. Computerized tomography of the head without contrast is normal. Bedside chest X-ray shows a central lung mass. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present and associated with the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is in convulsive status epilepticus based on the fact that he has had multiple seizures without return to baseline in between episodes. His partner reports recent irritability and paranoia, and he has involuntary movements (dyskinesia). He has a long history of smoking, and given the lung exam and chest X-ray findings, he most likely has small cell lung cancer, which can cause autoimmune encephalitis and seizures. It results from an immune reaction to cancer cells and is also called paraneoplastic encephalitis. A recent history of chronic cough, dyspnea, and unintentional weight loss would support the diagnosis of underlying lung malignancy and associated autoimmune encephalitis.       

Long-term smoking is a risk factor for the development of small cell carcinoma of the lung. Patients with autoimmune encephalitis may present with seizures, orofacial dyskinesias, or signs of dysautonomia. Positive serum and cerebrospinal fluid autoimmune antibodies are confirmatory. Treatment centers on anti-cancer therapies and immunosuppression.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cough, dyspnea, and recent unintentional weight loss :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Neck stiffness and light sensitivity:
Incorrect: Meningeal signs, like fever, neck stiffness, and light sensitivity, are suggestive of central nervous system infection, which can present with convulsive status epilepticus. This patient has free movement of the neck, no fever, and a normal white blood cell count, making meningitis unlikely. This patient with a significant smoking history and lung mass on chest X-ray most likely has autoimmune encephalitis. 
❌ Injection marks on the skin:
Incorrect: Injection marks on the skin may be present in patients who use injection drugs. Though substance use or withdrawal can precipitate convulsive status epilepticus, this patient’s urine drug screen was negative, ruling out opioid and injection drug-related seizure. This patient more likely has autoimmune encephalitis, which may present with cough, dyspnea, and weight loss if the cause is lung cancer. 
❌ Facial bruising and scalp hematoma :
Incorrect: Acute head trauma, as evidenced by outward signs of physical injury like facial bruising and a scalp hematoma, could result in intracranial hemorrhage that could trigger a seizure. This patient presents with subacute, evolving symptoms with normal neuroimaging ruling out intracranial hemorrhage. This patient with a significant smoking history and lung mass on chest X-ray most likely has autoimmune encephalitis. 
❌ History of epilepsy:
Incorrect: Patients with a known history of epilepsy with reported missed doses of anti-seizure medication or changes in medication may present with breakthrough seizures or convulsive status epilepticus. This patient, however, has no significant medical history and takes no medications. He has a significant smoking history and lung mass on chest X-ray, suggesting autoimmune encephalitis as the cause of seizures.

questions.text: A 41-year-old-woman with epilepsy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for altered mental status and seizure activity. Her partner reports she has been ill with frequent diarrhea for the past three days without fever or headache. Today, she felt weak, and they called for an ambulance. Seizure activity began in the ambulance 10 minutes before arrival. Medical history is notable for generalized epilepsy and gastroesophageal reflux. Daily medications include levetiracetam and omeprazole. She does not drink alcohol or use other recreational substances. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 130/80. On exam, bilateral eyes are open and deviated upwards. She does not respond to verbal commands or painful stimuli. There is no neck stiffness. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Bilateral upper extremities are flexed, and bilateral lower extremities are extended, with rhythmic jerking in both the upper and lower extremities. A finger-stick glucose is normal. Administration of intravenous lorazepam stops the movements. Which of the following tests would likely confirm the cause of her seizure activity?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient is in convulsive status epilepticus based on the presence of a tonic-clonic seizure lasting longer than five minutes. In patients with known epilepsy who are on anti-seizure medication, a cause for prolonged seizure can be a subtherapeutic medication level. In this patient with a diarrheal illness, Levetiracetam level will likely be low and confirm the cause of her seizure activity.        

Missed medication doses, poor compliance with antiseizure medications, poor absorption of medication, and recent changes in medication can precipitate seizures in patients with epilepsy. Additional history, such as substance use, history of overdose, or use of psychotropic medications, may suggest intoxication or withdrawal as the cause for status epilepticus. In the absence of a history of contributory medication or substance use, the differential diagnosis includes acute metabolic derangements, infection, autoimmunity, trauma, ischemia, hemorrhage, or hypoxia. Physical examination may reveal evidence of a specific toxidrome, meningeal signs, an acute-onset focal neurological deficit, or signs of physical injury.   

Option Analysis

✅ Levetiracetam level:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Urine toxicology screen:
Incorrect: Acute intoxication can result in a seizure that may present as convulsive status epilepticus and can be determined by a urine toxicology screen. This patient has no known history of substance use nor any examination findings of a known toxidrome, such as pupillary dilation and hypertension with amphetamine toxicity. 
❌ Stool culture:
Incorrect: Most acute cases of loose stools are self-limited, do not warrant further diagnostic testing, and are likely viral in nature. This patient has a diarrheal illness that has likely led to poor absorption of her antiseizure medication and subtherapeutic medication level. Findings of a low seizure medication level will most likely confirm this. Stool culture will not indicate the direct cause of seizures which is likely low Levetiracetam level. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) culture:
Incorrect: A positive CSF culture, pleocytosis, or PCR suggest a central nervous system infection as the cause for convulsive status epilepticus. This patient is afebrile without any neck stiffness or reported history of photophobia to suggest meningoencephalitis or intracranial abscess.  
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: CT of the head can identify a stroke, hypoxic injury, or traumatic hemorrhage as the underlying cause for convulsive status epilepticus. This patient has a known history of epilepsy with an active cause (i.e. diarrheal illness) of poor absorption of her antiseizure medication.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic because of left eye pain and dryness that has progressed throughout the day. His eye felt irritated when he awoke this morning, but he has not noticed redness or discharge from the eye. With repeated checks in the mirror, he has also noticed that the left side of his mouth is drooping compared to the right and his left brow does not furrow as much as the right. His hearing is intact bilaterally, and he has no ear pain or tinnitus. He has had no recent travel, immunizations, or new medications and resides in Arizona, United States. He has been under significant stress at work. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mmHg. There is no conjunctival erythema or discharge. Pupils are equally reactive and round. There is decreased tear production. He is unable to fully close his left eye. There is flattening of the left nasolabial fold. The left pinna, external ear canal, and tympanic membrane (TM) appear normal. Which of the following additional historical or physical examination findings would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Tingling in both feet and areflexia

questions.solution:
This patient presents with left eye pain and dryness and a left-sided facial droop. He is unable to fully close the eyelid and raise the eyebrow on the left, indicating lower motor neuron involvement of cranial nerve VII, which is a peripheral cause of facial paralysis. Bell palsy, also known as idiopathic peripheral facial palsy, is the most common cause of facial paralysis and is likely the cause of this patient’s symptoms given his lack of history or findings specific to another condition. Symptoms in Bell palsy are isolated to the head, and no other neurologic deficits indicating a systemic or central neurologic cause should be present.         

A focused history and physical examination will guide the evaluation and management of facial paralysis. Forehead involvement is indicative of a lower motor neuron lesion, or peripheral cause. The patient may describe a history of sudden onset facial droop, with difficulty raising the eyebrow, inability to fully close the eye, or decreased tearing. The examiner should test the frontalis strength by asking the patient to wrinkle his forehead or raise his eyebrows. Orbicularis oculi strength is tested by asking the patient to close the eyes tightly while the examiner tries to open them. Procerus function is assessed by asking the patient to furrow the brow.        

Other historical and examination characteristics can help differentiate between the most likely cause of peripheral facial nerve palsy. Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can result in unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, may present with additional history of tingling or weakness in the extremities and with hypo- or areflexia on examination. Lyme disease can present with either unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy. Patients may report exposure to an endemic area, a tick bite, or a rash. The most common type of peripheral palsy, Bell palsy, is idiopathic, though some patients may report a recent illness or stressor. Exposure to keratitis can be treated with lubricating eye drops and patching. Treatment with oral corticosteroids within 72 hours of symptom onset is recommended, with improvement anticipated over the next three months.   

Option Analysis

✅ Lack of additional neurologic deficits :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hearing loss:
Incorrect: Herpes zoster oticus, also known as Ramsay Hunt Syndrome, can result in peripheral facial nerve palsy, with co-involvement of cranial nerve 8 given its proximity to the geniculate ganglion. Patients may describe ear pain, hearing loss, tinnitus, and dermatologic reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus with painful vesicles. This patient does not report ear pain, decreased hearing, or tinnitus and has no abnormal findings on ear exam, making Ramsay Hunt Syndrome unlikely. 
❌ Erythema migrans rash :
Incorrect: Lyme disease can cause central or peripheral facial nerve palsy in patients with a history of exposure to Lyme-endemic areas, a known tick bite, or a target-like rash, none of which are noted for this patient, making Lyme disease less likely.  
❌ Tingling in both feet and areflexia:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome can present with either unilateral or bilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, but typically patients will first notice ascending lower extremity numbness, weakness, or difficulty breathing; areflexia is another common finding. This patient has no symptoms or findings consistent with Guillain Barree syndrome.  
❌ Left arm numbness and weakness:
Incorrect: Ipsilateral numbness and weakness can be seen with central facial palsy, and in a patient with stroke risk factors it is suggestive of acute ischemia. This patient’s forehead involvement indicates the facial nerve palsy is peripheral and not central as would be expected with a stroke.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for right arm numbness and slurred speech. Since awakening 6 hours ago, he has not been able to feel his right upper arm when he touches it. He also noticed that he has been slurring his speech and drooling, with there is liquid leaking out of the right side of his mouth when he drinks. The patient has been using intravenous drugs on and off for the last ten years. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows flattening of the right nasolabial fold and an asymmetric smile. He raises both eyebrows equally well and has a normal eye exam bilaterally. There is subjective sensory loss throughout the right upper extremity and pronator drift of the right arm. An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following should be performed next to confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast
Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without iodinated contrast

questions.solution:
This patient has central facial palsy, as evidenced by forehead sparing, along with the presence of other features of intracranial pathology including upper extremity numbness and weakness. The diagnostic workup for an adult with central facial palsy begins with neuroimaging to help differentiate between the most common causes, including stroke, demyelination, tumors, and brain abscesses. This patient’s history of intravenous drug use and presence of fever warrant investigation for intracranial infection, which is best achieved with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without gadolinium contrast.         

Radiographically, brain abscesses will appear as smooth peripheral rim-enhancing masses with central cystic changes. Other causes of central facial palsy can be differentiated by certain radiographic characteristics on MRI including restricted diffusion (acute ischemia), white matter hyperintensities (multiple sclerosis), or multiple contrast-enhancing lesions (metastatic tumors).   

Option Analysis

✅ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aerobic blood culture:
Incorrect: Aerobic blood culture would help identify a causative organism in a patient with bacteremia caused by a brain abscess but is only positive in 10% of brain abscess cases. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain, with and without contrast, is the preferred diagnostic method. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal fluid gram stain and culture would help identify an organism in a patient with bacterial meningitis but may be negative in cases of localized intracranial infection like brain abscess. This patient’s pattern of facial paralysis and arm weakness indicate a focal structural process, and MRI should be performed next. 
❌ Electromyogram and nerve conduction study :
Incorrect: Electromyography and nerve conduction analyses are helpful in the assessment of muscle and nerve function and can help differentiate between peripheral and central etiologies of weakness. In an adult with acute-onset central facial palsy, and signs of central nervous system dysfunction like limb weakness and lack of sensation, neuroimaging with MRI should be performed to determine the etiology. 
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without iodinated contrast:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in an adult with central facial palsy. CT imaging, though rapidly available, has a lower diagnostic yield than magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), especially when performed without contrast, and should be reserved for patients who are unable to undergo MRI.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of blurry vision. She describes intermittent, transient blurry vision with bending over for the last two weeks, and for the last three days the blurry vision has become constant. Past medical history includes chronic headaches for the past 6 months that have become more intense recently. Medications include an oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 36.7°C (97.7°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/80. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Visual acuity is 20/60 in both eyes. On examination, she has bilateral concentric visual field loss and impaired abduction bilaterally with lateral gaze. She has no nuchal rigidity and no focal neurologic abnormalities. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present upon further evaluation?

choices.text: Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure of 18 centimeters of water (cmH20).
Meningeal enhancement on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

questions.solution:
This patient has fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) given the rapid progression of symptoms with evidence of severe vision loss. She should have immediate brain MRI with venography. Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses may be seen on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) in patients with IIH.       

For patients with a history of symptoms of increased intracranial pressure and supportive examination findings, the first step is to obtain neuroimaging with a brain MRI with venography. Radiographic findings suggestive of IIH include an empty sella turcica, posterior globe flattening, dilation of the optic nerve sheaths, stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses, and slit-like ventricles, though neuroimaging may be unremarkable. A lumbar puncture with elevated opening pressure with normal cerebrospinal fluid composition can confirm the diagnosis.        

Once a diagnosis of IIH is suspected, the next step in the evaluation is to assess if an immediate threat of vision loss is present, which will help distinguish between typical and fulminant IIH. Most patients have slowly progressive disease, but a subset of patients have a more malignant course with rapid vision loss developing within weeks of symptom onset. If there has been less than 4 weeks between symptom onset and severe vision loss, or if rapid vision loss has occurred over a few days, then an immediate threat to vision is present, representing fulminant IIH.  If both features are absent, the patient has typical IIH.        

Patients with fulminant disease need immediate brain imaging and treatment with the carbonic anhydrase inhibitor acetazolamide in addition to temporizing treatments. They should also have consultations to determine if more invasive treatments are needed to prevent permanent vision loss.   

Option Analysis

✅ Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure of 18 centimeters of water (cmH20).:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of intracranial hypertension. An elevated CSF opening pressure of at least 25 cmH20 is typically seen with this condition.  
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis:
Incorrect: This patient is afebrile without nuchal rigidity, making meningitis which is associated with CSF pleocytosis unlikely. With idiopathic intracranial hypertension, CSF analysis reveals a normal composition. 
❌ Meningeal enhancement on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: This patient is afebrile without nuchal rigidity, making meningitis, which is typically associated with radiographic enhancement, unlikely. Brain MRI in patients with Idiopathic intracranial hypertension may show radiographic features such as posterior globe flattening or dilation of the optic nerve sheaths or Stenosis of the transverse venous sinuses on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). 
❌ Use of topiramate:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of intracranial hypertension. If this patient was prescribed Topiramate as a migraine preventative agent, decreased cerebrospinal fluid production would be expected, rather than the signs of increased CSF pressure present in this patient.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of a worsening headache for the past week. One month ago, she developed a holocephalic headache, that was worse with coughing and sneezing, and she had blurry vision. Fundoscopy at that time revealed bilateral papilledema. Visual field-testing showed an enlarged blind spot bilaterally. Brain magnetic resonance imaging was normal. She was prescribed acetazolamide at that time. She stopped taking her acetazolamide two weeks ago because she developed paresthesia, altered taste, and nausea. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/76. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Fundoscopy reveals bilateral disc elevation and blurred optic disc margins which are stable compared to previous ones, and visual field-testing is unchanged with an enlarged blind spot seen bilaterally. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. In addition to weight reduction efforts and headache management, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has typical idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) without immediate risk of vision loss given that the progression of her symptoms has been slow, and she has no vision loss. She is having significant side effects from acetazolamide, therefore, the next best step in management is a trial of topiramate.        

Treatment of typical IIH includes weight reduction measures, headache management, and use of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, typically acetazolamide. For patients who cannot tolerate acetazolamide due to side effects, a trial of topiramate should be considered as an alternative before pursuing surgical interventions. After treatment initiation, patient response should be routinely assessed by monitoring visual acuity, papilledema severity, and visual field function. If there is evidence of clinical deterioration despite medical management, surgical options including bariatric surgery, optic nerve sheath fenestration, or cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedures should be considered.    

Option Analysis

✅ Topiramate:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Optic nerve sheath fenestration:
Incorrect: Optic nerve sheath fenestration can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement:
Incorrect: Cerebrospinal fluid diversion via placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Serial lumbar punctures :
Incorrect: Repeated cerebrospinal fluid drainage can be considered for patients with fulminant idiopathic intracranial hypertension who do not respond to weight reduction, headache management, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. This patient presents with typical rather than fulminant disease and should explore other conservative, non-surgical interventions like topiramate first. 
❌ Bariatric surgery:
Incorrect: While weight reduction efforts, including bariatric surgery, if indicated, are an important part of the evidence-based approach to treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension; conservative, non-surgical interventions, like dietary modifications, exercise, headache hygiene and of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors or alternatives like topiramate should be tried first.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of shakiness of the right hand. For the past three weeks she has noticed clumsiness of the right hand when she buttons her clothing, applies makeup, and uses her touch screen device. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. There are no abnormal movements of the hand when it is at rest. With her arms outstretched, the right hand displays a slow, large amplitude side-to-side oscillatory movement that becomes more pronounced with finger-nose-finger testing with past pointing. She has interrupted saccadic eye movements and a wide-based, unsteady gait. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present upon further evaluation?

choices.text: Improvement of tremor with alcohol use

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a slow, 3 to 4 Hz, large amplitude side-to-side oscillatory action tremor, characteristic of a cerebellar tremor. Supportive findings include nystagmus, abnormal saccades, dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria, and gait ataxia. These isolated cerebellar signs help differentiate cerebellar dysfunction from other causes of tremor. 

The first step in the diagnostic evaluation of tremor is to rule out medication-induced tremors, followed by investigation for resting tremor. When a rest tremor is absent, and signs of cerebellar dysfunction are present as in this case, the patient can be diagnosed with cerebellar tremor. They should then be evaluated for an underlying cause like traumatic brain injury, neoplasm, multiple sclerosis, stroke, or genetic conditions like spinocerebellar ataxia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nystagmus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bradykinesia:
Incorrect: Bradykinesia can be a sign of Parkinson disease. With this condition, the tremor is typically a pill-rolling tremor that is present at rest and is often accompanied by cogwheel rigidity, fascial masking, a shorter stride length, or stooped posture. 
❌ History of albuterol use:
Incorrect: Beta-adrenergic agents may cause tremor and associated tachycardia as a side effect. A fast frequency, low amplitude, bilateral tremor may be present at rest and with movement and may involve other parts of the body, like the head, neck, jaw, or voice. 
❌ Improvement of tremor with alcohol use:
Incorrect: Essential tremor is an action tremor brought on by movement that often improves with alcohol use. However, this patient also has signs of cerebellar dysfunction, which is associated with nystagmus as well.  
❌ Elevated triiodothyronine (T3) level :
Incorrect: This patient presents with evidence of cerebellar dysfunction. Enhanced physiologic tremor can result from an underlying hypermetabolic state like hyperthyroidism. However, this patient also has signs of cerebellar dysfunction and nystagmus may be present as well.

questions.text: A 70-year-old-man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. His partner notes that over the past year, he has been walking more slowly and he seems depressed, without showing any emotion on his face. Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include pantoprazole, hydrochlorothiazide, and simvastatin. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.2°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. At rest, an involuntary movement of the right hand is noted where the patient’s index finger and thumb rub over one another in a rhythmic back-and-forth motion. This disappears with finger-nose-finger testing. The patient has masked facies, and overall, his movements are slow. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a pill-rolling resting tremor, characteristic of Parkinson disease. This neurologic disease is often accompanied by bradykinesia, facial masking, cog-wheel rigidity, a shorter stride length, or stooped posture. Improvement with dopamine supplementation (e.g. carbidopa-levodopa) confirms the diagnosis. 

Patients with Parkinson-plus syndromes may also have similar signs and symptoms to those in patients with Parkinson disease; however, they also have additional features such as early-onset dementia, psychosis and hallucinations, severe dysautonomia, a gaze palsy, or alien limb phenomenon.  

A parkinsonian tremor can be differentiated from other forms of tremor as it is present at rest and improves with action. It may be worse unilaterally.    

Option Analysis

✅ Trial of carbidopa-levodopa:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: The diagnostic utility of neuroimaging early in the course of Parkinson disease is low, especially in the absence of cerebellar signs or symptoms of a Parkinson-plus syndrome.  
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: While CSF testing can assist in the diagnosis of Parkinson disease in research settings, a trial of dopamine supplementation is noninvasive and is often sufficient to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Electroencephalography (EEG):
Incorrect: EEG analysis can be helpful in differentiating epileptic from nonepileptic movement disorders. This patient’s non-paroxysmal tremor is unlikely to be a seizure. 
❌ Serum ceruloplasmin level :
Incorrect: A serum ceruloplasmin level may be helpful in the evaluation of a patient with signs and symptoms of Wilson disease. The associated tremor of this condition is often noted with action and described as wing-beating. This is observable when the arms are abducted with the elbows flexed and the hands pointed towards each other with the arms facing down. This patient’s pill-rolling resting tremor is associated with Parkinson disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who is three weeks postpartum, presents to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness and difficulty breathing. Yesterday, her arm felt weak as she was brushing her hair, which she attributed to carrying her newborn baby. Today, she feels weaker and choked while eating breakfast and has had increased shortness of breath. She has a past medical history of asthma and uses albuterol as needed. She tried using her inhaler for the shortness of breath, but it failed to relieve her symptoms. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with ciprofloxacin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On exam, she has bilateral ptosis, and 4/5 strength with neck flexion and bilateral shoulder abduction. She has 5/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally. Sensation and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 26-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with signs and symptoms of rapidly progressive painless weakness and respiratory distress in the setting of known precipitating factors (i.e., post-partum status and use of fluroquinolone) for myasthenic crisis. This patient has findings of impending respiratory failure from neuromuscular weakness. Her respiratory status should be emergently assessed with bedside pulmonary function testing, to determine the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.        

Some patients with myasthenia gravis may be present for the first time in crisis, precipitated by a weakened immune system, or from exposure to certain medications known to exacerbate myasthenia symptoms (e.g., fluoroquinolones). More often, patients with a known history of myasthenia gravis present with myasthenic crisis in the presence of precipitating factors.        

Patients with Myasthenic crisis present with respiratory distress with shallow respirations, tachypnea followed by bradypnea or hypopnea, and hypophonia, drooling, and dysarthria secondary to bulbar neuromuscular weakness. Use of accessory muscles for respiration or paradoxical breathing patterns may be noted. Hypercarbia and hypoxemia are late manifestations.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bedside pulmonary function testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Arterial blood gas (ABG):
Incorrect: An ABG will typically be normal in the initial stage in patients with symptoms of myasthenic crisis; hypercarbia and hypoxemia are late clues. If there is evidence of bulbar weakness and respiratory distress, bedside pulmonary function tests can guide intubation timing. 
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph will usually be normal in patients with respiratory distress from myasthenic crisis, though it may show diminished lung volumes from neuromuscular respiratory weakness. Immediate respiratory management should not be delayed for imaging. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) magnesium:
Incorrect: While IV magnesium is sometimes used in the treatment of status, this patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with myasthenic crisis. Her respiratory status should be assessed first with bedside PFTs to determine the need for intubation. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While IV corticosteroids are sometimes used in the treatment of status asthmaticus, this patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with myasthenic crisis, her respiratory status should be assessed first, to determine the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation.
