questions.text: A 41-year-old woman with generalized seropositive myasthenia gravis is admitted to the hospital for worsening weakness and difficulty swallowing. She has taken pyridostigmine daily for the past year and underwent a thymectomy six months ago. She started oral prednisone two weeks ago but has experienced hypertension, hyperglycemia, insomnia, and mood disturbance from the medication. She has a past medical history of gastroesophageal reflux disease and takes omeprazole. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 136/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, she has bilateral ptosis that worsens with sustained upward gaze. She is unable to keep her cheeks puffed against resistance, and there is weakness with shoulder abduction bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which additional treatment should be considered now?
questions.solution:
This 41-year-old woman presents with signs and symptoms of generalized myasthenia gravis, as evidenced by bulbar weakness, fatigable ptosis, and painless generalized weakness. She has worsening symptoms and may be experiencing a myasthenic crisis. When symptoms persist despite the use of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like pyridostigmine and oral immunosuppressants in combination with thymectomy, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or plasmapheresis should be considered.        

The most commonly used acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, pyridostigmine, can result in intolerable gastrointestinal side effects. Corticosteroids can lead to hypertension, hyperglycemia, fluid retention, bone loss, and neuropsychiatric symptoms. Nonsteroidal immunosuppressant alternatives include azathioprine, mycophenolate, methotrexate, cyclosporine, cyclophosphamide, tacrolimus, and rituximab.        

In patients experiencing worsening symptoms and may be having an acute myasthenic crisis, IV corticosteroids can transiently worsen weakness. Other medications known to precipitate myasthenic crisis should be avoided in these patients too. These include beta blockers, magnesium, botulinum toxin, paralytics, and certain antibiotics.    

Option Analysis

✅ Plasmapheresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ High-dose intravenous (IV) corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient may be having a myasthenic crisis, and she has not been tolerating oral corticosteroids, therefore another mode of treatment should be used. Additionally, the use of high-dose IV corticosteroids may transiently worsen weakness in patients in myasthenic crisis.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) labetalol:
Incorrect: Although this patient has mild hypertension, it is likely a side effect of the oral steroids and should resolve with cessation of the medication. Furthermore, use of a beta blocker can exacerbate symptoms of myasthenia gravis, and they should be avoided. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) natalizumab:
Incorrect: natalizumab is an immunosuppressant that is not indicated for the use in myasthenia gravis. It is used to treat multiple sclerosis. Escalation of care in patients with refractory myasthenia gravis includes IV immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis. 
❌ Oral neostigmine:
Incorrect: This patient is not tolerating oral corticosteroids and is showing signs of possible crisis, for which a trial of a pyridostigmine alternative is unlikely to be helpful. This patient's treatment should be escalated to either intravenous immunoglobulin or plasmapheresis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of altered mental status. He was working on a construction site when he fell approximately 15 feet from a ladder, landing on his back. His coworkers found him unresponsive and immediately called 9-1-1. Emergency medical services arrived soon after. Glascow coma scale score was 7, and he was intubated in the field. He has no known past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 50/min, respirations are 10/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 156/66 mmHg. On examination, he does not open his eyes, nor does he spontaneously move, he does withdraw to pain. Abrasions are noted on the occiput. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 34-year-old patient presents with head trauma. He has signs and symptoms suggesting an unstable subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) including inability to protect his airway, altered breathing, and abnormal circulation following a significant traumatic head injury. The first steps in the management of unstable SAH are to stabilize the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation and to assess for signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). If increased ICP is present, management includes elevating the head of the bed, hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.       

The initial stabilization of a patient presenting with SAH may include intubation and mechanical ventilation. Intravenous access should be secured along with continuous vital sign monitoring, including cardiac telemetry. Patients should be monitored for signs of the physiological response to increased ICP known as the Cushing triad, which consists of the triad of bradycardia, hypertension/widened pulse pressure, and decreased respirations/irregular respirations.        

If patients have findings consistent with increased ICP, then an ICP monitor should be placed, and medical management should be initiated immediately. Patients should be monitored for any changes in status. Physical examination may reveal fixed and dilated pupils in the case of impending herniation. If increased ICP persists despite medical management, cerebrospinal fluid diversion may be considered. If these fail to reduce intracranial pressure, then, an emergent decompressive craniectomy may be needed.    

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperventilation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 0.9% intravenous (IV) saline:
Incorrect: This patient with head trauma has Cushing Triad which indicates increased intracranial pressure (ICP). He should be treated with intubation and mechanical ventilation, and hyperventilation, in addition to sedation, elevation of the head of the bed, and hyperosmolar therapy with either hypertonic fluids, as opposed to normal saline, or mannitol. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) epinephrine:
Incorrect: While epinephrine can be used for patients with bradycardia from different causes, this patient presents with recent head trauma and Cushing triad, consisting of bradycardia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, and decreased and irregular respirations secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). ICP can be exacerbated by administration of epinephrine. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) labetalol:
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs of the Cushing triad, including bradycardia, hypertension with widened pulse pressure, and decreased and irregular respirations, suggestive of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Hypertension should be treated in the case of a subarachnoid hemorrhage when the systolic pressure exceeds 160 mmHg. 
❌ Trendelenburg position:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of increased intracranial pressure, (ICP), which is treated by elevating the head of the bed (i.e., reverse Trendelenburg position), rather than lowering it in the Trendelenburg position, along with hyperventilation, sedation, and hyperosmolar therapy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a severe headache for the past 10 hours that started when she woke up in the morning. The patient states that she had a milder headache 4 days ago. She has no prior history of headaches. She has now developed, in addition to a persistent headache, neck stiffness and sensitivity to light. She has a past medical history of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. She takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg. The patient is in distress secondary to pain. She is alert and oriented. She has pain with passive knee extension when lying supine with her hips flexed at 90°. Fundoscopy, serum leukocyte count, and CT of the head without contrast are normal. Which of the following additional findings would most likely be present upon further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient, with Ehlers-Danlos, who presents with a severe headache, signs of meningeal irritation and a prior sentinel headache most likely has a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). A non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) of the head was performed to look for traumatic and non-traumatic etiologies and was negative. In the absence of acute radiographic findings of hemorrhage, if the index of suspicion for SAH is high, a diagnostic lumbar puncture may be confirmatory, if it reveals an elevated red blood cell count and xanthochromia.           

CT imaging loses sensitivity for SAH as early as six hours following aneurysmal rupture but xanthochromia may persist for up to 3-4 weeks. Xanthochromia is a yellow discoloration of the CSF from elevated bilirubin that results from hemoglobin breakdown.        

Once the diagnosis of SAH is confirmed, patients can have further imaging with CT angiogram or digital subtraction angiography to differentiate between aneurysmal and non-aneurysmal causes of non-traumatic SAH. Saccular or berry aneurysms within the Circle of Willis are most common to rupture. Individuals with connective tissue disease, like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, are at an increased risk of aneurysmal formation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) xanthochromia:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dilated, unresponsive pupils:
Incorrect: Mydriasis (dilated pupils) may occur due to impending brain herniation from increased intracranial pressure which would be associated with significantly altered mental status and Cushing triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respirations indicating increased intracranial pressure. This patient has normal vital signs and a normal fundoscopic examination. 
❌ A shortened partial thromboplastin time (PTT):
Incorrect: This patient presents with signs of subarachnoid hemorrhage. In this patient it is likely due to underlying Ehlers Danlos syndrome. SAH may also be caused by coagulopathy, in which case bleeding from impaired clotting function will prolong, and not shorten the partial thromboplastin time. 
❌ Irregularly irregular rhythm on electrocardiography (ECG):
Incorrect: Atrial fibrillation, as evidenced by an irregularly irregular rhythm on heart monitoring, is a risk factor for clot formation and subsequent ischemic stroke. This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with SAH. Ehlers-danlos syndrome is the most probable cause in this patient. 
❌ Petechial rash:
Incorrect: Patients with Bacterial meningitis can present with headache, nuchal rigidity, and a skin rash. The absence of fever and a normal serum white blood cell count makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of right-sided weakness. Two hours prior to arrival, he started having difficulty forming sentences and developed numbness of the right side of his face, arm, and leg. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and he has a 25 pack-year smoking history. His medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On examination, he is alert but is unable to correctly state the current month or his current age. He obeys commands. He has no eye deviation but has a right facial droop, right arm and leg drift, and decreased sensation throughout the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 64-year-old patient with significant risk factors presents with sudden onset neurological signs and symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke. The first step in management after stabilization of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation and placement on continuous vital sign monitoring is to obtain a fingerstick glucose level because hypoglycemia can mimic stroke symptoms and can be easily corrected with the administration of glucose.

A plasma glucose concentration below 70 mg/dL may cause encephalopathy and dizziness; tremor; confusion; and even focal neurological symptoms, like face or limb weakness and numbness, incoordination, dysarthria, and aphasia. A careful history may reveal risk factors for hypoglycemia, such as infection, malnutrition, or the use of certain medications (i.e. combination of insulin and metformin, sulfonylureas).   If the fingerstick glucose level is normal in a patient presenting with stroke-like symptoms, evaluation should proceed with a head CT and further investigations for an underlying etiology.   

Option Analysis

✅ Fingerstick glucose level :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) :
Incorrect: Administration of IV tPA is appropriate for some patients with acute ischemic stroke, but it is contraindicated in patients with intracranial hemorrhages and neoplasms. A fingerstick glucose level and head CT should be obtained to rule out hemorrhagic stroke and confirm ischemic stroke prior to administration of tPA. 
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is given for ischemic strokes but only after acute management is determined based on imaging and after finger glucose is first performed to rule out hypoglycemia as the cause of the neurologic findings.  
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: A head CT is an important diagnostic tool in the evaluation of patients presenting with sudden onset neurological symptoms. However, a fingerstick glucose should be obtained first to rule out hypoglycemia as it can mimic stroke symptoms and is easily corrected with administration of glucose.  
❌ Echocardiogram :
Incorrect: An echocardiogram is an important diagnostic tool to investigate for an underlying etiology for an acute ischemic stroke like atrial fibrillation. However, because hypoglycemia can mimic stroke symptoms, a fingerstick glucose level should be obtained first, especially in this patient who is on both metformin and insulin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance for evaluation of sudden-onset left arm numbness and weakness. One hour ago, he was talking with his grandson when he developed a tingling sensation in his left hand and face. He also had left-sided facial droop and slurred speech. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include metformin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 68/min and regular, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On examination, he is alert, oriented, and follows commands. Speech is slurred without aphasia. There is a leftward partial gaze palsy and partial hemianopia. Left facial paresis, left arm and leg drift, and left-sided decreased sensation are noted. There is no ataxia or neglect. Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast is unremarkable. Which of the following should be performed next?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck

questions.solution:
This 70-year-old man presents with sudden onset neurological symptoms suggesting an acute ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA). If an initial computerized tomography (CT) of the head does not show hemorrhage or evidence of ischemic stroke but symptoms persist and suspicion for stroke is high, CT or magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) may reveal vessel occlusion or source of emboli as the cause of ischemic stroke.

Patients may be candidates for mechanical thrombectomy or chemical thrombolysis. Perfusion imaging may demonstrate a penumbra of surrounding viable tissue. If higher-level imaging is unremarkable, this can suggest a TIA.

TIA is defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by focal ischemia without acute infarction. The diagnosis of TIA with documented absence of tissue infarction on imaging is a clinical diagnosis based on a determination that the symptoms are most likely caused by brain ischemia.

When patients have a likely stroke with neurological dysfunction that is persistent, the first step is imaging, typically with CT or sometimes MRI to determine if a hemorrhage is present. If there is no evidence of hemorrhagic stroke, then the next step is to diagnose the type of ischemic stroke by distinguishing between embolic and thrombotic ischemic strokes. If the stroke is thrombotic, the next step is determining if there is large vessel and small vessel (penetrating artery or lacunar) involvement. Echocardiogram may be performed to look for AFib and a source of emboli with embolic strokes.

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ambulatory cardiac monitoring:
Incorrect: Ambulatory cardiac monitoring can be performed if there is high suspicion of subclinical AFib as the cause of ischemic stroke. However, magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck should be performed first to distinguish between thrombotic or embolic stroke once CT rules out hemorrhagic stroke and to guide management. 
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: Echocardiography may show a patent foramen ovale, abnormal wall motion, or evidence of thrombi as the cause of an embolic stroke, but it is not diagnostic of a stroke. A magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA) should be performed first to help determine if the stroke is thrombotic or embolic. 
❌ Hemoglobin A1c:
Incorrect: While poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, as evidenced by an abnormally elevated hemoglobin A1c level, is a risk factor for acute ischemic stroke, it is not the best next step in the evaluation of ischemic stroke. 
❌ Lipid panel:
Incorrect: While poorly controlled hyperlipidemia, as evidenced by an abnormally elevated lipid panel, is a risk factor for acute ischemic stroke, it is not the best next step in the evaluation of ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man present to the primary care clinic for evaluation of poor sleep. He has difficulty falling asleep, awakens early, and has frequent, recurrent, unpleasant dreams. His partner notes he calls out and screams in the night, sometimes kicking or punching, and when it is happening, he is unable to be aroused. He does not snore. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension that is well-controlled with lisinopril. He takes no other medication. He does not consume alcohol or caffeine. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg. On exam, there is no airway obstruction. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be associated with his underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This 70-year-old man presents with interrupted sleep accompanied by frequent, unpleasant dreams accompanied by abnormal motor and verbal activity consistent with REM sleep behavior disorder, which is an REM-related parasomnia. There is a strong association between REM sleep behavior disorder and Parkinsonism. Tremors and postural instability may be present, and examination may reveal masked facies, cogwheeling rigidity, and bradykinesia.        

When evaluating patients with disordered sleep, contributing medical factors should first be ruled out. These can include hyperthyroidism and heart failure. Patients should then be assessed for abnormal verbal or motor activity during sleep, as this helps guide the differential diagnosis. This may be reported by family or friends. If present, and the patient reports detailed recollection of recurrent dreams, consider REM sleep behavior disorder.       

If no abnormal verbal or motor activity occurs during sleep, then patients should be questioned about difficulty with sleep initiation. If present, the differential diagnosis includes restless leg syndrome, delayed sleep-wake phase disorder, or chronic insomnia. If the patient has no difficulty with sleep initiation, obstructive or central sleep apnea or narcolepsy with cataplexy should be considered.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bradykinesia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Iron deficiency:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency is associated with restless leg syndrome. However, this patient’s abnormal verbal activity during sleep, and recurrent unpleasant dreams are more consistent with an REM sleep behavior disorder, which has a strong association with Parkinsonism. 
❌ Hallucinations:
Incorrect: Hallucinations can occur with narcolepsy with cataplexy. However, this patient’s abnormal verbal activity during sleep, and recurrent unpleasant dreams are more consistent with REM sleep behavior disorder, which has a strong association with Parkinsonism. 
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is a risk factor for obstructive sleep apnea. However, this patient does not snore, and his abnormal verbal activity during sleep, and recurrent unpleasant dreams are more consistent with REM sleep behavior disorder, which has a strong association with Parkinsonism. 
❌ Use of sedatives:
Incorrect: Use of sedating medications is a risk factor for central sleep apnea. However, this patient does not snore, and his abnormal verbal activity during sleep, and recurrent unpleasant dreams are more consistent with REM sleep behavior disorder, which has a strong association with Parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of complete loss of vision in the right eye. Two days ago, he had a similar episode of complete vision loss in the right eye that lasted a few minutes and then resolved completely. He currently has no eye pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Medications include lisinopril and simvastatin. He smokes two packs of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2. There is significant vision loss in the right eye with only hand motions seen in the temporal region. On exam, the right pupil is non-reactive. There is no conjunctival injection or eye discharge of either eye. Extraocular eye movements are intact. Fundoscopy reveals ischemic retinal whitening in the right eye, with pallor of the retinal arteries and a “cherry red spot” in the fovea. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
This 60-year-old patient with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking has had 1 episode of acute temporary painless monocular vision loss (amaurosis fugax) and presents with another episode of acute painless severe vision loss in the right eye with physical exam findings of retinal whitening on fundoscopic examination, suggestive of ischemia. The most likely diagnosis is central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Atherosclerotic disease of the ipsilateral carotid artery, which can be seen with carotid artery ultrasound, is the most common cause of central retinal artery occlusion.        

Patients presenting with CRAO may have had prior episodes of vision loss that are painless, brief, and self-resolving. The vision loss that occurs is severe, usually leaving no more than a small temporal island of vision. Fundoscopy will show retinal whitening and a “cherry red spot” in the fovea. CRAO is considered a type of stroke. Risk factors for CRAO include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, smoking, and atrial fibrillation.   

Option Analysis

✅ Carotid atherosclerosis on ultrasound :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent eye trauma:
Incorrect: Retinal detachment may occur as the result of ocular trauma and can cause painless vision loss. However, patients typically report “flashes” or “floaters” rather than complete vision loss in the affected eye.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: Diabetic retinopathy causes retinal microaneurysms and hard exudates that can be seen on fundoscopic examination. 
❌ Increased intraocular pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intraocular pressure is seen in patients with acute angle closure glaucoma. Patients with this condition typically present with acute severely painful vision loss and conjunctival erythema in the affected eye, associated with headache and nausea. 
❌ Contact lens use:
Incorrect: Unhygienic use of contacts can lead to infectious keratitis. However, patients typically have red conjunctiva and mucopurulent discharge.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Witnesses report that he collapsed in a park and developed rhythmic stiffening and jerking movements of his whole body for 2 minutes. He appeared confused and combative when emergency services arrived and was lethargic in the ambulance. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears lethargic and cannot be fully aroused. He opens his eyes to painful stimuli. His nares are patent. There is an abrasion on the tongue. He has no nuchal rigidity. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination is within normal limits. While in the emergency department, he has an episode of convulsions with alternating stiffening and jerking of the body. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents in convulsive status epilepticus, which is defined as repeated seizures without return to baseline between episodes. The most appropriate initial response is to perform an ABCDE assessment (airway, breathing, and circulation, exposure). Given that this patient is maintaining his airway and has normal oxygenation, the best next step is to establish intravenous (IV) access and administer an IV benzodiazepine such as lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam to stop the seizures.        

Acute management of an unstable adult with convulsive activity begins with an ABCDE assessment, with continuous vital signs monitoring. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary when patients are unable to protect their airway. Patients in convulsive status epilepticus, defined as either a tonic-clonic seizure lasting more than 5 minutes or multiple seizures without recovery to baseline between attacks, should be immediately treated with an IV benzodiazepine. Intravenous anti-seizure medications including fosphenytoin, phenobarbital, valproic acid, or levetiracetam may then be administered. Electroencephalography can be used to monitor the clinical response to therapy.        

Once the patient is stabilized, a focused history and physical can rule out secondary causes of seizure activity, such as toxic-metabolic derangement. For patients with a known epilepsy diagnosis, missed doses of anti-seizure medication or subtherapeutic drug levels may be the trigger for status epilepticus.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous (IV) benzodiazepine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: Some patients presenting in convulsive status epilepticus may not be able to maintain their airway and may require endotracheal intubation; however, this patient is breathing spontaneously with an intact airway and normal oxygen saturation. Therefore, the best initial treatment is to establish IV access and start an intravenous benzodiazepine. 
❌ Electroencephalography (EEG):
Incorrect: EEG monitoring can be utilized to evaluate for non-convulsive status epilepticus or to guide the use of a continuous infusion for the treatment of seizures. Immediate management of adults like this patient presenting in convulsive status epilepticus includes administration of benzodiazepines.  
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: Head trauma is in the differential for causing status epilepticus in a patient presenting with convulsions which can be evaluated with CT of the head. However, first the patient should be stabilized with administration of an intravenous benzodiazepine.  
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: Intoxication is in the differential for causing seizures; however, this patient in status epilepticus should first be stabilized with administration of an intravenous benzodiazepine.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of tingling and numbness in both feet. For two days, both of the patient’s legs have felt heavy, and yesterday, both feet began tingling. Additionally, she did not notice she was bleeding after stubbing her left great toe until she put on her socks today. Two weeks ago, she experienced two days of vomiting and diarrhea immediately following a camping trip in the Rocky Mountains. Past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical exam, there is symmetric sensory loss to sharp touch in the bilateral lower extremities to the level of the thigh. Position sense and vibration sense are impaired. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with rapidly progressive ascending sensory changes following exposure to a known trigger in the form of a recent gastrointestinal infection most likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). In addition to tingling, numbness, and weakness starting in the legs, patients may also report blurry or double vision, facial weakness, difficulty swallowing or speaking, shortness of breath, and various types of pain including low back pain, radicular pain, and muscle and joint pain.        

GBS represents an acute, monophasic, immune-mediated polyradiculopathy occurring one to three weeks following exposure to certain pathogens, including Cambylobacter jejuni. In addition to generalized paresis, patients can experience sensory loss, autonomic dysfunction, and respiratory failure. The most common variant is a demyelinating polyradiculopathy, but in some cases, the injury is axonal in nature; mixed symptoms are referred to as acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy. Electrodiagnostic studies obtained within one week of symptom onset can help confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Low back pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intermittent fevers:
Incorrect: Patients presenting with symptoms and signs suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome are typically afebrile as this condition often represents an immune-mediated delayed response to an acute infectious trigger. 
❌ Hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: Because of acute inflammatory demyelination, patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome develop hypo- or areflexia. While deep tendon reflexes may be preserved in the axonal variant, hyperreflexia suggests an alternative diagnosis. 
❌ Ingestion of homemade canned food:
Incorrect: Foodborne botulism can occur from ingesting C. botulinum spores in improperly canned foods. However, botulism typically presents as acute-onset dysphagia, symmetrically descending weakness first affecting the neck and arms, and constipation. This patient’s weakness is an ascending pattern of weakness following a gastrointestinal illness contracted during camping, which is concerning for Guillain-Barré syndrome. 
❌ Increased muscle tone:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms and signs suggestive of Guillain-Barré syndrome, which results in decreased, rather than increased, muscle tone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of clumsiness. For the past week, he has been tripping, and this morning he fell getting up out of a chair. Three weeks ago, he had five days of nasal congestion, cough, and low-grade fever attributed to a viral illness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 122/80 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. On physical exam, respirations are nonlabored, and lungs are clear to auscultation. There is symmetric bilateral weakness with ankle dorsiflexion, knee flexion and extension, and hip flexion. Patellar deep tendon reflexes are absent. Which of the following additional diagnostic findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with rapidly progressive ascending weakness following a recent viral respiratory infection most likely has Guillain-Barré syndrome. The patient has evidence of adequate respiratory functioning; therefore, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a lumbar puncture for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. Patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome will have an elevated protein count with a normal white blood cell count in the CSF, also known as albuminocytologic disassociation.       

However, if CSF analysis occurs very early in the disease course (within 48 hours of symptom onset), the results may be normal. Additionally, nerve conduction studies in patients with Guillain-Barré typically show a conduction delay, and electromyography (EMG) may show abnormal recruitment, an absent H-reflex, an abnormal upper extremity sensory nerve action potential, or reduced compound muscle action potential amplitude. However, these electrodiagnostic studies may also initially be normal. Therefore, if clinical suspicion is high, but results of CSF and electrodiagnostic testing are normal, the patient may be very early in the disease course, and treatment should proceed with testing repeated later in the disease course. Electrodiagnostic studies are typically performed to support the diagnosis of GBS and to provide prognostic information.   

Option Analysis

✅ Albuminocytologic disassociation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis:
Incorrect: A low or normal CSF white blood cell count is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pleocytosis (or elevated CSF white blood cell count) suggests alternative diagnoses, like viral myelitis. 
❌ Normal nerve conduction velocity:
Incorrect: Conduction delay is observed in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome. A normal nerve conduction velocity, especially beyond one week after symptom onset, suggests an alternative diagnosis. 
❌ Myopathic pattern on electromyography (EMG):
Incorrect: The EMG in a patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome may be normal or show evidence of muscle denervation. A myopathic pattern suggests an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ High negative inspiratory pressure:
Incorrect: Patients with impaired diaphragm function secondary to Guillain-Barré syndrome will have reduced inspiratory pressure and negative inspiratory force (NIF). A high NIF suggests an alternative diagnosis, like pulmonary edema or upper airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is brought to the neurology clinic by his partner for evaluation of abnormal movements and forgetfulness. Over the last six months, the patient has had progressive forgetfulness, and he has become increasingly irritable. He experiences involuntary quick limb jerks that cause him to drop items. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. Examination shows minimal speech or spontaneous movement, intermittent myoclonus, and an ataxic gait. A urine drug test, serum ethanol level, comprehensive metabolic profile, and computerized tomography (CT) of the head are all within normal limits. Which of the following tests will confirm the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Genetic testing for a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD), including involuntary myoclonus, rapidly worsening cognition, akinetic mutism (i.e., akinesia and mutism despite normal level of consciousness), and ataxia. The finding on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis of 14-3-3 protein, which is a nonspecific protein released by damaged cells, would support the diagnosis of CJD.

CJD is a neurodegenerative disorder resulting from the abnormal accumulation of prion proteins in neurons. Misfolded prions may be detected through a real-time quaking-induced conversion (RT-QuIC) assay. When CJD is suspected, CSF analysis for 14-3-3 protein, a RT-QuIC assay, and brain imaging should be ordered. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may reveal abnormal signals in basal ganglia structures, including the caudate and putamen as well as cortical ribboning. An electroencephalogram may show generalized periodic discharge complexes.

The cause of CJD may be familial, unknown (sporadic), iatrogenic, or the result of transmission from a bovine source. Treatment is supportive, including use of medications for symptom management. There is no cure for CJD.

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic testing for a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD) and does not exhibit the hallmark chorea of Huntington disease. The presence of 14-3-3 protein on cerebrospinal fluid analysis would support the diagnosis of CJD.
❌ Dopamine transporter scan (DaTscan):
Incorrect: A DaTscan is helpful in evaluating dopamine function in the brain for patients with findings suggestive of Parkinson disease. This patient presents with symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD) and does not exhibit the hallmark tremor of Parkinson disease. The presence of 14-3-3 protein on cerebrospinal fluid analysis would support the diagnosis of CJD.
❌ Consumption of alcohol:
Incorrect: While essential tremor may improve with the use of alcohol, this patient presents with signs of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD), which would not be affected by alcohol consumption. The presence of 14-3-3 protein on cerebrospinal fluid analysis would support the diagnosis.
❌ Comprehensive behavioral intervention for tic (CBIT):
Incorrect: CBIT may help improve the symptoms of Tourette syndrome. However, this patient presents with symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD), and the presence of 14-3-3 protein on cerebrospinal fluid analysis would support the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after collapsing in the park about 30 minutes ago while walking with his daughter. His past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and tobacco use. He is not currently taking any medication. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. Respirations are 8/min and are shallow and irregular, and his oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. On examination, the patient is awake and alert but is not speaking. He can look up and down but not side-to-side. His face appears slack bilaterally, and he has flaccid quadriplegia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of a brainstem lesion, including flaccid quadriplegia, anarthria, impaired horizontal extraocular eye movements, and bilateral facial weakness. Given the acute onset of these symptoms in the setting of several untreated stroke risk factors, the leading diagnosis is a basilar artery infarct. Since this patient also shows signs of impending respiratory failure, immediate stabilization of the airway—with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation—is indicated.

Patients with brainstem lesions may exhibit a range of findings depending on the level involved (midbrain, pons, or medulla). These manifestations may include cranial neuropathies, respiratory changes, altered levels of consciousness, motor or sensory deficits, dysautonomia, and/or cerebellar signs.

The first step in the acute management of an unstable adult patient with a brainstem lesion is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary, and continuous monitoring of vital signs is essential, as brainstem lesions can affect the respiratory centers, reticular activating system, and sympathetic pathways. Additionally, intravenous (IV) access should be established promptly to facilitate the administration of fluids and medications, and clinicians should monitor for and manage any associated elevations in intracranial pressure.

Option Analysis

✅ Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of brainstem impairment – possibly from an acute stroke – which warrant neuroimaging. However, before imaging, his shallow, irregular respirations and hypoxemia must be stabilized.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of brainstem impairment – possibly from an acute stroke – which warrant neuroimaging. However, before imaging, his shallow, irregular respirations and hypoxemia must be stabilized.
❌ Intravenous (IV) tissue plasminogen activator (tPA):
Incorrect: While an acute ischemic stroke is a consideration in this case, tPA should not be given before neuroimaging. Additionally, imaging should be delayed until this patient’s airway and breathing are secured.
❌ Intravenous labetalol:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is only minimally elevated and does not warrant immediate management with labetalol. The priority is to address the patient’s respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and new-onset horizontal double vision that began this afternoon. She has no prior history of headaches. Her past medical history is noncontributory, and she takes no medication. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in acute distress due to pain. There is ptosis of the right eye, which is deviated downward and laterally at rest. The right eye is unable to adduct or look upward. Strength and sensation are normal throughout. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus with abduction of the left eye
Weakness of the right upper extremity
Impaired abduction of the right eye

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of impaired right extraocular eye movements, ptosis, and headache—findings suggestive of a right cranial nerve (CN) III palsy. In cases of compressive CN III palsy from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, a unilateral dilated pupil may also be present due to involvement of the parasympathetic fibers running along the outer surface of the oculomotor nerve.
 

Patients with brainstem lesions can present with various signs depending on the level involved (midbrain, pons, or medulla). These signs may include cranial neuropathies, respiratory changes, altered levels of consciousness, motor or sensory impairment, dysautonomia, or cerebellar findings. A careful history and physical examination are essential to narrow the differential diagnosis.

For example, impairment in eye adduction is suggestive of a lesion in the midbrain, whereas impairment in eye abduction typically indicates a lesion involving the pons. In contrast, preserved extraocular movements may point toward a lesion in the medulla.  After evaluating extraocular eye movements, further assessment for ptosis, pupil involvement, limb weakness, and sensory deficits can help refine the differential diagnosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Right eye pupillary dilation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Horizontal nystagmus with abduction of the left eye:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. Horizontal nystagmus in the abducting (left) eye would suggest internuclear ophthalmoplegia. However, ptosis is not typically observed in that condition.
❌ Weakness of the right upper extremity:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. If weakness were to be present, it would be contralateral (i.e., left-sided) due to involvement of the corticospinal tract, which decussates in the medulla oblongata.
❌ Impaired abduction of the right eye:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. Impaired eye abduction, however, would be more suggestive of a cranial nerve VI palsy.
❌ Dysphagia and dysarthria:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a right cranial nerve III palsy, potentially secondary to a ruptured posterior communicating artery aneurysm given her headache. A lesion producing dysphagia and dysarthria would more likely be associated with medullary involvement of cranial nerves IX, X, and XII rather than with an isolated cranial nerve III palsy.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of persistent left arm numbness and weakness since yesterday morning. Past medical history includes right optic neuritis two years ago with residual impaired visual acuity and an episode of right leg paresthesias that lasted for two months and then resolved last year. Current medications include gabapentin as needed for neuropathy. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/25 in the right eye. Physical examination reveals subjective sensory loss in the left upper extremity and associated pronator drift. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain reveals a contrast-enhancing T2 hyperintense lesion in the right parietal cortex and a non-enhancing T2 hyperintense juxtacortical lesion in the left mesial frontal lobe. The patient is started on symptomatic treatment and intravenous corticosteroids. Which of the following, if prescribed, would prevent future relapses and slow disease progression?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of an acute relapse of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS), as evidenced by the development of new neurological deficits following a period of stable neurologic disability. In addition to supportive care, treatment of MS should include high-dose corticosteroids and disease-modifying therapy, like the monoclonal antibody natalizumab, to minimize future relapses and slow disease progression.

Similar treatment strategies are used to treat relapsing-remitting and primary progressive MS. These include symptomatic treatment, injectable immunomodulators, and oral and intravenous immunosuppressants. For patients who do not tolerate corticosteroids for acute attacks, plasmapheresis serves as an alternative treatment. Symptomatic management includes medications like muscle relaxants for spasticity or stimulants for fatigue, as well as physical or occupational therapy. Patients may benefit from the use of orthotics, cognitive behavioral therapy, or alternative therapies.

Disease-modifying agents include immunomodulatory and immunosuppressive therapies. The selection depends on the type of MS, mode of administration, side effect profile, and patient preferences. Immunosuppressants are associated with an increased risk of opportunistic infections, cancer, and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Natalizumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dalfampridine:
Incorrect: Dalfampridine may improve symptoms like the speed of walking in patients with multiple sclerosis; however, it is not a disease-modifying medication like natalizumab that will prevent future relapses and slow disease progression.
❌ Baclofen:
Incorrect: Baclofen may be used as a symptomatic treatment for spasticity related to multiple sclerosis, but it does not prevent future relapses or slow disease progression.
❌ Oral corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While high-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used to treat acute relapses, oral corticosteroids are not effective in preventing future multiple sclerosis relapses. Steroid-sparing immunomodulatory therapy is preferred.
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate may be used in rare cases as a disease-modifying agent, but it is not considered first- or second-line therapy for preventing multiple sclerosis relapses. Natalizumab would be preferred.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness. For the past year, he has experienced episodes of generalized weakness in his arms and legs after exercise, lasting for hours to days at a time. In between episodes, he experiences no weakness. There are no associated sensory changes. His past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medications. The patient’s biological mother and maternal grandmother have experienced similar symptoms, and they have noted that alcohol use can trigger these episodes of weakness. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. General and neurological examinations are normal. Which of the following additional pieces of information regarding this patient’s history or examination is most appropriate to obtain at this time?

choices.text: Relation of symptoms to food intake
Shortness of breath or chest pain with exercise

questions.solution:
This patient’s episodic limb weakness with an unremarkable neurological examination between episodes raises concern for hypokalemic periodic paralysis, especially given the family history of similar symptoms. To differentiate between the hereditary causes of muscle lesions, it is important to assess the timing and triggers of symptoms. To distinguish between hypo- and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis, it is important to determine whether symptoms are triggered by carbohydrate- or potassium-rich foods.         

Patients with muscle disease may present with weakness of the limbs and/or bulbar and respiratory musculature, and this may occasionally be accompanied by pain. In later stages, muscle atrophy may be apparent. Depending on the pattern of weakness, either proximal or distal muscles may be more affected, but sensation remains intact in purely muscle disorders.       

The initial evaluation of a stable patient suspected of having a muscle disease, and who has not been critically ill recently, should include a detailed family history, as hereditary causes may be identified. Additionally, assessing the timing and pattern of weakness can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Episodic symptoms occurring in response to specific triggers suggest a periodic paralysis as opposed to a persistent, progressive condition, like a muscular dystrophy (e.g., Becker muscular dystrophy, myotonic dystrophy type 1).    

Option Analysis

✅ Relation of symptoms to food intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Use of a statin:
Incorrect: This patient’s family history of similar symptoms suggests a hereditary etiology, like a periodic paralysis. In contrast, statin-induced myopathy is a nonhereditary cause of muscle weakness. Additionally, this patient’s past medical history does not include a diagnosis warranting statin therapy, making this diagnosis unlikely.  
❌ Presence of facial rash:
Incorrect: While inflammatory myopathies are on the differential for an individual with weakness, this patient’s family history of similar symptoms suggests a hereditary etiology, like a periodic paralysis, which typically worsens after consuming carbohydrate- or potassium-rich foods. 
❌ Shortness of breath or chest pain with exercise:
Incorrect: Muscular dystrophies, which could involve cardiomyopathy and present with dyspnea or chest pain on exertion, are on the differential for patients with weakness and a positive family history. However, the worsening of symptoms with alcohol use is more suggestive a periodic paralysis, which is often associated with food triggers. 
❌ Difficulty loosening grip  :
Incorrect: Myotonic dystrophy, which can present with grip myotonia, is on the differential for patients with weakness and a positive family history. However, the worsening of symptoms with alcohol use suggests a periodic paralysis, which is typically exacerbated by the consumption of carbohydrate- or potassium-rich foods.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents for an annual wellness examination. Her medical history is significant for well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, treated with metformin, and depression, for which she sees a therapist. She follows a vegetarian diet and uses tobacco. On review of systems, she reports worsening double vision over the past year but has not experienced any eye trauma. The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. Examination reveals horizontal diplopia that resolves when she closes her left eye and when reading the eye chart through a pinhole using her left eye. Fundoscopy shows clouding of the left lens. Which aspect of her history most likely increased her risk of developing this condition?
questions.solution:
This 70-year-old patient’s monocular horizontal diplopia is most likely due to a cataract, as evidenced by the lens opacity and improved vision with the pinhole exam. Her advanced age, diabetes mellitus, and tobacco use increased her risk of developing this condition. Other risk factors include sunlight exposure and corticosteroid use.

For patients with diplopia, or double vision, whether horizontal or vertical, the first step is to ask if it improves when one eye is closed. If it does, the diplopia is monocular and suggests an issue with the eye itself. The next step is a physical examination beginning with the pinhole exam, in which the patient views an eye chart with the affected eye through a pinhole. If the diplopia improves, a fundoscopic examination can assess for lens opacity. If present, the patient has a cataract. In the absence of a lens opacity, the patient likely has a refractive error, such as hyperopia, myopia, or astigmatism.

If a patient with monocular diplopia does not report improved vision with the pinhole exam, the likely cause is macular disease, such as macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, or uveitis.

Option Analysis

✅ Advanced age:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a common risk factor for cataracts, and her blood pressure is not significantly elevated. Age-related (also known as “senile”) cataracts are the most common type.
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: Cataracts are only slightly more common in women, at a ratio of 1:1.3. Advanced age is the greatest risk factor.
❌ Vegetarian diet:
Incorrect: While a diet poor in essential nutrients and antioxidants has been shown to increase the risk of developing cataracts, a plant-based diet does not increase a patient's risk. Advanced age is the primary risk factor.
❌ Depression:
Incorrect: There is no evidence that depression independently increases cataract risk. While vision loss may contribute to a depressed mood, this patient's advanced age is the key risk factor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of double vision. For the past month, she has experienced worsening horizontal and vertical double vision that improves when one eye is closed. There is no associated facial weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking or swallowing. She has no past medical history and takes no medication. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. On exam, she exhibits bilateral proptosis, lid lag, lid retraction, and conjunctival injection. There is slight swelling of the anterior neck, and fine tremors are noted in her hands. Facial sensation is intact. Which of the following additional tests will most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy, including binocular horizontal and vertical diplopia accompanied by external ocular findings such as proptosis, lid lag, lid retraction, and conjunctival injection, as well as a palpable goiter, fine tremor, and a lack of facial numbness. The presence of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor antibodies would confirm the diagnosis.

Binocular vertical diplopia alone, especially when accompanied by a head tilt, suggests a cranial nerve (CN) IV palsy, whereas bilateral horizontal diplopia alone suggests either a CN III or VI palsy. In patients with both vertical and horizontal diplopia, the presence of external ocular findings can indicate either thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy or cavernous sinus syndrome, for which TSH receptor antibodies and neuroimaging are helpful.

In the absence of external ocular findings, the differential diagnosis includes the Miller-Fisher variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome, for which cerebrospinal fluid analysis can be diagnostic, or myasthenia gravis, for which antibody testing, electromyography, an ice test, or a tensilon test may be useful.

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid stimulating hormone receptor antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acetylcholine receptor-binding antibodies:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis can present with intermittent, fatigable diplopia due to antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor. However, the external ocular findings here are more suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid protein level:
Incorrect: Demyelinating disease, such as multiple sclerosis or acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, may cause vertical and/or horizontal diplopia. However, these conditions would not produce the external ocular findings observed in this patient, which are more suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid opening pressure:
Incorrect: Increased intracranial pressure can cause horizontal diplopia due to bilateral abducens nerve palsies, but it does not explain the combination of vertical and horizontal diplopia along with the external ocular findings seen in this case. This presentation is more consistent with thyroid ophthalmopathy.
❌ Hemoglobin A1c level:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can cause cranial nerve palsies, leading to monocular horizontal or vertical diplopia or binocular horizontal diplopia. However, this patient does not have a known history of diabetes, and her external ocular findings, together with the history of binocular horizontal and vertical diplopia, suggest thyroid ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old farmer presents to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness. He has noticed difficulty chewing, swallowing, and lifting equipment for the past two days. He endorses dry eyes, dry mouth, and constipation. Today, he developed shortness of breath. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. On exam, he appears alert with bilateral ptosis, hypophonic and dysarthric speech, nasal flaring, and weakness with bilateral shoulder abduction. Lower extremity strength and sensation appear normal throughout. Which of the following details is most important to obtain next?

choices.text: History of fluctuating or nonfluctuating symptoms throughout the day

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of botulism as evidenced by painless and progressive weakness, dyspnea, and constipation. Patients with botulism experience nonfluctuating weakness that starts in the face and spreads caudally — ultimately affecting the muscles of respiration and digestion. Patients may also demonstrate signs of dysautonomia.

Patients with neuromuscular junction disorders often present with painless muscle weakness, ocular symptoms like double vision, or bulbar symptoms affecting speech or swallowing. Examination may reveal cranial nerve impairment (e.g. ptosis, ophthalmoplegia, or facial muscle weakness) as well as neck and proximal limb weakness with intact sensation. Initial laboratory testing, such as a complete blood count (CBC), metabolic panel, creatine kinase (CK), and thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), is usually normal.

The first step in evaluating a stable patient with a suspected neuromuscular junction disorder is to assess for fluctuations in weakness, as this helps direct further neurodiagnostic evaluation. Symptoms that worsen with repetitive use suggest myasthenia gravis, while symptoms that improve with repeated use suggest Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. Nonfluctuating weakness is seen in both botulism and organophosphate toxicity. The character of associated gastrointestinal dysfunction can differentiate between the two as botulism presents with constipation, whereas exposure to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors results in nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Option Analysis

✅ History of fluctuating or nonfluctuating symptoms throughout the day:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of malignancy:
Incorrect: While a history of malignancy can be important if Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is suspected, clarifying whether the weakness fluctuates is immediately more useful in guiding the differential diagnosis and additional diagnostics. Determining if the weakness fluctuates helps differentiate nonfluctuating conditions, like botulism or organophosphate toxicity, from fluctuating conditions, such as Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome and myasthenia gravis.
❌ Exposure to pesticides:
Incorrect: Painless weakness is best differentiated based on whether it fluctuates, which narrows the differential diagnosis and guides next steps. Both organophosphate poisoning and botulism can cause nonfluctuating weakness, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome and myasthenia gravis are more commonly associated with fluctuating weakness.
❌ Family history of weakness:
Incorrect: A family history is important to obtain in the evaluation of a patient with weakness. However, the acute onset of painless weakness is more concerning for a nonhereditary neuromuscular junction disorder. Fluctuation (or lack thereof) remains the more critical next point to clarify in order to narrow the differential diagnosis.
❌ Substance use history:
Incorrect: While slurred speech and ptosis can appear in acute intoxication, the constellation of bulbar symptoms, respiratory compromise, and autonomic dysfunction points more towards botulism. Confirming the pattern of weakness (fluctuating vs. nonfluctuating) is key to narrowing the differential diagnosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. For the past six months, the patient has felt unsteady, and his partner has noticed some cognitive decline. Past medical history includes hyperlipidemia treated with simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is alert and expressive. Strength and tone are normal in all four extremities. Gait initiation is hesitant, and he walks with a forward-bent posture, taking short, shuffling steps. There is difficulty with turning – the patient's head, trunk, and pelvis rotate as a single unit. Arm swing is normal. Which additional historical finding is most likely to be present?

choices.text: A family history of similar symptoms

questions.solution:
This patient presents with unsteadiness and falls. The gait pattern resembles a Parkinsonian gait, characterized by a forward-bent torso, hesitation with gait initiation, short, shuffling steps, and turning en bloc (meaning that the head, trunk, and pelvis move together as one unit without independent rotation). Without the associated rigidity, bradykinesia, and decreased arm swing of Parkinson disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) should be considered. NPH can feature urinary urgency, frequency, and incontinence due to reduced central inhibition of the detrusor muscle.

Patients may experience gait dysfunction because of motor weakness, sensory loss, poor coordination, or a movement disorder. These issues can result in various gait patterns, including spastic, stomping, steppage, ataxic, and Parkinsonian gait. Assessing the pattern of gait dysfunction helps narrow the differential diagnosis and direct further evaluation.

Option Analysis

✅ Urinary urgency, frequency, and incontinence:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ A pill-rolling tremor at rest:
Incorrect: This patient presents with Parkinsonian gait and cognitive decline. The absence of rigidity, bradykinesia, and decreased arm swing suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) over Parkinson disease. Thus, instead of a pill-rolling tremor, this patient would more likely experience urinary urgency, frequency, and incontinence due to reduced central inhibition of the detrusor muscle.
❌ Excessive alcohol use:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a Parkinsonian gait pattern rather than the ataxic gait pattern seen in alcohol-induced cerebellar degeneration. In the absence of rigidity, bradykinesia, and decreased arm swing, normal pressure hydrocephalus is more likely and may feature urinary dysfunction due to reduced central inhibition of the detrusor muscle.
❌ A family history of similar symptoms:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a Parkinsonian gait pattern rather than the ataxic or steppage gait patterns associated with genetic disorders. In the absence of rigidity, bradykinesia, and decreased arm swing, normal pressure hydrocephalus is more likely and can feature urinary dysfunction due to reduced central inhibition of the detrusor muscle.
❌ Syphilis infection:
Incorrect: This patient presents with a Parkinsonian gait pattern rather than the stomping gait pattern associated with tabes dorsalis (locomotor ataxia). In the absence of rigidity, bradykinesia, and decreased arm swing, normal pressure hydrocephalus is more likely and can feature urinary dysfunction due to reduced central inhibition of the detrusor muscle.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of left-hand numbness and tingling. The patient noticed a prickly sensation over the fourth and fifth fingers during prolonged violin practice sessions, which sometimes affects her ability to hold the neck of the instrument. Past medical history is noncontributory, and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. There is weakness in the left fourth and fifth fingers with abduction, adduction, and flexion, with slight weakness in wrist flexion. Froment sign is positive. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Nerve conduction velocity over the cubital tunnel
Plain radiograph of the left elbow
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine
Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of compressive ulnar neuropathy at the elbow, as evidenced by decreased hand grip, along with numbness, tingling, and pain over the fourth and fifth fingers. A nerve conduction study can confirm the diagnosis.

Compressive neuropathies occur due to mechanical entrapment of peripheral nerves, resulting in paresthesias, pain, or weakness. Patients typically describe specific patterns of numbness, tingling, pain, or difficulty with specific motor tasks, depending on the site of the injury.

A focused history and physical examination are often sufficient to diagnose specific mononeuropathy. However, additional tests can help confirm the suspected diagnosis, such as a focused nerve conduction test or electromyography. In some cases, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or ultrasonography can be used to localize the lesion or identify the underlying cause. Mononeuropathies can occur from conditions like diabetes and hypothyroidism, and basic laboratory tests can be useful in these cases.   

Option Analysis

✅ Nerve conduction velocity over the cubital tunnel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Plain radiograph of the left elbow:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of ulnar neuropathy, for which plain radiographs are of low diagnostic yield. A nerve conduction study is more likely to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of an ulnar neuropathy, for which an MRI of the elbow or a nerve conduction study may be helpful. However, without other signs of brachial plexopathy, neuroimaging of the cervical spine is unlikely to confirm an underlying diagnosis.
❌ Serum anti-nuclear antibody (ANA) level:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of an ulnar compressive neuropathy, likely secondary to repetitive use of the elbow while playing the violin. Although autoimmune conditions, which are often associated with an elevated ANA level, can cause neuropathies, this is an unlikely cause for this patient’s condition.
❌ Serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of an ulnar compressive neuropathy. Pregnancy is a risk factor for compressive neuropathies, but a nerve conduction study is more likely to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of frequent falls. For several years, the patient has experienced gradually progressive numbness and tingling in both feet, and for the past year, the patient has felt increasingly unsteady. Past medical history is significant for gastroesophageal reflux disease managed with omeprazole and over-the-counter antacids. The patient follows a vegan diet. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. Proprioception and vibration are impaired. There is mild weakness with ankle plantar and dorsiflexion bilaterally. The patient has hyperreflexia and a wide-based gait. Which of the following findings would be expected on workup?

choices.text: Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with symptoms and findings concerning for polyneuropathy, including weakness, ataxia, and progressive, bilateral paresthesias. Given the later age of onset, the slowly progressive nature of the symptoms, and the historical clues (e.g., vegan diet, antacid use), vitamin B12 deficiency is the most likely diagnosis. A low vitamin B12 level is expected.

Polyneuropathies are associated with demyelination or axonal injury of multiple peripheral nerves. Possible etiologies include hereditary and acquired conditions. A family history of similar, slowly progressive symptoms suggests a hereditary cause. In contrast, rapidly progressive symptoms without a family history may indicate an acquired cause such as Guillain-Barré syndrome or critical illness polyneuropathy. Symptoms progressing over months to years in the absence of a family history suggest acquired causes like diabetic neuropathy, alcoholic neuropathy, or vitamin B12 deficiency.

In addition to the characteristics above, the pattern of symptoms and physical exam findings may point to a specific diagnosis and can guide additional testing. This can include measuring vitamin B12 levels for deficiency, hemoglobin A1c for diabetic neuropathy, CSF analysis for Guillain-Barré syndrome, genetic testing for Friedreich ataxia or Charcot-Marie-Tooth type 1a, and VLCFA levels for conditions like adrenomyeloneuropathy.

Option Analysis

✅ Low vitamin B12 level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Frataxin gene mutation:
Incorrect: A mutation in the Frataxin gene is associated with Fredrich ataxia. However, a hereditary cause like Friedrich ataxia is unlikely in an older adult, as it typically presents in childhood or adolescence. Additionally, a vegan diet and frequent use of antacids are risk factors for vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ PMP22 duplication:
Incorrect: A PMP22 duplication is associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease type 1a (CMT1A). CMT1A typically has an onset in childhood or adolescence and is often associated with pes cavus and hammertoes bilaterally. This patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ Albuminocytologic dissociation in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is associated with albuminocytologic dissociation in the CSF. However, GBS tends to feature rapidly progressive, ascending symptoms. This patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency.
❌ Elevated hemoglobin A1c:
Incorrect: The patient’s history of slowly progressive sensory changes, weakness, and ataxia, along with the diet and medication history, suggests vitamin B12 deficiency. Even apart from the absence of long-standing poor glucose control, diabetic neuropathy typically presents with burning pain and sensory loss in a stocking-glove distribution.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness for the past six months. The patient has noticed difficulty getting out of a chair and using his hands. More recently, the patient has been choking while eating. The patient has not seen a physician in many years and does not take any daily medications. There is no history of substance use. Review of systems includes unintentional weight loss. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears thin with breathy, hypernasal, slow, slurred speech. There is tongue atrophy and fasciculations. Generalized weakness, muscle atrophy, spasticity, and hyperreflexia are present. An electromyogram reveals fibrillation and fasciculation potentials with abnormal recruitment. Which type of speech dysfunction is most commonly associated with the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with breathy, hypernasal, slow speech, along with tongue atrophy and fasciculations, which are characteristic of flaccid dysarthria. This can be seen in individuals with motor neuron disease, specifically amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

Impaired swallowing or motor speech can occur in various neurological and non-neurological conditions. Historical and physical examination findings help determine whether the primary issue is dysphagia or dysarthria, as well as the specific subtype. As with many movement disorders, the language used by clinicians to describe the exact speech difficulty plays a key role in differentiating the various types of dysarthria.   

Option Analysis

✅ Flaccid dysarthria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypokinetic dysarthria:
Incorrect: Hypokinetic dysarthria is typical of parkinsonism. This patient’s breathy, hypernasal, slow speech accompanied by tongue atrophy and fasciculations is characteristic of flaccid dysarthria, a common feature of motor neuron disease, specifically amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
❌ Hyperkinetic dysarthria:
Incorrect: Hyperkinetic dysarthria is associated with Huntington disease or Tourette syndrome. This patient’s breathy, hypernasal, slow speech accompanied by tongue atrophy and fasciculations is characteristic of flaccid dysarthria, a common feature of motor neuron disease, specifically amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
❌ Spastic dysarthria:
Incorrect: This patient’s breathy, hypernasal, slow speech accompanied by tongue atrophy and fasciculations is characteristic of flaccid dysarthria, a common feature of motor neuron disease. Spastic dysarthria can also occur in motor neuron disease, but the speech pattern is harsh and strained, and there is typically no tongue atrophy or fasciculations.
❌ Ataxic dysarthria:
Incorrect: Ataxic dysarthria is characteristic of cerebellar dysfunction. This patient’s breathy, hypernasal, slow speech accompanied by tongue atrophy and fasciculations is characteristic of flaccid dysarthria, a common feature of motor neuron disease, specifically amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of choking and coughing with eating and drinking for six months. The patient has had trouble swallowing both liquids and solids. There is no chest pain or pain upon swallowing. The patient endorses feeling clumsier, tripping easily. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety managed with citalopram. The patient’s father developed similar symptoms, which she attributes to alcohol use. There is no personal history of substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg. On exam, the patient is alert with loud, explosive speech, pausing after each syllable. The patient sways slightly to and fro while seated. There is ataxia on finger-nose-finger testing, and her gait appears wide-based. Results of which of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of oropharyngeal dysphagia and loud, explosive, scanning speech characteristic of ataxic dysarthria. Accompanying limb and truncal ataxia suggests cerebellar dysfunction. The family history suggests a possible underlying genetic etiology, such as spinocerebellar ataxia. Neuroimaging, specifically magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast, is indicated.

Impaired swallowing or motor speech can result from various neurologic and non-neurologic conditions. Neurologic etiologies include cranial nerve dysfunction, neuromuscular junction disorders, neurodegenerative conditions, demyelination syndromes, and stroke. Historical and physical examination findings help differentiate whether the primary issue is dysphagia or dysarthria and determine the subtype. Additional diagnostic tests can help determine the exact etiology.

For patients with oropharyngeal dysphagia, nasal endoscopy and video fluoroscopy can evaluate structural and functional causes, respectively. Esophagoduodenoscopy with or without manometry can help differentiate types of esophageal dysphagia.
