Physical examination is most helpful in differentiating between hypo- and hyperkinetic, flaccid, spastic, or ataxic dysarthria. Neurodiagnostic tests, including MRI and electromyography, can identify the underlying etiology.

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nasal endoscopy:
Incorrect: Nasal endoscopy can reveal structural abnormalities in the oropharynx and larynx. However, this patient’s dysphagia and dysarthria are coupled with signs of cerebellar dysfunction. Neuroimaging is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis.
❌ Esophagoduodenoscopy (EGD) with esophageal manometry:
Incorrect: An EGD can show structural abnormalities in the upper gastrointestinal tract, and esophageal manometry may help assess for motility disorders. However, this patient’s dysphagia and dysarthria are coupled with signs of cerebellar dysfunction. Neuroimaging is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis.
❌ Electromyography (EMG):
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of dysphagia, ataxic dysarthria, and other signs of cerebellar dysfunction, for which neuroimaging is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis. Electromyography is more helpful in diagnosing flaccid or spastic dysarthria.
❌ Video fluoroscopy (modified barium swallow):
Incorrect: Video fluoroscopy can evaluate swallowing mechanics, signs of aspiration, and structural lesions. However, this patient presents with cerebellar abnormalities, necessitating imaging via MRI of the brain.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache. The patient reports episodic migraines with aura since adolescence. Today, a sudden, intense headache developed, described as the “worst of my life.” Past medical history includes gastroesophageal reflux. Medications include omeprazole, amitriptyline, and rizatriptan as needed. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 188/85 mmHg. She appears alert but irritable, with noted photophobia and nuchal rigidity. There is drift in the right upper extremity. Which of the following historical findings most strongly suggests the need for neuroimaging?
questions.solution:
This patient with a long history of primary headaches now presents with a thunderclap headache, raising concern for secondary causes such as subarachnoid hemorrhage. A thunderclap headache is characterized by sudden-onset, severe pain, unlike the gradually progressive pain typical of migraine, and neuroimaging is warranted.

Primary headaches (e.g., migraine, tension-type headaches) occur without an underlying structural or systemic condition. In contrast, secondary headaches result from an identifiable disease process, such as meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage. Neuroimaging is rarely indicated for primary headaches but should be performed in patients with features suggestive of a secondary headache, typically starting with a non-contrast CT of the brain.

History and physical examination can help distinguish primary from secondary headache disorders by identifying red flags. These concerning features are summarized by the SNNOOP10 mnemonic, which includes:

  •    Systemic symptoms (such as fever or weight loss)
  •    Neurological deficits   Neoplasm (known history of cancer)
  •    Onset sudden (thunderclap headache) 
  •    Onset after age 50
The additional ten "p"s include:
  •    Pattern change in headache
  •    Positional headache (worsening with changes in posture)
  •    headache Precipitated by Valsalva maneuvers (such as coughing or sneezing)
  •    Papilledema
  •    Progressive worsening of headache 
  •    Pregnancy
  •    Painful eye with autonomic features
  •    Posttraumatic headache 
  •    Pathology of the immune system (such as HIV or immunosuppressive therapy) 
  •    Painkiller overuse (suggesting medication-overuse headache)

Option Analysis

✅ Onset and intensity of headache:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of headaches:
Incorrect: A history of stable, recurrent migraines does not warrant neuroimaging. However, a sudden change in the character or severity of the headache, especially in the setting of new focal neurological findings, requires further evaluation with imaging.
❌ Use of over-the-counter analgesics:
Incorrect: Chronic use of over-the-counter analgesics increases the risk of medication overuse headache. However, this patient’s sudden change in headache accompanied by focal neurological deficits suggests a more serious etiology.
❌ Family history of meningioma:
Incorrect: Neuroimaging is not indicated for patients with a long-standing, stable pattern of migraine headache, even in the setting of a family history of a benign intracranial mass. Neuroimaging should be considered for patients with a sudden change in headache presentation or pattern, especially when accompanied by focal neurological deficits.
❌ Age:
Incorrect: While age over 50 is considered a risk factor for secondary causes of headache, this individual is only 41. In the absence of other concerning features, age alone would not necessitate neuroimaging.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache for six months. There have been intermittent episodes of severe, unilateral head pain behind the right eye, lasting as brief as 15 minutes to 3 hours. The episodes occur either every other day or multiple times per day. Nausea is present, and vomiting occurred once today. Medical history is unremarkable, and no medication is taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mmHg. The patient appears restless and agitated and is squinting. There is ptosis and miosis of the right eye, which appears injected and tearing. Motor strength and reflexes are normal. Which of the following will provide the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the brain

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of cluster headache, a primary headache disorder characterized by severe, unilateral orbital or temporal pain accompanied by ipsilateral autonomic symptoms such as ptosis, miosis, conjunctival injection, and lacrimation. The diagnosis can be made using clinical criteria alone when the presentation is typical, and no red flag features are present.

Primary headache disorders include migraine, tension-type headache, and the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias such as cluster headache. These conditions can usually be diagnosed based on a careful history and physical examination. In patients without red flag features, further diagnostic testing is often unnecessary.

However, when headache presents with warning signs such as new neurologic deficits, fever, sudden onset headache with thunderclap quality, altered mental status, or signs of increased intracranial pressure, a secondary cause should be suspected. These may include conditions such as giant cell arteritis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, meningitis, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis, or idiopathic intracranial hypertension. In such cases, further workup with neuroimaging, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, or laboratory testing is required to confirm the diagnosis and guide management.   

Option Analysis

✅ Clinical criteria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis:
Incorrect: CSF analysis is used to evaluate for secondary causes of headache, such as meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is not indicated in the evaluation of a typical cluster headache.
❌ Inflammatory markers:
Incorrect: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein are primarily useful in evaluating conditions like giant cell arteritis. They do not aid in the diagnosis of cluster headache.
❌ Temporal artery biopsy:
Incorrect: Temporal artery biopsy is used to diagnose giant cell arteritis, which typically affects adults over 50 and presents with jaw claudication and visual symptoms. This patient’s age and symptom pattern are more consistent with cluster headache, which is diagnosed clinically.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for the brain:
Incorrect: MRI may be used to rule out structural causes of headaches when red flag features are present. However, without neurologic deficits or atypical features, imaging is not necessary for diagnosing a typical cluster headache.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents to the emergency department with generalized weakness for the past two days and a tremor in both arms. The patient reports a headache over this period, sensitivity to light, and muscle aches. On review of systems, there is a history of recent insect bites while camping. Past medical history includes type 1 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears lethargic but answers questions appropriately. There is diffuse 4+/5 weakness in all extremities. A maculopapular rash is noted over the trunk, back, and bilateral upper extremities. A diagnostic lumbar puncture is performed. Which of the following would likely be positive on cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of encephalitis, including lethargy, headache, photophobia, fever, rash, symmetric limb weakness, and tremor. The most likely diagnosis is West Nile viral encephalitis, given the recent insect bites (potentially mosquitoes) while camping. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the presence of West Nile virus IgM antibodies in the CSF. Individuals who are immunocompromised, older adults, and those with diabetes are at increased risk for this infection.       

Encephalitis may result from infectious or autoimmune causes. Laboratory evaluation typically includes a complete blood count (CBC) with differential, serum antibody testing, CSF analysis, and neuroimaging to help narrow the differential. Neuroimaging findings are often nonspecific and may show edema, hemorrhage, ischemia, hyperintensities, calcifications, or ring-enhancing lesions. In infectious encephalitis, CSF testing frequently identifies the causative agent (e.g. positive Toxoplasma gondii PCR), while autoimmune encephalitis is often associated with the presence of specific autoantibodies (e.g. anti-NMDA receptor antibodies).       

Option Analysis

✅ West Nile (WN) virus IgM antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Herpes simplex virus (HSV)-1/2 PCR:
Incorrect: HSV encephalitis typically presents prodromal upper respiratory symptoms, olfactory hallucinations, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. It is not typically associated with a rash or recent insect exposure. 
❌ Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) IgM antibodies:
Incorrect: VZV encephalitis is more commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals or older adults and may present with acute, stroke-like symptoms. While some patients may have a recent history of chickenpox or shingles infection, these rashes are typically vesicular and not usually described as a diffuse maculopapular rash. Additionally, it is not associated with recent insect exposure. 
❌ Toxoplasma gondii PCR :
Incorrect: Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis more commonly occurs in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with advanced HIV/AIDS. Additionally, while it can cause focal neurologic deficits, it is not typically associated with a diffuse rash, tremor, or insect exposure. 
❌ Taenia solium antigen:
Incorrect: Neurocysticercosis, caused by the larval form of Taenia solium, is more commonly associated with travel to endemic regions, such as Latin America, sub-Saharan Africa, or Southeast Asia. It may cause seizures, signs of increased intracranial pressure, eye pain, and vision loss. It is not typically associated with tremor, diffuse rash, or insect exposure.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for an annual wellness examination. The patient has noticed worsening tremulousness of both hands when reaching for objects over the past three years. She feels increasingly clumsy, and family members have noticed slurred speech, especially when the patient is tired. Past medical history includes generalized anxiety, treated with citalopram. There is no history of illicit substance use. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears alert. A high-amplitude tremor is noted on finger-nose-finger testing. Gait is ataxic. Urine drug screen is negative. Which of the following additional features is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with cerebellar dysfunction, including intention tremor, dysarthria, and ataxia. The diagnostic approach to cerebellar lesions is guided primarily by the timing of symptom onset. In this case, the chronic and slowly progressive course, along with the absence of alcohol use, suggests a hereditary cause and warrants investigation for a family history of similar symptoms.       

Acute-onset cerebellar symptoms are most commonly due to stroke, infectious cerebellitis, or post-infectious acute cerebellar ataxia (more common in children), and they are typically evaluated with neuroimaging.       

Subacute or chronic cerebellar symptoms may result from underlying genetic conditions such as Friedreich ataxia or one of the many spinocerebellar ataxias, for which genetic testing may be appropriate. Alcoholic cerebellar degeneration, which predominantly affects the cerebellar vermis, typically causes truncal ataxia rather than limb involvement. Structural abnormalities, such as Chiari I malformation, may present with headaches due to elevated intracranial pressure. Multiple system atrophy (cerebellar type) can feature additional signs of pontine involvement or dysautonomia. Both structural and degenerative causes can be evaluated with neuroimaging.        

Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration should be considered in patients with a known or suspected malignancy; diagnosis may be supported by serum or cerebrospinal fluid testing for anti-Yo, anti-Hu, or anti-Tr antibodies.       

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of similar symptoms:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chronic alcohol use:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation suggests cerebellar hemispheric dysfunction, which is more characteristic of hereditary ataxia than alcoholic cerebellar degeneration. The latter typically affects the cerebellar vermis, leading to truncal ataxia, and is associated with long-standing alcohol misuse. 
❌ Underlying malignancy:
Incorrect: While paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration can cause similar findings, it typically presents subacutely and is more common in older individuals. The slow progression and early age in this case are more consistent with hereditary ataxia. 
❌ Headache worsened by Valsalva maneuvers:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of chronic cerebellar dysfunction, which can be seen with cerebellar ectopia. The absence of sensory changes, motor weakness, dysphagia, or associated cranial neuropathies suggests a degenerative process rather than an obstructive lesion, as seen in hereditary ataxias. 
❌ Hypertension:
Incorrect: Uncontrolled hypertension can result in acute cerebellar infarction or hemorrhage, typically with rapid onset of symptoms. The gradual progression in this case suggests a hereditary rather than vascular cause.

questions.text: A 49-year-old adult presents to an urgent care clinic for evaluation of left shoulder pain described as severe, electric, shooting pain radiating from the shoulder to the forearm. The left hand feels numb. There is no chest pain. Medical history includes osteoarthritis and stable angina. Medications are meloxicam and amlodipine. An annual influenza vaccination was received recently. The individual works in construction and plays tennis. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/74 mmHg. On exam, there is 4+/5 weakness with left wrist flexion and forearm pronation. Numbness is noted in the left palm. The clinician suspects a plexopathy. Which of the following findings would suggest an alternative diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of upper extremity weakness in a distribution consistent with brachial plexus involvement. A recent history of vaccination places the patient at risk for brachial neuritis (also known as Parsonage-Turner syndrome), a brachial plexopathy characterized by acute onset of severe shoulder pain followed by weakness and sensory loss in the ipsilateral upper extremity. Among the answer choices provided, spasticity is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion and would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

When evaluating weakness, first assess the pattern: unilateral or bilateral, limb distribution, sensory changes, symptom fluctuation, and cranial nerve involvement. A focused history and physical exam help localize the lesion. Key components of the neurologic exam include assessment of tone, reflexes, and the presence of upper or lower motor neuron signs. Upper motor neuron (UMN) signs include spasticity and hyperreflexia, while lower motor neuron (LMN) signs include decreased tone, hyporeflexia, atrophy, and fasciculations.

A plexopathy is a condition affecting multiple contiguous nerve roots. Patients typically present with subacute or progressive weakness, often accompanied by sensory deficits and, in some cases, pain. The pattern of involvement is non-dermatomal and affects multiple peripheral nerves arising from the involved plexus. Exam findings should be consistent with lower motor neuron lesions.

Option Analysis

✅ Spasticity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyporeflexia:
Incorrect: Hyporeflexia is a lower motor neuron finding and is consistent with brachial plexopathy.
❌ Decreased muscle tone:
Incorrect: Decreased tone is expected in lower motor neuron lesions, including brachial plexopathies.
❌ Muscle atrophy:
Incorrect: Muscle atrophy may occur in the subacute or chronic phase of brachial plexopathy due to denervation.
❌ Fasciculations:
Incorrect: Fasciculations can be seen in lower motor neuron disorders and are not uncommon in plexopathies.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of neck weakness over the past two weeks. She has difficulty holding her head upright, which worsens as the day progresses. The patient also reports trouble brushing her hair in the evening. There are no sensory symptoms in the arms. Medical history includes hypertension managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On examination, there is weakness with neck flexion, extension, and shoulder abduction bilaterally. Which additional diagnostic test can confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fluctuating bilateral weakness, a finding suggestive of a neuromuscular junction disorder. Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) can localize dysfunction to the neuromuscular junction and help differentiate between myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS).

To approach weakness, first determine if it is unilateral or bilateral. Unilateral weakness involving more than one limb or region may indicate a brain lesion. Isolated limb involvement may indicate radiculopathy, plexopathy, or mononeuropathy, depending on the distribution. Bilateral weakness requires an assessment of sensory involvement. If sensory loss is present, assess for a sensory level or cranial nerve involvement, which can suggest spinal cord lesions or polyneuropathy. If there is no sensory involvement, assess for fluctuating symptoms. Diurnal or activity-related worsening suggests a neuromuscular junction disorder such as myasthenia gravis. Rapid progression after an exposure may suggest botulism or toxin-related paralysis. Episodic weakness with metabolic triggers points to a channelopathy. Persistent weakness without fluctuation should prompt evaluation of tone and reflexes. Normal tone and reflexes suggest a myopathy, while abnormalities suggest motor neuron disease.

In neuromuscular junction disorders, electrophysiologic testing provides further diagnostic clarity. RNS at low frequencies (2–3 Hz) depletes acetylcholine. A decremental response is characteristic of myasthenia gravis, while an incremental response is more typical of LEMS.

Option Analysis

✅ Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Incorrect: Cervical radiculopathy could cause upper extremity weakness, but symptoms would typically be constant and may include sensory deficits. The fluctuating nature of this patient’s symptoms is not characteristic of radiculopathy.
❌ Stool sample:
Incorrect: Botulism, another neuromuscular junction disorder, can be diagnosed with a stool sample. However, botulism typically presents with descending paralysis and autonomic features and does not exhibit the diurnal fluctuation of weakness seen in this patient with myasthenia gravis.
❌ Voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) antibodies:
Incorrect: VGCC antibodies are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which also affects the neuromuscular junction. LEMS often presents with proximal lower extremity weakness and autonomic symptoms, with strength that improves with activity. This patient instead has bulbar and upper extremity involvement with diurnal worsening, which are more characteristic of myasthenia gravis.
❌ Serum potassium level:
Incorrect: Channelopathies such as hypokalemic or hyperkalemic periodic paralysis cause episodic weakness linked to potassium fluctuations. These disorders typically present earlier in life and are not associated with diurnal variation or fatigability, as seen in this patient with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old individual is reevaluated in the intensive care unit for ongoing management following cardiopulmonary arrest after being found unresponsive in an apartment 48 hours ago. Past medical history is unknown. A urine drug screen on arrival to the emergency department is negative. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min by mechanical ventilation, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. The patient is intubated and not receiving intravenous sedation. The patient remains unconscious without localizing movements in response to painful stimuli. There are intermittent arm flexion and arm-crossing movements. Brainstem reflexes are absent. Deep tendon reflexes are present bilaterally. Computed tomography (CT) of the head shows loss of gray-white matter differentiation. Current laboratory values are shown below. The treating physician is planning to perform apnea testing. Which of the following findings prohibits the physician from confirming the suspected diagnosis at this time?

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 113 mEq/L
 Potassium 3.4 mEq/L
 Chloride 95 mEq/L
 Creatinine 1.9 mg/dL
 Albumin 3.2 g/dL
 BUN/Cr > 20
 Toxicology
 Serum ethanol 0 mg/dL
 Acetaminophen level 5 mcg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient’s treating physician is planning to perform an apnea test, which is used to help confirm a diagnosis of brain death. However, the patient’s markedly low sodium level (hyponatremia) prohibits the confirmation of this diagnosis and must be corrected before further testing can proceed.

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain function and may result from trauma, stroke, hypoxic-ischemic injury, mass lesions, infections, or toxic/metabolic disturbances. Neuroimaging often demonstrates cerebral edema, typically evidenced by loss of gray-white matter differentiation, and may reveal signs of herniation.

Before brain death can be confirmed, other potential causes of the patient’s clinical state must be excluded. This includes observing the patient for a sufficient period, typically at least 24 hours, to assess for any signs of neurologic improvement. Medications that could affect consciousness or the neurologic examination, such as barbiturates or benzodiazepines, must be ruled out or metabolized. Laboratory evaluation should assess for correctable metabolic or acid-base disturbances. The patient must not be under the effects of neuromuscular blockade. In addition, prerequisites for testing include a core body temperature of at least 36°C, a systolic blood pressure of 100 mm Hg or higher, and a mean arterial pressure of at least 75 mm Hg.

Option Analysis

✅ Sodium level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Presence of deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: Spinally mediated reflexes such as deep tendon reflexes may persist in brain death and do not exclude the diagnosis.
❌ Intermittent arm crossing movements:
Incorrect: These movements are consistent with spinal automatism (i.e. Lazarus sign), which can occur in brain death and do not preclude the diagnosis.
❌ Acetaminophen level:
Incorrect: An acetaminophen level of 5 mcg/mL is not clinically significant and unlikely to contribute to the patient’s presentation.
❌ Potassium level:
Incorrect: A potassium level of 3.4 mEq/L is mildly low but not severe enough to account for this patient's neurological status.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the primary care clinic for evaluation of weakness. Over the past five years, she has had progressive difficulty rising from a chair and climbing stairs without holding onto the railing. Medical history includes hypertension and depression, treated with lisinopril and fluoxetine. A sibling has been non-ambulatory since childhood due to a neuromuscular condition. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. On exam, there is proximal lower extremity weakness, bilateral thigh atrophy, and areflexia without spasticity. Laboratory studies, including a comprehensive metabolic panel, muscle enzyme levels, thyroid function tests, and vitamin B12 level, are all within normal limits. Which of the following additional diagnostic tests would most likely help confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Genetic analysis of the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene
Genetic analysis of the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene
Genetic analysis of the chromosome 9 open reading frame 72 (C9orf72) gene
Survival motor neuron 2 (SMN2) gene copy number analysis
Genetic analysis of the dystrophin gene

questions.solution:
This 50-year-old patient presents with slowly progressive proximal lower extremity weakness, evidenced by difficulty standing and climbing stairs, along with areflexia. A family history of a sibling with similar symptoms who became non-ambulatory in childhood further raises concern for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type 4. The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic analysis demonstrating deletions or mutations in both copies of the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene.

The diagnostic workup for suspected motor neuron disease begins with assessing whether upper and/or lower motor neurons are involved. Lower motor neuron signs include muscle atrophy, fasciculations, hypotonia, and hyporeflexia, while upper motor neuron signs include spasticity and hyperreflexia.

Both SMA and acute flaccid myelitis (AFM) are lower motor neuron disorders, whereas amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) involves both upper and lower motor neuron findings. SMA and AFM may be distinguished based on the timing of symptom onset and rate of progression. Genetic analysis confirming deletion or mutation of the SMN1 gene establishes the diagnosis of SMA type 4. In contrast, cerebrospinal fluid analysis showing pleocytosis and spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealing grey matter involvement would support a diagnosis of AFM.

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic analysis of the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Genetic analysis of the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene:
Incorrect: Mutations in SOD1 are associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a condition that features both upper and lower motor neuron involvement. This patient has only lower motor neuron signs, with no spasticity or other evidence of upper motor neuron disease. The gradual onset of symptoms and significant family history make spinal muscular atrophy type 4 the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Genetic analysis of the chromosome 9 open reading frame 72 (C9orf72) gene:
Incorrect: Mutations in C9orf72 are linked to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), which involves both upper and lower motor neuron signs. This patient lacks upper motor neuron findings, and the gradual onset of symptoms and significant family history make spinal muscular atrophy type 4 the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Survival motor neuron 2 (SMN2) gene copy number analysis:
Incorrect: SMN2 copy number correlates with disease severity and prognosis in spinal muscular atrophy but does not establish the diagnosis. Confirmation requires evidence of a pathogenic mutation or deletion in SMN1.
❌ Genetic analysis of the dystrophin gene:
Incorrect: Mutations in the dystrophin gene cause Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies, which are X-linked myopathies. These typically present earlier in life, primarily affect males, and are associated with elevated creatine kinase levels.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMS after a pedestrian found the patient sitting on the ground in a park with word-finding difficulty, saying “want water now” and “park two yesterday.” The patient is unable to write when offered a pen and paper. Past medical history is unknown. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 188/98 mmHg. On exam, the patient appears anxious and frustrated, without outward signs of injury. The patient follows commands but is unable to repeat phrases. A urine drug screen and serum ethanol level are unremarkable. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Left face, arm, and leg weakness

questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with signs of dysfunction in the left posterior inferior frontal lobe, evidenced by non-fluent speech, impaired writing, and poor repetition with preserved comprehension. These findings are consistent with Broca aphasia. Lesions in this region often produce contralateral weakness when adjacent motor or supplementary motor areas are involved.       

Cortical lesions may cause aphasia (language impairment), anopsia (visual field deficits), agnosia (inability to recognize objects), or neglect. Identifying the dominant feature aids in localizing the lesion. Broca aphasia, marked by non-fluent speech, impaired writing, and preserved comprehension, typically indicates a lesion in the dominant (usually left) posterior inferior frontal gyrus. In contrast, Wernicke aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech, paraphasias, and poor comprehension and repetition, suggests injury to the left posterior superior temporal gyrus. Additional deficits may occur if nearby structures are affected.       

In the absence of these symptoms of cortical impairment, the differential diagnosis of subcortical lesions can be similarly narrowed by the dominant presenting symptom, including motor symptoms (either weakness or involuntary hyperkinetic movements), hemisensory loss, or cognitive/behavioral changes (memory loss, apathy, hypersexuality, hyperphagia).  

Option Analysis

✅ Right arm weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Left face, arm, and leg weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness on the left side would suggest a right hemisphere lesion. However, the patient’s Broca aphasia indicates a lesion in the left hemisphere. 
❌ Impaired hearing:
Incorrect: Thisis patient presents with Broca aphasia. Hearing loss is unlikely given the preserved ability to follow commands. Wernicke aphasia, which affects auditory comprehension, may be mistaken for hearing loss, but this is not consistent with the clinical picture. 
❌ Left homonymous hemianopsia:
Incorrect: This patient presents with Broca aphasia, which localizes to the left inferior frontal lobe. Lesions in the left frontal lobe do not typically affect the visual pathways. 
❌ Dysphagia:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of Broca aphasia. Dysphagia is more often associated with brainstem or subcortical lesions. Cortical lesions in the frontal language area are unlikely to impair swallowing.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department following an altercation in which another individual stabbed the patient on the right side of the neck with a screwdriver. Witnesses report that the patient collapsed at the scene. There is no known medical history, and no medications are taken. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert and appears appropriately anxious. The screwdriver is lodged in the right posterior neck. There is flaccid paralysis of the right arm and leg, along with impaired proprioception and vibration sense on the right. There are spontaneous movements of the left arm and leg. Which of the following additional examination findings confirms the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left arm and leg

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of hemicord syndrome, as evidenced by unilateral weakness and sensory deficits following penetrating spinal cord trauma. In this condition, damage to the dorsal column on the affected side results in ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception since these fibers ascend ipsilaterally before decussating in the medulla. Additionally, involvement of the contralateral spinothalamic tract leads to loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side, as these fibers cross near their level of entry in the spinal cord.        

The differential diagnosis for a suspected spinal cord lesion in adults depends in part on the level of involvement. When weakness or sensory loss is absent in the cervical or thoracic regions, conditions such as conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome should be considered. When present, the differential is broader and includes central cord syndrome; anterior, posterior, hemicord, or complete cord syndromes; syringomyelia; spinal cord infarction; subacute combined degeneration; tabes dorsalis, penetrating trauma; spinal cord compression; cord transection; and transverse myelitis. The pattern of sensory loss, along with the presence, absence, and distribution of weakness, helps to narrow the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Loss of pain and temperature sensation in the left arm and leg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rightward tongue deviation:
Incorrect: Tongue deviation suggests cranial nerve XII involvement, which is not expected with a cervical hemicord lesion. 
❌ Right pupillary dilation:
Incorrect: Right pupillary dilation would indicate unopposed sympathetic activity or impaired parasympathetic input, typically resulting from brainstem or cranial nerve III involvement. A cervical hemicord lesion affects spinal cord tracts, not the midbrain or oculomotor pathways. 
❌ Left hyperreflexia:
Incorrect: This patient has a cervical hemicord lesion. Hyperreflexia would be expected on the same side as the lesion (right), due to involvement of the ipsilateral corticospinal tract. 
❌ Dysarthria:
Incorrect: Dysarthria is more consistent with cortical or brainstem involvement, not an isolated spinal cord injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening mid back pain and numbness and tingling in both legs for the past two days. This morning, the patient tripped while going up the stairs and has felt progressively weaker throughout the day. She has not voided since the previous evening. Medical history includes multiple sclerosis managed with teriflunomide. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. On exam, there is symmetric drift in both lower extremities and impaired proprioception, pain, temperature, and vibration sense in both legs. Upper extremity strength and sensation are normal. Which of the following tests confirms the diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbosacral spine with and without contrast
Serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for oligoclonal banding

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of a complete spinal cord syndrome, including mid-back pain, progressive bilateral lower extremity weakness, bladder dysfunction, and loss of all sensory modalities in the legs. A history of multiple sclerosis raises concern for an acute demyelinating episode, such as transverse myelitis. This diagnosis can be confirmed with MRI of the thoracic spine with and without contrast.        

The differential diagnosis for a suspected spinal cord lesion in a stable adult depends on the level of involvement (e.g., cervical or thoracic) and can be further refined by evaluating the pattern of sensory loss and the presence and distribution of weakness.        

After clinical localization, additional neurodiagnostic studies such as electromyography, nerve conduction studies, MRI, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis can help confirm the diagnosis. Careful clinical assessment before imaging can reduce unnecessary and costly testing.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the thoracic spine with and without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine with and without contrast:
Incorrect: Lower extremity symptoms without upper extremity involvement suggest a lesion below the cervical spinal cord. The presence of mid-back pain supports thoracic localization rather than cervical. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain with and without contrast:
Incorrect: A cerebral lesion would not produce isolated bilateral lower extremity weakness and complete sensory loss. The findings are more consistent with a spinal cord syndrome. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbosacral spine with and without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient’s bilateral lower extremity loss of all sensory modalities suggests a complete cord syndrome. The accompanying mid-back pain suggests a thoracic level lesion as opposed to a lumbar lesion.  
❌ Serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis for oligoclonal banding:
Incorrect: While oligoclonal bands may support a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, this test is not appropriate for the acute evaluation of spinal cord dysfunction. Immediate imaging is necessary to assess for structural or inflammatory lesions.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion lasting for two hours. The patient was in his usual state of health when he suddenly began speaking in short, fragmented sentences. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which the patient does not take his prescribed medication. A motor vehicle accident two years ago resulted in a back injury. The patient consumes alcohol and smokes tobacco daily. Family history is significant for a parent with dementia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 210/102 mmHg. On examination, the patient is alert and appears frustrated when questioned. The patient speaks in short, grammatically incorrect sentences, has significant word-finding difficulty, and is unable to write but can read. The patient cannot repeat phrases. There is drift in the right arm. Which of the following aspects of medical history most significantly increased the risk for the development of this condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
This older adult patient presents with symptoms of expressive aphasia, characterized by word-finding difficulty and non-fluent speech, but with intact comprehension. Impaired repetition points toward Broca aphasia. The acute onset, along with right-sided weakness, suggests an acute ischemic stroke. Severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor in this patient.    

Patients with aphasia may experience trouble communicating, although the abnormality may sometimes be reported by caregivers and the patient may be unaware of the language impairment. A thorough physical examination can provide clues to the etiology of aphasia and should assess verbal and written language output, comprehension, and the ability to repeat phrases.        

The differential diagnosis for aphasia depends on its type, as each is associated with specific localizations within the language circuitry pathway. Aphasia is considered a cortical sign, and the assessment should include an investigation for stroke risk factors, symptoms of space-occupying lesions, or signs of dementia.    



Option Analysis

✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: Alcohol use can contribute to stroke risk. However, this patient's severe, uncontrolled hypertension is his most significant modifiable risk factor for ischemic stroke.  
❌ Family history:
Incorrect: This patient’s expressive aphasia and right arm weakness are likely due to an acute ischemic stroke. A family history of dementia may suggest a genetic predisposition to neurodegenerative diseases, but it is not a major risk factor for stroke. A family history of cardiovascular disease or stroke would be more relevant in this case. 
❌ Trauma history:
Incorrect: Although a history of trauma from a motor vehicle collision could affect speech and motor function, this patient’s acute symptoms are more consistent with ischemic stroke. In this case, the patient’s severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the most significant risk factor for ischemic stroke. 
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Tobacco use is a known risk factor for stroke. However, in this case, severe, uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor contributing to this patient’s ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a family member who went to check on the patient after several unanswered phone calls yesterday. The family member found the patient confused and disoriented at home. The patient was holding her left arm limp at her side while trying to cook, and she was having difficulty selecting the appropriate utensils. Past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and tobacco use. Medications include lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 180/85 mmHg. On examination, the patient is not oriented to place or time. There is pronator drift and decreased sensation in the left upper extremity. Which of the following diagnostic test results is most likely to confirm the underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast
Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient with several cardiovascular risk factors presents with symptoms of acute encephalopathy secondary to a subcortical stroke, including confusion, anosognosia (unawareness of their own neurological deficit), and apraxia. The evaluation for acute stroke begins with non-contrast neuroimaging, with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain being the most likely to confirm the presence of a subcortical stroke.

Encephalopathy can occur from a variety of causes, including neurologic and other medical conditions. The differential diagnosis can be narrowed based on the patient’s past medical history and physical examination, which will often guide the diagnostic workup. Laboratory studies may reveal a toxic or metabolic etiology, like liver, kidney, or thyroid dysfunction. If seizure is suspected, an electroencephalogram (EEG) can be diagnostic. In cases where infection is suspected, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is warranted. Finally, for patients with stroke-like symptoms, neuroimaging in the form of non-contrast computerized tomography (CT) or MRI can confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain without contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Urine toxicology screen:
Incorrect: While confusion can result from substance ingestion, this patient’s acute focal neurological deficits and stroke risk factors make non-contrast neuroimaging the most appropriate next step to evaluate for ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) cell count analysis:
Incorrect: Although central nervous system infections may present with confusion, this patient’s focal deficits, absence of fever, and vascular risk factors are more concerning for stroke, requiring prompt neuroimaging without contrast.
❌ Electroencephalogram (EEG):
Incorrect: While confusion and focal neurological deficits can occur in seizure or post-ictal states, the presence of stroke risk factors makes non-contrast neuroimaging the priority to rule out acute ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke.
❌ Computerized tomography (CT) of the head with contrast:
Incorrect: While CT imaging can detect many intracranial pathologies, non-contrast CT or MRI is preferred in the initial evaluation of suspected stroke to differentiate ischemic from hemorrhagic causes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of left arm weakness after seeing a chiropractor. The patient has been experiencing neck pain for a few months. The chiropractor ordered cervical spine radiographs, which were normal, and performed spinal manipulative therapy, after which the patient immediately experienced shooting pain down his left arm. After driving home, the patient noticed difficulty opening the car door. Past medical history includes hypertension managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. On exam, there is weakness with left elbow extension, wrist flexion and extension, and finger extension. Left elbow flexion and shoulder abduction strength are normal, as are right arm and bilateral lower extremity strength and reflexes. The left triceps reflex is diminished. Which of the following additional findings confirms the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Numbness of the left third finger

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of C7 radiculopathy, manifesting as unilateral weakness in elbow extension, wrist flexion and extension, and finger extension, along with a diminished triceps reflex. Patients may also experience numbness and tingling in the ipsilateral middle finger due involvement of the C7 dermatome.        

Patients with weakness or sensory deficits may have issues involving a peripheral nerve, nerve root, or plexus. For patients with hand numbness and weakness resulting in wrist drop, or foot numbness and weakness resulting in foot drop, the underlying cause depends on the specific muscles involved and the pattern of sensory loss. Additional features (e.g., onset of symptoms, red flag features) can also be useful when multiple nerves may be involved. The table above compares distinguishing features and patterns for several types of lesions.   

Option Analysis

✅ Numbness of the left third finger:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Decreased brachioradialis reflex:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a left C7 radiculopathy, which is characterized by weakness in the triceps, wrist flexion and extension, and finger extension, in addition to third finger numbness and a decreased triceps reflex. A diminished brachioradialis reflex would be more likely if the C5 or C6 nerve root, upper trunk of the brachial plexus, or radial nerve were involved, as in brachial plexopathy or radial neuropathy. 
❌ Left shoulder numbness:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a left C7 radiculopathy, which may be accompanied by numbness of the third finger. Left shoulder numbness would be seen in a lesion involving the C5 nerve root or upper brachial plexus (i.e. brachial plexopathy). 
❌ Tingling in the left shoulder:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of a left C7 radiculopathy, which may be accompanied by numbness of the third finger. Tingling in the shoulder would be more consistent with a C5 nerve root or upper brachial plexus lesion.  
❌ Headache and dizziness:
Incorrect: While spinal manipulation could result in a vertebral artery dissection presenting with headache and dizziness, the symptoms here suggest left C7 radiculopathy, which may be accompanied by numbness of the third finger.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of worsening low back pain with walking. The patient's symptoms have been ongoing for over 8 months. The pain is worsened with standing  upright and walking  and relieved with sitting. There is no relief when he continues standing upright but stops walking. He sometimes experiences pain and tingling into the buttocks and legs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and fifteen-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not reveal any bony tenderness or defects of the lumbar spine. Neurologic assessment demonstrates 5/5 strength of the lower extremities bilaterally and a normal sensory examination. Straight leg raise is negative bilaterally. A digital rectal exam demonstrates an enlarged prostate without bogginess or asymmetry and adequate rectal tone. A radiograph of the lumbar spine shows only osteophytes. Further history is most likely to elicit which of the following regarding this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This older patient presents for evaluation of low back pain and buttocks and leg pain worsened with walking and standing and relieved with sitting but not when he stops walking but continues to stand. These findings are consistent with spinal stenosis. A characteristic feature of spinal stenosis is pain relief with bending forward at the waist, as it helps offload pressure and widens the spinal canal. Which is in contrast to leg pain seen in vascular claudication which is worse with walking and relieved when the patient stops walking even when they remain upright.  

Spinal stenosis refers to narrowing of the vertebral foramen in one or more vertebrae, typically in the lumbar region. Most commonly, this is an age-related condition due to osteoarthritis and progressive disk degeneration that results in facet joint arthropathy, osteophyte formation, and hypertrophy of the ligamentum flavum. These processes ultimately result in the narrowing and impingement of the central spinal canal.  

Clinically, spinal stenosis results in “neurogenic claudication”, which refers to worsening pain with walking or standing upright, and relief with sitting where there is forward flexion at the waist. lying flat, or bending forward. In more severe cases, impingement on the central canal can compress spinal nerves, resulting in numbness, weakness, or tingling in the extremities. In most cases, the physical examination is non-contributory unless associated neurologic deficits are present.

Option Analysis

✅ Pain relief with bending forward:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Twenty-pound weight loss:
Incorrect: The diagnosis of primary or metastatic bone malignancy, especially prostate cancer in men, should always be considered when evaluating older men with low back pain. However, this patient’s prostate exam demonstrates only an enlarged prostate. Spinal stenosis which this patient has signs and symptoms of is commonly caused by arthritic changes in the spine and not metastases.  
❌ Loss of lower extremity hair:
Incorrect: Loss of lower extremity hair is commonly found in patients with vascular claudication from peripheral artery disease. Leg pain in this condition is worsened with walking and improved when the patient stops walking which is not seen in this patient.  
❌ History of osteoporosis:
Incorrect: Compression fractures result from underlying osteoporosis. This patient’s imaging does not show evidence of a vertebral body compression fracture.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Cauda equina syndrome is a neurologic emergency that arises from compression of the spinal cord at the level of the cauda equina. Associated symptoms include urinary retention, loss of bowel or bladder control, poor rectal tone, and weakness of the lower extremities. In rare cases spinal stenosis can lead to cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck with a baseball bat. The patient reports pain in the left eyebrow but does not have vision changes or pain with eye movements. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a hematoma and tenderness to palpation over the supraorbital rim. A CT scan of the face is shown below. Which of the following nerves is at risk of injury based on this patient’s traumatic mechanism?
   

Reproduced from: radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a supraorbital rim fracture after being struck with a blunt object. Given this mechanism and location of the injury, the supratrochlear nerve is at the highest risk of damage.

The trigeminal nerve branches into the frontal nerve within the orbit, dividing into the supraorbital nerve and supratrochlear nerve as they traverse via a bony recess called the supraorbital notch. These nerves provide sensory information to the skin of the forehead and scalp and are at risk of injury as they course superiorly from the orbit.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supratrochlear nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: The infraorbital nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information to the lower portion of the orbit. This patient’s injury is at the superior aspect of the orbit.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s injury pattern.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This nerve is more likely to be damaged with injury to the lateral face.  
❌ Nasociliary nerve:
Incorrect: The nasociliary nerve, a branch of V1, is less likely to be implicated given this patient’s injury due to its course within the orbit. This patient does not have evidence of damage to orbital structures.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents for evaluation of progressively worsening muscle stiffness and pain. The symptoms developed seven months ago after she suffered a left-sided cerebral stroke. She currently has difficulty performing fine motor tasks with the right hand. Her past medical history is also notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which she currently takes amlodipine and rosuvastatin. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 138/76 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. She has 3/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity. Mild contractures are present in the right hand, as demonstrated below. Resistance to active and passive range of motion is also noticed in the right upper extremity and is more prominent with rapid movements. Which of the following medications will most likely be effective in treating this patient’s symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with contractures and resistance to movement following a stroke, which is concerning for post-stroke spasticity. Spasticity occurs in around 20-30% of all patients who have experienced a stroke. The condition can be treated with medications such as tizanidine, baclofen, and botulinum toxin injections.

Tizanidine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant. It is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that stimulates receptors on the presynaptic neurons in the central nervous system (CNS), resulting in the decreased release of norepinephrine from sympathetic neurons.

Tizanidine can treat muscle spasticity in neurological disorders, such as stroke, multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. In addition, the medication can be used off-label to treat skeletal muscle pain (e.g., low back pain, neck pain).

In terms of side effects, tizanidine can cause drowsiness, confusion, dizziness, hypotension, weakness, and xerostomia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Gabapentin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with contractures and increased resistance to motion in the right upper extremity following a stroke. She likely has post-stroke spasticity. Gabapentin can effectively manage seizures and peripheral neuropathy but not post-stroke spasticity.  
❌ Cyclobenzaprine:
Incorrect: Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant that can treat musculoskeletal pain (e.g. low back pain) and is off-label to treat fibromyalgia. However, studies have not demonstrated the effectiveness of this medication in treating post-stroke spasticity.  
❌ Triamcinolone:
Incorrect: Triamcinolone is a glucocorticoid that can be injected to treat Dupuytren contracture, which is a benign fibroproliferative disorder that causes contractures of the fingers and palms. In contrast, this patient is presenting with contractures and increased resistance to motion following a stroke, which is more concerning for post-stroke spasticity. Triamcinolone injections are ineffective in treating post-stroke spasticity.  
❌ Oxycodone:
Incorrect: Oxycodone is an opioid that can be used to manage severe pain. However, oxycodone can also cause numerous side effects, including addiction, respiratory depression, sedation, constipation, and pruritus. As a result, the medication is not typically used to treat post-stroke spasticity or associated pain. Instead, botulinum toxin injections and oral muscle relaxants (e.g., baclofen, tizanidine) are preferred.  
✅ Tizanidine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman arrives at the outpatient neurologist for a pulsatile headache that is worse in the morning. She also has experienced occasional episodes of vomiting. She has no significant past medical history, and she does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 122/70 mmHg, pulse is 68/min., and body mass index is 25 kg/m2. Fundoscopic examination reveals bilateral papilledema. There is no neck stiffness or cranial nerve deficits. Sensation and strength are intact in all extremities. The cardiovascular, pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. After appropriate workup, the patient is diagnosed with idiopathic intracranial hypertension. She is started on a medication that inhibits carbonic anhydrase. Which of the following laboratory findings best characterizes the adverse effects of this medication?
questions.solution:
The patient was prescribed a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (CAI) for management of idiopathic intracranial hypertension.    

In the kidneys, CAIs inhibit the carbonic anhydrase enzyme located in the proximal convoluted tubule. These medications increase the amount of bicarbonate, sodium, and water being excreted in the urine. Since CAIs decrease bicarbonate reabsorption, more bicarbonate remains in the urine, resulting in urine alkalinization. Of note, the alkaline urine predisposes patients to forming calcium phosphate renal stones. In contrast, serum bicarbonate concentration decreases, resulting in metabolic acidosis.    

Patients taking CAIs will also develop hypokalemia. This is since CAIs cause increased amounts of urine sodium to reach the collecting duct, where more sodium leads to more potassium excretion into the urine. In addition, patients can develop hyperchloremia since the body compensates for reduced serum bicarbonate levels by releasing chloride from the cells into the blood.  

At high doses, patients may develop neurological side effects such as drowsiness and paresthesias.  

Lastly, CAIs are contraindicated in patients with liver cirrhosis since individuals with liver damage have difficulty removing ammonia from the blood. CAIs further decrease urinary excretion of ammonia, potentially causing hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy.  



Option Analysis

❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication prevents bicarbonate reabsorption from the urine. This results in a low serum bicarbonate level and high urine pH, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. 
✅  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↓  ↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↓  ↑ ↑ :
Incorrect: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g. acetazolamide) increase urine bicarbonate excretion. This causes serum bicarbonate to decrease and urine pH to increase, since bicarbonate is an alkaline substance. However, this medication class would also cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑ ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. 
❌  Serum Bicarbonate  Serum Potassium  Urine pH  ↑  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: The patient was started on a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (e.g. acetazolamide) for treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). The medication reduces bicarbonate absorption in the proximal convoluted tubule, thus decreasing serum bicarbonate levels. Moreover, the medication would cause hypokalemia as an adverse effect.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a recurrent, throbbing headache. The headache occurs over the left side of her head and is associated with nausea, photophobia, and vomiting without an associated aura. The patient has been using over-the-counter acetaminophen without relief from her symptoms. The headache is often triggered by eating chocolate and relieved by resting in a dark, quiet room. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for trigeminal neuralgia in the patient’s father. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate treatment option for this patient during these episodes?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with photophobia, nausea, and vomiting, consistent with migraine without aura. Triptans are recommended in patients who have moderate-to-severe migraine headaches or are unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics.

Triptans function as agonists at 5-HT1B and 5HT1D serotonin receptors to prevent vasoactive peptide release and reduce trigeminal nerve activation via vasoconstriction. These medications are also used as a first-line treatment option for managing acute cluster headaches. Examples include sumatriptan and zolmitriptan.

Side effects of triptans include pain or burning at the injection site when administered subcutaneously and paresthesias, fatigue,  and dizziness when administered orally. Since triptans are known to induce vasoconstriction, they can also raise blood pressure resulting in coronary vasospasm and angina. Triptans are contraindicated in patients with underlying hypertension, coronary artery disease, prinzmetal angina, and peripheral vascular disease. When used with other serotonin receptor agonists, Triptans can induce serotonin syndrome. Patients who have recently been given ergot alkaloids or other serotonin agonists should avoid triptans for at least 24 hours.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Erenumab is a human monoclonal antibody that antagonizes calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor function. It is approved as a preventive treatment for migraine, but it is not effective in the management of treating acute migraine.  
✅ 5-HT1B/1D agonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Beta-blocker:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers, such as propranolol, can be used for prophylaxis in managing migraines. It is not an abortive agent.  
❌ Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor:
Incorrect: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors effectively manage major depressive disorder, not acute migraine.  
❌ D2 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol are D2 receptor antagonists used to manage schizophrenia, psychosis, and bipolar disorder. It is not a practical option for the treatment of acute migraine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son because of a right-sided weakness that started an hour ago. According to the patient’s son, his mother initially experienced dizziness and developed right arm and leg weakness shortly afterward. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin and amlodipine. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mmHg. Physical examination shows a minimally responsive patient with 0/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities. CT scan head shows left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage with a 4 mm midline shift towards the right. The patient is started on a mannitol infusion. She is most likely to develop which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient received a mannitol infusion for management of elevated intracranial pressure. Mannitol works by rapidly increasing the plasma or tubular fluid osmolality, causing water to move from the intracellular space into the vascular space or tubular lumen. As the water is excreted, hypernatremia may follow. Water movement from the intracellular space to the extracellular space may cause hyponatremia and pulmonary edema. Additional side effects of mannitol therapy include headache, nausea, and vomiting.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is an adverse effect associated with a loop or thiazide diuretics. Osmotic diuretics do not affect potassium excretion.  
❌ Hypocalciuria:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule, thereby decreasing calcium excretion in the urine. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
✅ Hypernatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule and can lead to hypercalcemia. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This patient was started on mannitol to decrease intracranial pressure. Mannitol does not affect potassium excretion and would not cause hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman comes to an outpatient clinic for an annual checkup. The patient is accompanied by her daughter. The patient is feeling well except for some minor joint pain in both hips. She sometimes feels sad because her husband recently passed away. However, she continues to enjoy spending time with friends and family. The patient's daughter states that she has noticed her mother struggling with activities of daily living. It started two years ago with her forgetting simple instructions or having difficulty running errands. The patient can no longer pay her bills and sometimes forgets how to get home. Past medical history is significant for obesity, hypertension, and type II diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 158/108 mmHg. Neurological examination shows a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 7. The patient has 5/5 strength in the upper and lower extremities. No muscle rigidity is observed. Which of the following is the first-line treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a gradual decline in cognitive function, which is suggestive of Alzheimer dementia (AD). Anticholinesterases such as donepezil, galantamine, and rivastigmine are indicated for the treatment of Alzheimer disease.    

In Alzheimer disease, acetylcholine levels are decreased, especially in the front of the brain at a location called the basal nucleus of Meynert. The medications mentioned above have a tertiary structure, meaning they can cross the blood-brain barrier and are capable of increasing acetylcholine levels in the brain, resulting in symptomatic improvement.    

Edrophonium, neostigmine, and pyridostigmine, on the other hand, are examples of anticholinesterases with quaternary structures. They cannot cross the blood-brain barrier and only act in the peripheral nervous system.  

Option Analysis

❌ Edrophonium:
Incorrect: Edrophonium is the shortest acting anticholinesterase used to diagnose myasthenia gravis. It increases acetylcholine concentration in the synaptic cleft, causing a visible improvement in the patient’s muscle strength for a brief period. It does not cross the blood-brain barrier and would not help improve this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Neostigmine:
Incorrect: Neostigmine is an anticholinesterase inhibitor primarily used in the postoperative reversal of neuromuscular blockade. It can also treat myasthenia gravis, postoperative ileus, and urinary retention. However, neostigmine does not cross the blood-brain barrier and would not help improve this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Physostigmine:
Incorrect: Physostigmine is a tertiary amine that freely crosses the blood-brain barrier. It is an effective antidote for patients with anticholinergic toxicity but does not improve symptoms of Alzheimer dementia.  
✅ Rivastigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor used to treat a major depressive disorder, which may present with cognitive impairment and, in severe cases, dementia. This patient, however, does not meet the criteria for major depressive disorder.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of weakness. The patient recalls being so fatigued and weak at the end of the day that she is often unable to perform chores around the house. She has also developed difficulty chewing and swallowing foods. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder, hypertension, and seasonal allergies. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/84 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for 2/5 strength in the upper extremities and 4/5 strength in the lower extremities. Visual examination is notable for mild diplopia. The patient is started on the appropriate treatment and undergoes significant improvement. However, she is now experiencing frequent nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and excessive sweating. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diplopia and upper greater than lower extremity muscle weakness at the end of the day. These findings are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. Pyridostigmine is used to treat muscle weakness in patients with myasthenia gravis.    

The medication is a cholinesterase inhibitor that results in prolonged acetylcholine-mediated muscarinic and nicotinic receptor stimulation. Side effects of cholinesterase inhibitor use include increased smooth muscle contraction, causing miosis, diarrhea, urination, bronchospasms, and increased secretions leading to salivation, lacrimation, and sweating. They can also cause life-threatening emergencies by stimulating the central nervous system and leading to convulsions and coma. Finally, they can depress the cardiovascular system and cause bradycardia.   

Antimuscarinic, such as atropine, can be administered to reverse the side effects of cholinesterase inhibitors.  

Option Analysis

❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist and an important antidote in reversing muscarinic symptoms in organophosphate poisoning. It is also used to treat bradycardia and nocturnal enuresis and dilate the pupils for ophthalmologic examination. Atropine toxicity causes decreased gastric motility instead of diarrhea and abdominal cramps.  
✅ Pyridostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tizanidine:
Incorrect: Tizanidine is an ɑ2-receptor agonist used to manage muscle spasticity. Side effects include hypotension, weakness, and xerostomia. In contrast, this patient’s nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and excessive sweating are unlikely to be caused by tizanidine.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Side effects of β-blockers include erectile dysfunction, cardiovascular complications (e.g., bradycardia, AV block, heart failure exacerbation), as well as asthma and COPD exacerbations. Nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and excessive sweating are not seen.  
❌ Fluoxetine :
Incorrect: Fluoxetine can occasionally cause nausea, diarrhea, and excessive sweating. However, it is unlikely this patient was prescribed fluoxetine, given her symptoms are most consistent with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of throbbing headaches for three weeks. Yesterday, the patient had blurry vision in both eyes and an episode of double vision lasting minutes. The patient has been taking over-the-counter analgesics with only mild improvement in her symptoms. Past medical history is significant for polycystic ovarian syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and facial acne. She has not had any trauma, weakness, or changes in sensation. Current medications include metformin and isotretinoin. BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows decreased peripheral vision field testing. Fundoscopic findings of the left eye are demonstrated below, with similar findings in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the observed fundoscopic findings in this patient?  


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which typically presents in young obese females with daily headaches, bilateral symmetric papilledema, and transient visual disturbance. The fundoscopic findings of optic disc swelling (elevation of the optic disc with blurred disc margins) are suggestive of papilledema.  

Papilledema is a term exclusively used to describe optic disc swelling, secondary to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The optic nerve is surrounded by subarachnoid space containing cerebrospinal fluid, so any condition that raises ICP will compress this nerve. Prolonged compression also occludes the central retinal vein, resulting in venous engorgement and peripapillary hemorrhage. Additional conditions that can manifest with papilledema include central nervous system infections or tumors.   

Option Analysis

❌ Macular degeneration:
Incorrect: Degeneration of the macula can be observed in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), which is subdivided into dry and wet AMD. This condition results in the gradual loss of central vision and metamorphopsia in affected eyes.   
✅ Elevated intracranial pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Impaired retinal perfusion:
Incorrect: Impaired retinal perfusion occurs with central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO), often secondary to cardiac emboli in young patients and carotid atherosclerosis in geriatric patients. CRAO presents with acute painless visual loss in the affected eye.   
❌ Elevated intraocular pressure:
Incorrect: An acute elevation intraocular pressure is characteristic of acute-angle closure glaucoma, which typically presents with painful monocular vision loss, headache, vomiting, conjunctival injection, and a mid-dilated non-reactive pupil.  
❌ Middle cerebral artery embolism:
Incorrect: Embolic occlusion of the middle cerebral artery can lead to the development of contralateral homonymous hemianopia. However, owing to the extensive area of the brain that the MCA supplies, other signs of stroke, such as contralateral limb weakness and sensory loss, would also be apparent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office because of a two week history of cough, fatigue, impaired vision, and worsening headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient recently recovered from bacterial pneumonia two months ago. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for the last thirty-eight years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. After a thorough diagnostic workup, a diagnosis of metastatic small cell cancer of the lung is made. A schematic overview of the patient's visual fields is shown below. This patient is most likely to have a metastatic lesion in which of the following locations of the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
The visual pathway transmits visual information from the retina to the visual cortex through the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus, and optic radiations. The superior bundle of right optic radiations (right dorsal optic radiation) relays information from the left inferior quadrants of the visual field (i.e. from the right superior quadrant of both retinas). Therefore, damage to the right superior bundle of optic radiations would produce left lower homonymous quadrantanopia (“pie on the floor”).    

Other visual field defects that may be seen with lesions at different points along the optic nerve pathway are summarized in the diagram below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Right macula:
Incorrect: The right macula transmits visual information from the center of the right eye's visual field. Damage to the right macula (e.g. due to macular degeneration) results in right central scotoma.   
❌ Optic chiasm:
Incorrect: The optic chiasm is where the optic nerve fibers of the nasal side of the retina cross the midline. Damage to this structure would result in bitemporal hemianopsia.   
❌ Right optic tract:
Incorrect: The right optic tract transmits information from the left half of each eye's visual field (i.e., from the nasal half of the left retina and temporal half of the right retina). Damage to the right optic tract would result in left homonymous hemianopsia.   
❌ Right Meyer loop:
